webTitle: Airlines land on a new marketplace

fields.headline: Airlines land on a new marketplace
fields.standfirst: The internet-based pioneers of cheap air travel face serious competition
fields.trailText: The host of young entrepreneurs who began selling flight tickets over the internet made two bold promises: to fill more seats at lower prices and to pioneer a retail market on the web.
fields.body:
The host of young entrepreneurs who began selling flight tickets over the internet made two bold promises: to fill more seats at lower prices and to pioneer a retail market on the web.

Despite making progress on both counts, many flight booking websites have seen their fortunes fade as more competitors - including the airlines - enter the market. The battle for the online travel trade is likely to become even more intense, with increasing numbers of would-be travellers turning to the web for a better deal.

A typical example is IT consultant Bella Patel, 35, who bought a return ticket to Cape Town for just £233, plus £42 tax, at an internet flight auction. "A friend who works in the airline industry told me it was happening," she said. "I was shocked. I didn't expect to get a seat for that price."

She later attempted to book another seat on the same flights for a colleague and was quoted the full fare of £530 for a one-way ticket.

The deal was offered by Lufthansa, which uses the internet to auction off seats which have not been performing well on the high street.

"We look at what fares are doing over the next couple of months and if some are not selling well, we put them up for auction," said Sabine Graham of the airline's marketing services department.

'Comfortable'

British Midland offers a similar service and has sold more than 36,000 tickets for European flights in the past year through internet auction specialist QXL.com - some starting from £1 with no reserve.

Marc Charron, UK managing director of QXL, said the speed and flexibility of the internet could often match passenger demand, with flight availability far better than conventional booking agents.

"People are particularly comfortable booking flights online. While consumer confidence in other products is still growing, they really feel they know what they are getting when they buy plane tickets.

"The top sites are very easy to use these days and there is a growing confidence that customers can compare and contrast prices at several sites in three or four minutes."

Nevertheless, according to the civil aviation authority, an estimated 29% of seats on scheduled flights with UK airlines were empty last year and 11% were empty on chartered flights. The potential for innovative ways of bring passengers and airlines together on the net remains enormous, argue the e-commerce enthusiasts.

Lastminute.com has become Britain's highest profile net stock on the back of hopes that it would do just that by selling discount flights at the eleventh hour. A host of rivals including cheapflights.com, ebookers.com and expedia.com are also in the market.

Priceline.com, the US firm which launched its British operation, Priceline.co.uk, last month, offers reductions to travellers if they are prepared to be flexible about flight times and airlines. It invites customers to register what they are prepared to pay to travel to their chosen destination, then asks a range of carriers if they will accept the price. An answer is promised within an hour.

The company claims this formula has provided more than 5m travellers with between 20% and 80% reductions on published ticket prices since the service began in April 1998.

Mike Darcy, a spokesman for Priceline, said that while customers feel empowered when they name their own price, the airlines are happy too: they are filling seats without directly offering lower prices.

"The reason you cannot walk up to an airline and say: 'I know you have 10 free seats on this flight, I will buy one of them for half the price' is because that would make a mockery of the published prices. No one would ever book early if that were possible.

"By shielding the brand, we allow carriers to fill the seats without affecting their published rate structures."

This reverse auction variant so impressed the US markets earlier this year that Priceline was valued at $17bn and the firm claimed to be the most recognised dot.com brand in the US after Amazon.com. But, like many dot.com stocks, its has since taken a severe knocking, with a share price fall of 94% over seven months.

Mike Honor, a retail analyst at internet consultancy Forrester Research, said investors should not expect a switch from high street travel agent to online ticket sales to happen overnight. Not everyone is comfortable with the web or suited to the uncertainties of blind reverse auctions and last minute bargains.

"Nevertheless, airlines are increasingly venturing online. Not just to offload tickets that are not selling well, but to make big savings on a range of transaction costs at travel agents and call centres."

But while novel ways of selling more seats at cheaper prices may have been pioneered by young entrepreneurs at e-commerce start-ups, there is little to stop the airlines setting up in competition, he added.

Teaming up

"Pure internet players may have come up with a halfway decent business model but many do not have the funding or the experience to offer a long-term challenge. Many of the bigger name start-ups have spent a lot on marketing - burning through their cash to win market share without much concern for the longer term picture."

Already many airlines are manoeuvring into position on the web. In May, British Airways' chief executive, Rod Eddington, said he was considering teaming up with nine other major European carriers - including Air France, Lufthansa, and KLM - for a joint online booking operation.

In the US, a similar threat to the net pioneers looms in the shape of Hotwire.com, an online venture set up by American Airlines, United Airlines, US Airways Group and others.

With such competition on its heels, Priceline's launch in Britain has been low-key compared to the publicity that surrounded the American version.

Conspicuous in its absence has been the bold advertising campaign in which Star Trek's William Shatner boasts the site is destined to be "big ... really big". A lesson learned, perhaps.

webTitle: West Indian Jeremy has his jaw broken

fields.headline: West Indian Jeremy has his jaw broken
fields.trailText: West Indies' tour of Australia got off to a bad start yesterday when Kerry Jeremy's jaw was broken by a bouncer playing against Western Australia at the Waca.
fields.body:
Kerry Jeremy's first tour looks finished almost before it has begun. The 20-year-old West Indian fast-medium bowler had his jaw broken by a bouncer yesterday playing against Western Australia on the famously fiery Waca pitch in Perth.

It was a disastrous start to the tour for the West Indians. They lost the toss and collapsed to 132 all out. Matthew Nicholson, who took three for 32, ended the innings when his bouncer struck Jeremy, an Antiguan who has played one one-day international, in the face.

West Australia then made good progress towards a substantial first-innings lead, reaching 110 for two by the close.

Mike Hussey made 41 before falling to Marlon Black, the most efficient West Indian fast bowler. Justin Langer, quite recovered from another trying season at Middlesex, finished on 40 not out.

Tom Moody's decision to put the tourists in was quickly justified by his pace bowlers. The West Indians were reduced to 29 for four and then 64 for five, with all the victims falling to catches by the Australian Test wicketkeeper Adam Gilchrist.

With Brian Lara absent, only three players made it to 20. Ramnaresh Sarwan top-scored with 22.

 Hampshire have completed the signing of Neil Johnson, the Zimbabwean all-rounder, who will stand in for Shane Warne as the county's overseas player next season.

webTitle: Tres jolly but cut short by folly

fields.headline: Tres jolly but cut short by folly
fields.standfirst:
Governors XI 224
England 241-5
Scoreboard
fields.trailText: Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart were the mainstay of the innings as England reached 241-5 in reply to 224 from the Governors XI.
fields.body:
One rush of blood cost Marcus Trescothick his first first-class century for England here yesterday. One small lapse in concentration, when the rest of a golden day and the next beyond that stretched out before him.

He had made 93 in a manner both upright and forthright, pummelling the boundary relentlessly, when out of the blue he decided to trip lightly down the pitch to the left-arm spin of Mohammad Hussain.

This is a former Test bowler and no mug either. The batsman could not have telegraphed his intent more if he had blown a bugle.

Hussain saw him coming and angled the ball across Trescothick's bows instead of spinning it into his pads. Ball and batsman made only fleeting acquaintance before it disappeared into Rashid Latif's gloves. Trescothick, stumped by yards and feeling a fool, swished the turf angrily at his indiscretion.

In the dressing room they call him Tres and they might well add Bon to that, for this is a very good young batsman. His innings, containing 16 fours and a six picked up backward of square as clean as you like, involved survival of the new ball (swung vigorously and skilfully by the former Test left-armer Kabir Khan) and then some more expansive batting later when the ball was softer and the early moisture had been burned off on a day clear enough to reveal at last the mountains that horseshoe around Peshawar.

The Somerset left-hander's innings, and a delightfully belligerent one of 59 from Alec Stewart (just the sort of response that Nasser Hussain would have been expecting after the past week), meant that England closed last night on 240 for five, 16 ahead of the Governor's XI, the seamers Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Craig White having taken the remaining five wickets in the first 80 minutes of the day.

"I was very annoyed at getting out," said Trescothick. "I was looking forward to seeing the day out and then coming back for more. Instead I had a bit of a rush of blood.

"These things happen sometimes when I'm not in control of myself and this was such an occasion. It is still hurting and it will hurt for a good while yet."

He insists, though, that he will learn from it, which will be all to the good because English batsmen remain worryingly inept when they venture down the pitch to spin.

When a top player of spin - Sachin Tendulkar, say, or Carl Hooper - ventures from his crease, he does so late, and once he has gone he totally commits. The English have the air of batsmen who feel obliged to charge but are not comfortable doing it. Yesterday Michael Vaughan shuffled half-heartedly down the pitch to Hussain and was similarly stumped.

Stewart, who is not recognised as a notably good player of spin, showed how it can be done. After getting off the mark with a boundary, he went down the pitch to Hussain and spanked him straight for six and before he had reached his half-century he twice more repeated the stroke, for a four and another six.

Well as Trescothick played, Stewart's was the innings of the day. It ended when he tried to withdraw his bat from the pace of Sajid Shah and was adjudged to have edged a catch, bringing the day to a close.

Hussain, though, remains in indifferent form. He might, in more finger-happy times in this part of the world, have been given out lbw first up, after Mike Atherton had top-edged the opening ball after lunch to slip. He was not so lucky 35 deliveries later, when the same bowler, Kabir, pitched the ball in the same place, outside leg stump, yelled his raucous appeal and received a positive verdict.

fields.headline: Owen calms Liverpool nerves
fields.standfirst:
Stajner 9, Breda 85 | Barmby 30, Heskey 75, Owen 81
Liverpool win 4-2 on agg
fields.trailText: Michael Owen came off the bench to score after just 20 seconds as Liverpool laboured to victory in the Czech Republic.
fields.body:
Modern life now has three inevitabilities - taxes, death and Liverpool making things difficult for themselves when they should be strolling down Easy Street.

The good news is that as winning really is all that matters in knockout football the Merseysiders' first-ever competitive fixture in the Czech Republic was a success, albeit a far from unqualified one.

Indeed, not until the unknown, unfancied journeymen of Slovan Liberec began to tire did a team conservatively valued at £80m impose their will on proceedings and thus guarantee safe passage through into this morning's Uefa Cup third-round draw.

Three and a half weeks after sustaining a head injury during a League game at Derby County Michael Owen was back on duty, although with Robbie Fowler recalled to partner Emile Heskey he was on the substitute's bench until, after 81 minutes, he strolled on to score with his very first touch, a deflected drive from 25 yards.

Gérard Houllier was undoubtedly being charitable when he described the U Nisy stadium as homely; one can only assume that is a French euphemism for smallish verging on the primitive.

Still, despite the sub-zero temperatures the playing surface was admirable and, mercifully, Liverpool did not perform with the monumental ineptitude which had characterised their display in the first leg at Anfield when Liberec were beaten only by a very late goal.

This time we had an early goal - nine minutes in - and, astonishingly, it went to a Liberec team which had failed to land a single shot on target a fortnight ago. Not for the first time in recent weeks the Liverpool defence was collectively at fault. Roman Jun found the time in which to cross from the left and Jiri Stajner climbed above Christian Ziege at the far post to send a fine header beyond Sander Westerveld.

It took Liverpool time to digest the fact that the anticipated cake-walk had been unexpectedly transformed into a genuine competition, but the response was at least encouraging and both Heskey and Fowler began to make inroads into a leaden-footed defence.

Even so, it was 31 minutes before they restored parity, Nick Barmby flicking in a delightful header from Ziege's free-kick. At last Liverpool's football began to boast an acceptable level of authority and Heskey could have removed any doubt about the outcome after reaching first a Jamie Carragher cross, but his header found post rather than net.

Had Liverpool's finishing been more clinical we might have had a memorable rout, for as Liberec's appetite began to wane their defence toyed with the idea of capitulation.

But it came right in the end. Before Owen struck, Heskey capped a buccaneering display with a neat strike from a Vladimir Smicer cross 15 minutes from time. Liberec reduced the arrears with a splendid goal by the substitute David Breda but by then Liverpool had taken care of business.

Houllier was both content and relieved. "It was a very difficult game. We had a job to do, to qualify, and we have done that. We should have taken more of our chances. Their goalkeeper was tremendous, as he was in the first game.

"Owen has been out for almost a month but, in my opinion, he is fit enough to play for England in Italy next week. Him scoring just 20 seconds after coming on was a real bonus."

 Udinese, the leaders of Serie A, were knocked out by PAOK Salonika 3-1 on aggregate after a 3-0 win following extra-time. PAOK became the second Greek team to beat an Italian side in 24 hours after Juventus were eliminated from the Champions League with defeat at Panathinaikos.

Slovan Liberec ( 4-4-2): Hauzr; Capek, Michalik (Breda, 84), Lexa, Stajner; Jun (Nezmar, 81), Johana, Janu, Neumann; Liuni (Kozuch, 72), Pilny.

Liverpool (4-4-2 ): Westerveld; Carragher (Murphy, 54), Hyypia, Babbel, Ziege; Smicer, Gerrard, Hamann (Owen, 82), Barmby; Fowler (McAllister, 62), Heskey.

Referee: E Steinmuller (Germany).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: O'Leary's kitty boosted by £10m
fields.trailText: Progression to the second phase has boosted David O'Leary's transfer funds by £10m, and the first purchase is likely to be a striker despite the club's continued pursuit of Rio Ferdinand.
fields.body:
David O'Leary's transfer funds have been boosted by £10m following Leeds United's progress to the second phase of the Champions League.

The extra revenue generated by Leeds' success has been promised to the manager to bolster his squad and, while Leeds are still hopeful of persuading West Ham to part with their central defender Rio Ferdinand for £15m, O'Leary's first purchase is likely to be a striker.

Azar Karadas and Thorstein Helstad, forwards who play for the Norwegian side Brann Bergen, arrive today to begin a trial at Elland Road after being watched closely by Leeds scouts in the past few months.

Brann have been reluctant to sell the pair, but a director at the club, Arne Moller, said yesterday: "We have thought about this deal after receiving many requests. We have said no to all the other invitations, but we still needed to keep the doors open and as Leeds have followed us throughout the season, we felt if we were going to do this we should let them have the chance.

"The players will not be joining any other club on trial and there is a good chance they could join Leeds permanently. We think they are the right club for both players to go to."

The 16 teams who have qualified for the second phase of the Champions League can register three more players before February 1, although they will not be eligible for the first two games which will be played in the next four weeks.

Rangers, who narrowly failed to progress in the Champions League, have been offered Liverpool's striker Titi Camara on loan with a view to a permanent deal. "We are looking into the deal," said the Rangers chairman David Murray. "Much will depend on just how quickly our current injury problems can clear."

Hearts supporters have threatened to give up their season tickets in protest at the actions of the club's chief executive Chris Robinson and his board. Jim Jefferies resigned on Wednesday while his assistant Billy Brown was sacked, and the supporters' club has started a petition to have Robinson removed.

"Reading between the lines, the situation has been between Jim Jefferies and Chris Robinson and unfortunately Jim is the one who has moved on," said the secretary of the federation of Hearts supporters clubs, John Borthwick. "We would have preferred Chris Robinson to have moved on."

Rudi Völler will remain in charge of the German national side until the 2002 World Cup. Christophe Daum, who was expected to take the post in June 2001, has been passed over after he failed a drugs test.

The former Norwich and Everton manager Mike Walker has been appointed as coach of the Cypriot side Apoel Nicosia.

webTitle: Who ate all the prawns? Keane accuses United fans

fields.headline: Who ate all the prawns? Keane accuses United fans
fields.trailText: Roy Keane has launched a blistering attack on the club's supporters after the poor atmosphere created during the United's victory over Dynamo Kiev on Wednesday night.
fields.body:
Prawn sandwiches made an unexpected return to the national consciousness yesterday when Manchester United's captain, Roy Keane, chose an analogy made famous by Gerald Ratner to deliver a withering attack on the club's supporters.

Disillusioned by the lack of atmosphere at Old Trafford during United's 1-0 win over Dynamo Kiev on Wednesday, Keane claimed the 66,776 fans present did not create the right noise for such a crucial Champions League game.

"There were one or two stray passes and they were getting on players' backs. It's out of order," he said. "I don't think some of them can even spell football, let alone understand it.

"Away from home our fans are fantastic. But at home they have a few drinks and probably the prawn sandwiches, and they don't realise what's going on out on the pitch."

Yesterday there were already signs that he might grow to regret all reference to prawn sandwiches, as Mr Ratner did nine years ago when he said that some of his store's earrings cost less than a Marks & Spencer prawn sandwich, and didn't last as long. The remark led to a fall in profits.

Keane's remark, directed at the new breed of corporate United fans, was quickly taken up on a national radio phone-in, with callers pointing out that the money paid by the crustacean-eating classes funded his £50,000-a-week wages.

"It's very difficult for people to get passionate shouting about 11 millionaires," said one.

Although prawn sandwiches are not actually sold in Old Trafford, Keane's criticism was supported by the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association. "Broadly speaking, I agree," said Andy Walsh, its chairman. "Over-zealous stewarding, all-seater stadiums and the price of tickets have helped reduce the atmosphere."

webTitle: United's Cole out until next year

fields.headline: United's Cole out until next year
fields.trailText: Andy Cole will be out until next year because of an achilles tendon injury.
fields.body:
Andrew Cole's flying start to the season has been brought to a juddering halt with the news that he will be out until next year because of an achilles tendon injury.

Although Cole was able to participate fully in Manchester United's victory over Dynamo Kiev on Wednesday night, which ensured their progress into the second phase of the Champions League, the striker was ruled out of Peter Taylor's England squad which was announced yesterday.

Cole has been an ever-present for England this season, playing the full 90 minutes in each of Kevin Keegan's last three games in charge - the friendly against France and the World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland - although he is yet to score a goal for his country. While the 29-year-old will miss next week's friendly against Italy in Turin, he should be back in contention to win his 11th cap in the match against Spain at Villa Park in February.

Cole, who has scored nine goals this season as his partnership with Teddy Sheringham has blossomed, will undergo surgery on Tuesday and is expected to be out for two months.

United were keen to avoid losing Cole before they had secured their progress from the first phase of the Champions League and, although he will miss the first two matches of the second phase, Sir Alex Ferguson said yesterday that his striker could not afford to wait any longer.

"Andy has been carrying this for so long now that it's necessary," United's manager said. "Now we are over the first stage of the Champions League we hope he will be ready for the next stage. It's disappointing, but it needs to be done."

Cole is also likely to miss 10 Premiership matches, including the derby against Manchester City a week on Sunday and the visit of Liverpool to Old Trafford on December 17.

With Sheringham, who has scored 12 goals this season, in such prolific form Dwight Yorke and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer will be fighting for Cole's place in United's attack.

fields.headline: Taylor starts the youth revolution
fields.standfirst:
Beckham the new England captain but no place for the 30-somethings
Introducing the young guns
England squads
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor has stuck to his word and gone for youth for England's friendly against Italy next Wednesday. But that still doesn't explain why he has included Seth Johnson, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor, who had promised an injection of young talent into England's squad for the friendly against Italy in Turin next Wednesday, has been as good as his word. Indeed the manager has gone for youth in such a big way that he is not so much a caretaker as a childminder.

Fifteen of the squad of 26 announced by Taylor yesterday are under 25. The average age is 23 and would be even lower but for the presence of two Aston Villa 30-year-olds, Gareth Southgate and David James.

The team will be captained by David Beckham, who at 25 may feel positively middle-aged in this company. "I was impressed with David when he took a lot of stick after being sent off against Argentina in the 1998 World Cup," Taylor explained. "A lot of the criticism was unfair but he took it well."

Earlier this season Keegan nominated Beckham as a future captain and later made him vice-captain, but few could have countenanced the likelihood that he would be wearing the armband so soon.

Yet only last month Beckham declared that he considered himself sufficiently mature to take the job. "I'm growing up both as a footballer and as a person," he said.

Among the regulars omitted for the Italy match are four previous captains - Tony Adams, David Seaman, Paul Ince and Martin Keown, who led the side in Helsinki 3 weeks ago. Teddy Sheringham, whom Howard Wilkinson recalled for that game, is another absentee along with Dennis Wise, Steve McManaman and both the injured Coles, Andy and Joe. Nigel Martyn and Graeme le Saux are also unfit.

It remains to be seen whether the likes of Adams, Ince, Wise, Seaman or Sheringham decide to take the hint and retire from international football altogether now. This is not Taylor's intention but as he said yesterday after speaking to most of those left out: "I'm not sure all of them were 100% happy, as I wouldn't be, but I think they understood the situation."

The benchmark of 30-plus is no accident. As Taylor explained: "I decided to pick people of 30 or under because I am treating this match as a one-off and I want to give players who have shown their potential with the under-21s an opportunity against tough opposition at senior level."

Taylor's three years as England Under-21 coach under Glenn Hoddle are reflected in his choice of 11 of those who played for him during this period. Some, like Gareth Barry, Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer, Michael Owen and Emile Heskey, are already established in the senior squad.

Manchester United's Wes Brown would have been capped more than once but for injury and Taylor clearly feels that Frank Lampard is worth more than the cap he won in last season's friendly against Belgium. Taylor will hope that Liverpool's Steven Gerrard stays fit; if not then Manchester United's Nicky Butt is in the squad as a midfield cover.

The inclusion of Michael Ball, initially promising on the left at Everton but with only five starts to his name this season, is a mild surprise. That is nothing, however, compared with the presence of Derby County's Seth Johnson, a moderate left-sided midfielder who was banned from internationals for three months by Wilkinson after breaking a curfew, with two other players, during this summer's European under-21 championship.

Nevertheless Taylor may feel he needs Johnson on the left side of midfield although with Barry, Fowler and Ball available England are better off for naturally left-footed players than they have been for some time. In any case the more experienced Nick Barmby and Darren Anderton can each operate on this flank if need be.

With James, in sound form for Villa just now, joined by Paul Robinson of Leeds and Ipswich's Richard Wright, Taylor has strong options in goal. His under-21 leanings may see a second cap for Wright. Robinson, Taylor confirmed yesterday, will be the third choice in Turin.

The England caretaker has a team in mind but will not decide on either personnel or formation until after the weekend's Premiership programme which may bring more injuries and withdrawals. At Leicester, Taylor likes to use a 3-5-2 system and while he would opt for 4-4-2 if he felt it appropriate, England could line up against Italy thus: Wright; Ferdinand, Southgate, Barry; Dyer, Beckham, Scholes, Gerrard, Johnson; Heskey, Owen.

webTitle: BT gets cautious thumbs-up from regulator

fields.headline: BT gets cautious thumbs-up from regulator
fields.trailText: Telecoms regulator Oftel has told BT it expected "further improvements" before it is satisfied it is doing all it can to open up its local exchanges, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Telecoms regulator Oftel has told BT it expected "further improvements" before it is satisfied that the company is doing all it can to open up its local exchanges to competing telecoms and internet service providers.

Anne Lambert, Oftel director of operations, was speaking today after BT announced plans to allow rival operators access to 600 of its local exchanges by July 2001.

The unbundling move will give operators - including those offering high-speed internet services - access to BT's local loop networks, which are the local copper wire between an exchange and officer or home.

Ms Lambert said: "Oftel has made it clear to BT that it expects further improvements to be made and we will ensure that no resources are spared in preparing its exchanges as quickly as possible.

"There is a lot more work to be done by Oftel, BT and the operators. But today gives a sound basis for taking the process forward."

BT is proposing to unbundle 190 local loops where operators can install the necessary equipment in its exchanges and 410 where they must find space in adjacent buildings.

After July 2001, BT is proposing to open up a further 200 local loops per month, with operators allowed into its exchanges in half the areas and finding their own accommodation in the other half.

BT has also proposed a service level agreement that includes penalty payments for late delivery of local loop access.

But rival telecoms operators, who have been lobbying Oftel for months to force BT to unbundle its local loops, remained sceptical about how quickly the company would move.

Jonathan Watts, managing director of Colt Telecom, said that BT had already been committed to allowing rival operators into 190 of its local exchanges and in the 410 other exchange areas the plan "relies on competitors finding properties as close as possible to the exchange and converting".

"This is the second best option. It lets BT off the hook, because they don't have to allow us space in their exchanges."

Mr Watts said the move was therefore "not quite as significant as BT are claiming", but was still the "first time we have seen something positive" happening on the local loop unbundling issue.

webTitle: The debate between who will run the lottery continues

fields.headline: The debate between who will run the lottery continues
fields.trailText: The commons committee have to decide whether the next franchise should go to the company which has run it for seven years with few glitches and has handed over £10.5 bn for good causes - or the people who gave us Virgin Trains.
fields.body:
The Commons culture committee looked at the national lottery yesterday. They have to decide whether the next franchise should go to the company which has run it for seven years with few glitches and has handed over £10.5 bn for good causes - or the people who gave us Virgin Trains.

Sir Richard Branson was suddenly among us. He affected his most Bransonian style: scuffed shoes, open-neck shirt, and hair so tousled it must take hours for handmaidens to glue every single lock in place. He has the amiable, slightly pleading manner of the most ruthless public schoolboys.

But first, the committee chairman, Gerald Kaufman, said that he had a declaration of interest to make. We waited anxiously. Had he taken money from Sir Richard in brown envelopes? Or passed a month sunbathing gratis on the tycoon's tropical island? Apparently not. "I asked Virgin Atlantic to help a very seriously disabled boy in my constituency to visit Florida, and Virgin Atlantic made that possible."

Hearing this solemn confession, Sir Richard appeared delighted at his own munificence. "Millionaire gives invalid child plane seat which was crossing Atlantic anyway" might not be thought wildly generous, so half an hour later Mr Kaufman interrupted the session again to say that he wished to clarify the matter: "I only came to Virgin to help the boy, because British Airways refused." At this point several of his colleagues on the committee - I won't name them, they have to go travelling with him - buried their faces in their hands.

Running a lottery is, of course, about greed. For example, shortly before Sir Richard arrived, Camelot said they were about to launch a new game called Lottery Extra, which will have rollovers of a maximum £50m. This is a huge sum, similar to that Gordon Brown has given the hauliers, for whom every week is now a rollover week.

Sir Richard says that his People's Lottery will work on a non-profit basis. The committee looked sceptical. What, they wanted to know, was in it for him? Apparently it's because he is a saint. His only wish is to do the best for everyone. How would he recruit staff? "They will be extremely proud to work for the best company in Britain, doing the most good for Britain!" he said, teeth flashing like a wolf with its own TV chat show. "Our only duty is to maximise the amount of money devoted to good causes," he said repeatedly.

He told us that his chief executive, Simon Burridge, had left an excellent job to join the People's Lottery. Mr Burridge has absorbed an impressive amount of lottery jargon since his arrival. On scratch cards: "What people are interested in is not scratching, but the theme they're scratching." Sounds like a bored ape in a zoo.

We learned his philosophy of running lotteries: "Successful lotteries are based on failure. We need to give people permission to lose, and to feel good about losing."

But he too was asked what was in it for him. "To work for a product which touches the lives of so many people," he replied. "I think of what my child asks when I get home: 'what did you do at work today, daddy?'"

All this was too much for many committee members, who, as Mr Burridge continued to talk about "enhancing the fabric of the UK" looked as if they might detract from the fabric of the House of Commons by barfing over it.

But Sir Richard clearly felt it had all been a great success, and left the committee with that familiar, engaging grin which makes some people want to hurl a brick.

fields.headline: Private finance and public health
fields.standfirst: How does the NHS benefit from the Private Finance Initiative?
fields.trailText: How does the NHS benefit from the Private Finance Initiative?
fields.body:
Why does the NHS need private finance? Over the years the health service has been starved of public capital funding - the money used to buy new equipment and build new hospitals. The lack of cash has not been helped by the service's tendency to use capital funds to pay for increases in the price of drugs, staff pay and other "revenue" costs. This has resulted in crumbling hospitals and a maintenance backlog of more than £3bn.

To which projects has the PFI been applied? To date, the government has focused on pushing through the large, acute hospital projects, such as the new £66m Baglan hospital in Wales. However other projects include new mental health facilities, information technology, scanners and GP surgeries.

What is the total value of private finance in the NHS? Across the UK, building work has started on 108 projects worth a total of £2.28bn, while two new hospitals, at Carlisle and South Buckinghamshire, are now open.

How successful has it been? Between 1992 and 1997, not at all. But with so many new hospitals being built and a handful now open it could be said that the current government's handling of the initiative has been successful. However, critics say the real problems will kick in once the hospitals are open and the NHS has to pay for them. No-one can be sure whether the PFI will be successful until a problem occurs or the contracts end without a hitch.

Why are critics against the PFI in the health sector? Critics believe the PFI leads to a reduction in bed numbers. Studies for UNISON and the British Medical Association have shown bed numbers at the new hospitals in Durham and Carlisle have fallen by 24 per cent and 15 per cent respectively. The government's National Beds inquiry in spring 2000 ordered all PFI schemes to take another look at the number of beds in their proposed hospitals.

What next for NHS PFI? The PFI will provide £7bn of capital investment by 2010. Particular attention will be paid to GP premises and the government will set up a new body, NHS Lift, to invest up to £1bn in new surgeries over the next 10 years. The government is also keen to "bundle" groups of PFI projects to make them more attractive to investors and cheaper for the public sector.

webTitle: BBC in running for Derby rights

fields.headline: BBC back in the running for Derby rights
fields.trailText: Friday 6pm update: The BBC could regain live coverage of the Derby after 20 years, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC could regain live coverage of the Derby after 20 years, after signing non-exclusive deals with both bidders for TV horseracing rights in the UK.

The corporation has signed up with both the Go Racing consortium - formed by Channel 4, BSkyB and racecourse owner Arena Leisure - and Carlton Communications to continue covering its existing live horse racing events, including the Grand National.

A BBC spokesman confirmed that as part of the agreement in principle with Carlton, the corporation would also acquire exclusive live rights to the Derby, which are currently held by Channel 4.

It is also understood that under the terms agreed with Go Racing, Channel 4 could give up the Derby rights.

webTitle: Unclear drugs guidance leaves social workers in difficult position

fields.headline: Unclear drugs guidance leaves social workers in difficult position
fields.standfirst: The law gives little guidance to social care workers confronted with occupants using drugs on hostel premises, writes Charlotte Cook
fields.trailText: Drugs seem to be the new cause celebre of the political and social landscape. From the experiences of two hostel workers in Cambridge, to Ann Widdecombe's comments at the Conservative party conference, it is clear that soft drugs have now extended beyond the usual remit of students and the intellectual elite. They concern us all.
fields.body:
Drugs seem to be the new cause celebre of the political and social landscape. From the experiences of two hostel workers in Cambridge, to Ann Widdecombe's comments at the Conservative party conference, it is clear that soft drugs have now extended beyond the usual remit of students and the intellectual elite. They concern us all.

Many people see the use of drugs as either a medical assistance, a way to escape the ills of society, or merely a recreational substance, suitable even for shadow cabinet ministers. With such widespread use, it is not surprising that social care providers will be confronted with instances of their own residents seeking to employ similar standards.

The 1971 Misuse of Drugs Act prohibits "suffering" the use of certain drugs on care hostel premises. "Suffering" is a confusing term - ranging from turning a blind eye (or nose) to people smoking cannabis, to actively knowing that dealing is taking place on the premises and not doing anything to stop it. Keeping a "banned book" listing the names of people believed to be dealing on the premises has been interpreted in a recent case as strong enough evidence that workers knew dealing was taking place, and were therefore guilty of an offence. Others may see this as the hostel seeking to protect residents from known dealers.

For many care workers, there are issues of policy involved - and the question of whether they are truly exercising their duty of care to the occupants of a hostel if they do not provide a safe place for people to take drugs, or to be protected from drugs. What seems most unjust to many workers, whether they approve of or condone the use of drugs or not, is that the activities of visitors to a drop-in centre - over whom they have very little control - can lead to them being subject to criminal action.

Why should the smoking of cannabis by the occupant of a care home be enough to prejudice a care worker's employment, or put them in fear of imprisonment? The law does not expect citizens to spy on their neighbours' use or abuse of non-prescription drugs. It is accepted that the responsibility placed upon workers in care hostels, and indeed in other sectors of the care community, will extend to the health, safety and welfare of those residents - but how far should that responsibility extend? Issues of privacy, which could be breached by a housing worker wishing to have access to an individual's private room, could then come into play. It may be open to residents to claim under the Human Rights Act that their right to a private and family life is breached.

Whatever our own individual views on the use or legalisation of non-prescription drugs, the law as it stands gives little guidance as to how one should act. Many police forces will turn a blind eye to the use of drugs such as cannabis. They may even consider the use of needles for injecting drugs to be better handled if done in the safety of a social care provider's premises - where sharps bins are provided for safe disposal. Addicts are not then seen to menace members of society by "hanging around" on street corners.

The main question for care providers is to ensure that they continue to act, and to be seen to act, within the law, but also that they treat their residents as responsible, right thinking and reasonable people.

 Charlotte Cook is a solicitor at Trowers & Hamlins

webTitle: Nov 10: diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Visions in Catford
fields.standfirst: Social services director Lisa Christensen is up to her neck in action plans, targets and milestones in Lambeth, but stops off for a bit of primary care visioning in south-east London
fields.trailText: This week, spent a lot of time presenting and discussing the Barratt report and the social services inspectorate (SSI) report into our children's services with staff and members. Impressed with the way in which staff from adult services are recognising the relevance of the messages for them.
fields.body:
This week, spent a lot of time presenting and discussing the Barratt report and the social services inspectorate (SSI) report into our children's services with staff and members. Impressed with the way in which staff from adult services are recognising the relevance of the messages for them.

Tuesday brought a discussion with the management team about the next report on our performance which will be hitting the streets shortly - the report of the joint review carried out in May and June this year. Our action plan (not another one I hear you cry) is drafted and clearly sets out the tasks, milestones, targets etc. It has taken a lot of work and there will be still more work when we come to integrate it with our other action plan that relates to the SSI inspection and the grandaddy plan which is our improvement plan (drafted when we became monitored under special measures). Are you still with me?

If you are confused, imagine how staff here will feel if we don't manage to translate this ghastly process into something that is meaningful to the average home care worker/social worker/admin support officer.

Attended a big primary care trust visioning event in Catford, south-east London, on Wednesday - useful but not enough discussion of care trusts for my liking. We are very keen to follow the logic of our increasingly close relationships with health colleagues and get some creative and effective solutions that increase flexibility for users. We see our improvement agenda in adult services as inextricably linked to integration with health agencies.

Visit one of the children's area offices who are going through the chaos of moving as part of the implementation of the restructure of services - desks too big, files in crates and remarkably little moaning - people want to get on.

 Lisa Christensen is social services director of Lambeth council in south-east London

webTitle: City cautious over proposed Bertelsmann/EMI merger

fields.headline: City cautious over proposed Bertelsmann/EMI merger
fields.trailText: The City has given a tentative thumbs up to the proposed merger between EMI and Bertelsmann Music Group, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The City has given a tentative thumbs up to the proposed merger between EMI and Bertelsmann Music Group.

Analysts said a deal now has a better chance of getting past EU regulators, after they forced EMI to pull out of its £12bn link-up with Warner Music.

EMI's shares shot up 10% upon news of the deal, which had followed a week of feverish speculation, but soon fell back to 562.5p, up 3.5%, by late afternoon.

"A BMG and EMI link-up stands a better chance than the Warner deal because the combined back catalogue of the two groups would only be marginally larger than Warner's," said Helen Snell, media analyst at ABN Amro.

The Warner Music deal collapsed due to watchdog concerns over the combined group's share of the music publishing market and its possible dominance of the internet music market.

The merger of Warner Music's parent company Time Warner with internet giant AOL convinced regulators that the EMI deal would restrict the market for music downloads over the web.

Bertelsmann's web interests, which include the Lycos Europe internet service provider, are thought to pose a smaller threat.

EMI has an extensive list of artists from the Rolling Stones to Robbie Williams, making it an attractive proposition for content-hungry media companies.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and even Spanish mobile phone company Telefonica have been mentioned as possible bidders since the postponement of the Warner joint venture.

EMI's shares rose 3.5%, or 18.5p to 562.5p by late afternoon.

webTitle: Racist complaints against police highest ever

fields.headline: Racist complaints against police highest ever
fields.standfirst:
The PCA's annual report
Special report: race in Britain
fields.trailText: The number of racist complaints against police escalated by 75% last year to the highest figure ever recorded, it was disclosed today.
fields.body:
The number of racist complaints against police escalated by 75% last year to the highest figure ever recorded, it was disclosed today.

The Police Complaints Authority (PCA) dealt with 579 allegations of racist behaviour by police last year, compared to 331 the year before, according to their annual report released today.

Complaints against officers have risen from 17% to 23% among ethnic minorities in general, with the percentage of complaints from the Asian community more than doubling over the last five years.

One incident cited in the report centred on an officer who faced disciplinary action after referring to several Asian suspects as "Pakis".

The PCA chairman, Sir Alistair Graham, said: "We have seen a significant rise in the number of complaints of racially discriminatory behaviour by police officers.

"While we can only speculate as to the reasons for the increase, we believe it may reflect, in the aftermath of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, a greater willingness by members of the black and minority ethnic community to register a concern about how they feel they have been treated."

The report also shows that the number of people dying in police stations almost halved from 36 in 1998-99 to 19 last year. The installation of more CCTV cameras in stations is partly behind the reduction, the report said.

There was a record number of independent investigations into motor accidents involving police cars. A total of 22 people died and 16 were seriously injured in 21 pursuits investigated by the PCA. These 21 investigations last year compared with 17 the year before and nine in 1997-98.

"There is worrying evidence that the skill and judgment of some police drivers are open to question and criticism," said Sir Graham.

The report also welcomed the Metropolitan police's decision to fit aircraft-style black boxes inside patrol cars.

Last year saw the highest ever level of woman complainants - 24% of the total. The number of claims from people aged over 45 also rose from 8% in 1997-98 to 18% in 1999-2000.

Other complaints included the issue of CS gas use. The report raised concerns over the spray being used at too close a range, being used in cars, when a subject was already restrained and accidentally spraying members of the public.

In all, the PCA dealt with 17,932 complaints against police officers, including 182 of serious assault, 64 of sexual assault and 78 of corrupt practice.

Within the report there was evidence of a number of regional hotspots for grievances against officers.

Heading the league for the most complaints per officer is Cambridgeshire with one complaint for every 3.7 officers (342 complaints directed at 1,272 officers).

This contrasts with one complaint for every 16.7 officers in Durham (93 complaints directed at 1,555 officers).

Other high complaint areas include Suffolk and Sussex with one complaint for every four officers - 290/1,160 and 717/2,909 respectively.

In Merseyside, the number of complaints per officer was just under one in five (822/4,071).

In London there was one complaint for every 6.3 officers (4,045/25,885). The average for all forces in England and Wales was one complaint for every 7.2 officers (17,932/128,408).

fields.headline: Council apologises to race victim
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An Asian shopkeeper and his partner who have endured nine years of racial abuse at their shop on a Lancaster housing estate yesterday attacked an apology finally received from the city's council as "grudging and insincere".
fields.body:
An Asian shopkeeper and his partner who have endured nine years of racial abuse at their shop on a Lancaster housing estate yesterday attacked an apology finally received from the city's council as "grudging and insincere".

Mal Hussein and Linda Livingstone were first targeted in 1991 when they bought a corner shop and upstairs flat on the run down Ryelands housing estate. The Pakistani-born shopkeeper has recorded more than 2,000 incidents, including being shot at twice. The council apology comes in the week when the worst attacks have traditionally occurred. Every November between 1991 and 1996 the couple were firebombed inside their home.

The written apology opens with "profound regret" for these events, which it says "stained" the city's reputation.

It continues: "The council regrets that the initiatives we took, though undertaken in good faith, were initially not sufficiently effective in reducing the incidents of harassment. It regrets too that it took much longer than we would have wished to gather sufficient evidence to take effective action against offenders."

The apology acknowledged and regretted the "long term suffering and indignity" endured by the couple. "We also acknowledge and regret that many innocent residents of Ryelands have been stigmatised as racist."

Mr Hussein and race campaigners yesterday attacked the apology, which arrived by post following a council debate and vote last week, as "grudging and insincere".

Mr Hussein said the council's approach further demonstrates that "the real bigotry lies in the corridors of power because there is no political will to make changes. That is why it is fundamentally important that we have a public inquiry".

Last year Lancashire police made a personal and unreserved apology to the couple for its repeated failure over eight years to investigate the violent campaign against them. The couple are considering a legal claim against the chief constable of Lancashire.

Lee Jasper, secretary of the National Assembly Against Racism and political adviser to London mayor Ken Livingstone, described the council's apology as "a slap in the face for Mal and the black residents of Lancaster".

Last year civil liberties lawyers took the government to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg for Lancaster council's failures.

Solicitor Clive Romain of Bindman Partners said they would submit the apology to the European court, which has to decide whether to allow the case to proceed to the second stage where the government will have to respond.

webTitle: BT forced to open up access to its networks

fields.headline: BT forced to open up access to its networks
fields.trailText: BT is to speed up access to its high-speed internet technology under pressure from rival operators and telecoms watchdog Oftel, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BT is to speed up access to its high-speed internet technology under pressure from rival operators and telecoms watchdog Oftel.

The unbundling of its local loop networks, the copper wire between an exchange and office or home, has become the most contentious issue in the industry.

Today BT, which has faced widespread criticism from rival telecoms and internet service providers for dragging its feet in opening up its networks to greater competition, is going to give its rivals access to an initial 600 exchange areas in the first six months of 2001.

Local loop unbundling (LLU) will enable other operators to rent BT's local lines and offer telecoms and internet services directly to customers.

Ian Morfett, BT director of regulatory affairs, said: "Our proposals will substantially boost early availability of unbundling. We see significant commercial value in LLU across Europe and expect it to bring exciting opportunities for our ventures in other EU countries."

webTitle: Tarnished honour in celebrity honorary degrees

fields.headline: Tarnished honour in celebrity honorary degrees
fields.standfirst: Today, Sir Denis Thatcher joins the long list of celebrities who have been awarded honorary degrees. The danger, argues Lee Elliot Major, is that these publicity stunts are devaluing the reputation of degrees as a whole
fields.trailText: Today, Sir Denis Thatcher joins the long list of celebrities who have been awarded honorary degrees. The danger, argues Lee Elliot Major, is that these publicity stunts are devaluing the reputation of degrees as a whole
fields.body:
David Hockney remarked last June that being an honorary university doctor four times over may sound grand, "but you cannot write out prescriptions for your own drugs on this."

For those who have sacrificed years to complete a PhD, only to have to explain for evermore that they are not in fact medical doctors, the artist's comments may grate. But Hockney's pledge to accept no more honorary degrees signals a backlash against a populist trend in university degree awarding ceremonies.

Hockney's degree, awarded by the Leeds University Chancellor, Lord Melvyn Bragg, represented the epitome of this modern academic phenomenon: a celebrity PR coup for Leeds, outdoing the ceremonies being publicised by other universities.

Today, Sir Denis Thatcher becomes the latest famous appointee to this ever expanding club of honorands. He is to receive an honorary degree from Buckingham University - perhaps fittingly for the Thatchers the only UK academic institution independent of state finances.

One can only wonder what Sir Denis is being honoured for. Services to amateur golf? Being married to a tyrant? (Or could it be that Denis's wife happens to be a long serving chancellor of the university?) "It is an honour that I have neither earned nor deserved," he has said. "Nonetheless I am proud to become an Honorary Graduate of such a distinguished University as is Buckingham."

Since their very beginnings, universities have used honorary degrees to win influential friends. Usually the recipients were those in power: royalty, the clergy, politicians and, more latterly, business leaders. The degrees were presented as recognition of worthy accomplishments outside the ivory towers.

But recently there has been a new phenomenon: the celebrity honorary degree. Those honoured now include pop stars (Mick Hucknall, Umist), boxers (Lennox Lewis, North London University), and former children's TV presenters (Johnny Ball, Glasgow University). The bigger the celebrity, the more publicity gained by the university.

The problem with the proliferation of honorary degrees is that, inevitably, it devalues the reputation of university degrees as a whole. Currently, there are plans to unify the degree system across Europe - ensuring that degrees, wherever they are awarded, represent the same academic standards.

Universities need to think of the millions of unknowns who have worked hard to complete degrees and PhDs, before handing out awards to the next Thatcher or Hockney. And Hockney is doing the honourable thing by not accepting degrees anymore.

webTitle: Predicting Peter,  Grinning Gerard, and  Running Ron

fields.headline: Predicting Peter,  Grinning Gerard, and  Running Ron
fields.trailText: BIG CUP ROUND TWO DRAW ONE
fields.body:
BIG CUP ROUND TWO DRAW ONE

Today's Big Cup draw has an eerily - some might say suspiciously - familiar, ring to it. Just as in the first phase, Manchester United have an open goal of a group, and Arsenal's task is relatively straightforward too. Meanwhile, Leeds will have to get past Lazio, Anderlecht and Real Madrid, climb K2, and recite the weekly diet of Lennart Johannsen in Swedish before Uefa will let them anywhere near the quarter-finals.

In any case, that's how the Fiver sees it, rubbing its strangely magnetic balls. Oddly enough, Manchester United chairman Martin Edwards agrees with us. After seeing his side paired with Valencia, Sturm Graz and Panathaniakos, he admitted: "I think it is a good group. It could have been worse, as they say, and it's a draw which gives us a good opportunity of progressing." And with that he was off, presumably to plan a trip to Busty Birgit's Bordello Bar.

Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein was also happy with the draw, which sees the Gunners play Bayern Munich, Spartak Moscow and Lyon. "Our aim is to win [Big Cup]," he thundered, in a refreshing change to all this "we're not old enough to win it" baloney you get from some Premiership managers. Unsurprisingly, Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale was in a hippy, dippy, bordering-on-trippy mood. "Coming back on the plane from Milan we were all dreaming about playing Real Madrid and going back to Rome again," he revealed, "and we have got our wish." Ridsdale then went on to predict a Leeds v Manchester United final. Has he never been told to be careful what he wishes for?

GOLIATH TO MEET PLUCKY DAVID

The Fiver is always pleased when small clubs are rewarded for giant-killing exploits. So hats off to plucky Liverpool, who last night stunned the world of football by dumping mighty Slovan Liberec out of Euro Vase. The Reds, as they are known, have been paired with Greek giants Olympiakos - the lads from England must be wondering when they'll wake up!

"This is a very hard draw because they are a team who have won their championship in Greece and have performed very well in [Big Cup]," said manager Gerard Houllier as commemorative flags were handed out to local children. "They have already beaten Valencia and Lyon on their own ground, and both those teams are quality opposition," he continued, while excited civic dignitaries scuttled around him, putting up bunting.

You won't witness this sort of innocent excitement in Glasgow, because Rangers, who take on German side Kaiserslautern, have been around the European block before. But who can blame the folk from the small northern English port for making the most of their fifteen minutes of fame? "We will need the same attitude and effort again. I know they are a very skilful side," an emotional Houllier explained, as the whole town came to a standstill.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We are not going to sit in armchairs" - Blackburn boss Graeme Souness wants promotion so badly he's banned the use of bog-standard furniture.

BFR 4 BCFC?

Manager of Bradford City: it's the job nobody wants. First Paul Jewell walked out - in favour of Sheffield Wednesday, for God's sake - and then Chris Hutchings got all Machiavellian to make damn sure he didn't stay around any longer than was absolutely necessary. Even caretaker manager Stuart McCall has decided to distance himself from the permanent vacancy. No wonder, then, that a desperate Bradford board became interested in the litmus test that is Ron Atkinson: after all, if he's not interested, nobody will be.

"I'm not interested," Big Fat Ron flatly told firststake.com today. "I've had no contact with Bradford at all. If there was an approach, I would say I'm not interested." To prove his point, the former Manchester United manager then stuck his fingers in his ears, scrunched his eyes firmly shut and yodelled "I'm not interested" over and over again in a strange high-pitched mantra.

Eventually, Ron realised where he was and decided to reiterate his position in a more sensible manner. "I've retired from club football and nothing could tempt be back," he said in soft tones, before sprinting (well, waddling) as fast as he could in the opposite direction. So that's that, then. Poor old Bradford. Nobody will want the job now.

Actually, Roy Evans is probably still up for it.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Peter Reid has issued a hands-off warning to Leeds, who are reportedly planning a £13m plus Darren Huckerby bid for Kevin Phillips.

Raja Casablanca midfielder Youssef Safri could join fellow Moroccans Youssef Chippo and Mustapha Hadji at Coventry in a £1m deal, according to onefootball.com.

Rangers flop Sebastian Rozental has been invited for a week's trial at Manchester City, with a view to a permanent move. Manager Joe Royle admitted: "Sebastian is a world-class player on his day who has just turned 24. He will be joining us for the week when I can assess his fitness."

NEWS IN BRIEF

Teddy Sheringham has won the Carling player of the month award for October. Arsene's Arsenal Wenger was named manager of the month.

David Seaman has sprained an ankle in training and could be out of action for at least three weeks.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Sports Centre Uefa Cup Special (11.30pm)
Berlin! Baguettes!

Sky Sports 2: Live Nationwide League Football - Preston v Crewe (7pm)
Ball-boys! Boots!

Sky Sports 3: Hold The Back Page (10pm)
Bouffant! Bouffant!

webTitle: TV film viewers want information not censorship

fields.headline: TV film viewers want information not censorship
fields.standfirst: Full report: www.filmfour.com
fields.trailText:
11.30am: A new survey censorship of TV films says viewers want less intervention and more information, reports Jason Deans.
Full report on www.filmfour.com
fields.body:
A new survey on attitudes to censorship of films screened on TV suggests that viewers want less intervention and more information.

The survey, Making Sense of Censorship commissioned by FilmFour, found that while viewers have concerns over violence within feature films on TV, they are able to distinguish between real and cartoon, or escapist, violence.

Respondents said they wanted less intervention from legislators, but more facts and information from broadcasters so they could make their own informed decisions about which films to watch.

The survey also revealed there is more concern about growing access to the internet and control of video stores than the content of films on TV.

The study also found that:
 64% believed the internet was a more significant issue than TV
77% stated that cutting TV movies is the least favoured method of regulating the content, with warnings and information prior to transmission the preferred approach
 82% believed it was their responsibility to decide what was acceptable viewing for their families and households, a figure that rose to 98% in homes with children
 64% believed existing censorship legislation was unclear, while insufficient information was available to allow self-regulation

Making Sense of Censorship was based on more than 900 interviews carried out by TWResearch. The survey will be presented in full at a conference taking place today at the ICA in London.

fields.headline: Liverpool drawn against Olympiakos
fields.trailText: Liverpool have been handed a tricky looking tie against Olympiakos in today's third round Uefa Cup draw in Geneva.
fields.body:
Liverpool have been handed a tricky looking tie against Olympiakos in today's third round Uefa Cup draw in Geneva.

The Greeks will be no pushovers, having narrowly missed out on a place in the second phase of the Champions League, coming third behind Valencia and Lyon.

Manager Gerald Houllier admitted: "This is a very hard draw because they are a team who have won their championship in Greece and have performed very well in the Champions League.

"They have already beaten Valencia and Lyon on their own ground, and both those teams are quality opposition. This shows us that they will be a very hard draw for us. We will need the same attitude and effort again. I know they are a very skilful side."

Liverpool were due to play the first leg at home on November 23, but that has been switched due to domestic matches in Athens on December 7. Liverpool will therefore now play away in a fortnight and at Anfield in the second leg.

Rangers also have a difficult looking draw against German side Kaiserslautern. Rangers came out of the draw first and will play the first leg at Ibrox on Thursday November 23 and then travel to Germany a fortnight later.

Elsewhere, Internazionale have been drawn against Bundesliga leaders Hertha Berlin, while Barcelona face Belgian side Club Bruges.

webTitle: No evidence to support ban on children's ads, says survey

fields.headline: No evidence to support ban on children's ads, says survey
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Advertising has little or no effect on children, according to a book by a US psychologist. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Advertising has little or no effect on children in spite of the multi-million pound campaigns that target them, according to a book by the US psychologist Professor Adrian Furnham.

Professor Furnham, of University College, London, argues that there is no evidence to support calls for stricter controls on the advertising of toys, sweets and other goods aimed at children.

In Children & Advertising: the Allegations and the Evidence, he claims that children can distinguish between ads and television programmes by the time they are three. When they are seven they realise that advertising can mislead.

His conclusions fly in the face of the Independent Television Commission, which last week claimed that children were strongly influenced by advertising.

So-called pester power - the problem of ads that deliberately encourage children to ask their parents for things they don't need and often can't afford - has become a hot topic in recent years, with some European countries issuing a blanket ban on all advertising aimed at children.

webTitle: Two Way TV signs Domino's Pizza deal

fields.headline: Pizza to go for Two Way gamers
fields.trailText: 2pm: Interactive games outfit Two Way TV has signed a deal with Domino's Pizza allowing users to order pizzas via their TVs, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Interactive games service Two Way TV has signed its first transactional deal with Domino's Pizza.

The initial six-month tie-up, which encourages Two Way TV users to order pizza before playing games, is Two Way TV's third commercial deal following sponsorships from Sportal and the Rugby League World Cup.

A button on the front page of the Two Way TV channel, which runs on the interactive areas of all cable channels and ONdigital, links through to Two Way TV/Domino's page where users can order food through their TV.

The terms of the deal, brokered by Quantum New Media Services, means that Two Way TV will receive a small percentage of sales of pizza made through the service.

Further cross-promotional deals are expected to be developed by Two Way TV and Domino's following this first tie-up.

Two Way TV managing director Matthew Tims said: "The deal will really add to the entertainment experience that is Two Way TV."

webTitle: EMI in merger talks with Bertelsmann

fields.headline: EMI in merger talks with Bertelsmann
fields.trailText: 12.30pm update: EMI is discussing a merger with BMG, the record company owned by German media giant Bertelsmann, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK music group EMI today confirmed it is discussing a merger with BMG, the record company owned by German media giant Bertelsmann.

However, EMI said in a brief statement that no offer had been made for the company despite persistent rumours that Bertelsmann was about to mount a takeover bid.

"Following recent speculation, the board of EMI group today said that it has been approached by Bertelsmann regarding a possible combination of Bertelsmann Music Group with EMI," the company said.

EMI added that no detailed discussions had taken place.

Thomas Middelhoff, chief executive of Bertelsmann, has said that he wants BMG to be the world's biggest record company by the end of the year, with an EMI bid the most likely vehicle for his ambitions.

Today's announcement finally torpedoes EMI's £12bn merger with Warner Music, which was temporarily abandoned in the face of hostility from EU regulators. The merger was proposed in January but is now seen as a definite non-runner.

If Bertelsmann and EMI decide to merge, it is likely that competition watchdogs will subject the deal to similar scrutiny.

Regulators are likely to focus on the implications of Bertelsmann's e-commerce and internet interests linking up with EMI's extensive back catalogue.

The EU's doubts over the EMI/Warner deal centred on the combined companies' dominance of the market for music downloads on the internet.

fields.headline: Channel 5 scores with football
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Channel 5 enjoyed bumper peak time ratings last night, thanks to live European football and Steven Seagal movie Fire Down Below, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 enjoyed a bumper peak time ratings haul last night, thanks to live European football and Steven Seagal's eco-warrior antics in terrestrial TV movie premiere Fire Down Below.

Liverpool's less than convincing Uefa Cup victory over Czech side Slovan Liberec averaged 1.9m and an 8% share from 6.45-9.05pm.

Then the macho Mr Seagal followed up with an even better 2.5m - a 12% share - over two hours in Fire Down Below.

This dynamic duo helped Channel 5 to nearly double its Thursday peak time (6-10.30pm) audience share compared with a week ago, to 8%. Across all hours yesterday, the broadcaster also had an 8% share, up from 5.4% last Thursday.

Elsewhere yesterday, 13m - 54% of the available audience - watched Peggy throwing a drink in Pat's face, as EastEnders continued to pull in punters eager to catch up on the tangled aftermath of Frank Butcher's departure from Albert Square last week.

Channel 4's feature-length documentary, Endurance: Shackleton and the Antarctic, averaged 1.7m and a 7% share over two hours from 8pm.

After a slightly shaky start, the relaunched BBC1 Breakfast News looks to be closing the ratings gap with commercial rival GMTV, no doubt helped by the big news stories around in the past couple of weeks.

In the first week following the relaunch, from Monday October 2, the early morning bulletin fronted by Jeremy Bowen and Sophie Raworth averaged 700,000 and a 21.8% share, against GMTV's 1m and 28.4%.

By last week Breakfast News had closed the gap to just 100,000 viewers and two share percentage points, averaging 1m and 26.4%.

Over the first four days of this week, the BBC1 early morning bulletin has averaged just under a million viewers and a 25.8% share, against GMTV's 1.1m and 29.3%.

BBC2's Newsnight has also been boosted this week as the US presidential election has lurched from drama to farce and now towards a full-blown constitutional crisis.

The current affairs flagship has averaged 1.4m and a 9% share, Monday to Thursday, with last night's edition pulling in a handy 1.6m viewers - double the show's year-to-date average of 0.8m.

webTitle: Jerusalem remains quiet after Friday prayers

fields.headline: Jerusalem remains quiet after Friday prayers
fields.trailText: Weekly prayers at the Al Asqa mosque in Jerusalem have ended without violence today, despite earlier clashes between Muslims and police.
fields.body:
Weekly prayers at the Al Asqa mosque in Jerusalem have ended without violence today, despite earlier clashes between Muslims and police.

Thousands of officers were stationed to prevent Arab men under 45 from entering the compound, which is Islam's third holiest site.

Riots have flared almost every week, before or after Friday prayers, since the current fighting erupted at the shrine, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, on 28 September, after a visit by hardliner Ariel Sharon.

Police raised their batons before the prayers and moved towards the worshippers, kicking some and hitting others. Witnesses said that there were no casualties.

Earlier, a small bomb was detonated in retaliation for a helicopter strike that killed a prominent militia leader, Hussein Abayat.

The explosion, just outside the walled Old City, slightly injured a policeman on patrol to prevent violence outside Al Asqa.

A newspaper poll today showed that two-thirds of Israelis favour peace talks, but that, if there is no agreement, 58% would prefer unilateral separation from the Palestinians instead of another interim accord, favored by 30%.

Separation would involve Israel building a line of fortifications along the areas of the West Bank it intends to keep and patrolling them with its military.

According to deputy defense minister Ephraim Sneh, who is drawing up the plan, Israel is not trying to cut itself off from the Palestinians or turn Gaza and the West Bank into large refugee camps full of starving people.

The Gallup poll in the Maariv daily questioned 570 Israeli adults and quoted a 4.5% margin of error.

Peace negotiations continued in Washington yesterday with a meeting between US president Bill Clinton and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

Mr Clinton's national security adviser, Sandy Berger, said: "Violence breeds violence, and we must find a way to break this cycle. It's important for people on both sides to do all they can to try to achieve that."

There was little criticism in Israel of the killing of Mr Abayat. Justice minister Yossi Beilin said that the strike was necessary to stop Palestinians from shooting at Israeli enclaves.

A leaflet circulated last night in the Bethlehem area of the West Bank, the site of the helicopter assault, pledged revenge for the death of Mr Abayat and singled out Israel's army chief for retaliation.

webTitle: US election: Voting over, but campaign continues

fields.headline: Voting over, but campaign continues
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US election race
fields.trailText: The voting is done, but the campaign continues, with neither Al Gore nor George W Bush assured of the US presidency three days after the election - and the delay could last at least another week.
fields.body:
The voting is done, but the campaign continues, with neither Al Gore nor George W Bush assured of the US presidency three days after the election - and the delay could last at least another week.

Mr Bush led by just 327 votes out of nearly 6m in the Associated Press survey of a recount of the crucial, deciding, Florida votes completed early today.

With the tissue-thin margin, several thousand ballots in the mail from overseas could elect America's 43rd president. However, they will not all be counted before November 17 - ten days after the election.

Unless the election is challenged in other states, Florida's disputed vote will decide the presidency under the constitutional system that allots electoral votes to each state to equal its number of congress members.

Instead of focusing on a future in or out of the White House, Mr Bush and Mr Gore are raising funds for legal battles, waging a public relations struggle and deploying waves of lawyers and political aides to Florida.

"The presidential election, of course, is on hold," the former secretary of state, James A Baker III, said yesterday in Florida, where he laboured on behalf of Mr Bush's campaign. Another former secretary of state, Warren Christopher, represented Mr Gore's interests.

Not counting Florida, where Mr Bush's brother Jeb is governor, Mr Bush had won 29 states for 246 electoral votes. Mr Gore had won 18 states plus the district of Columbia for 255, with 270 needed for victory.

Political charges aside, the uncertainty overshadowed any talk of the transition to a new administration.

The incomplete popular vote totals showed Mr Gore ahead, with 49,145,883 votes, or 48%. Mr Bush had 48,940,963, also 48%. But Mr Gore was not assured of even the uncritical popular vote lead because hundreds of thousands of overseas ballots remained to be counted nationwide.

"This is serious stuff. It's time to cool partisan passions or risk being damaged goods, even if you win the presidency," said Democratic consultant Jim Duffy.

Passions seemed to escalate yesterday as the two sides swapped charges and several lawsuits were filed in Florida.

The two sides clashed over the design of a ballot in Palm Beach County that left some Gore voters expressing concern they had inadvertently cast votes for Reform party candidate Pat Buchanan.

In addition, the Gore campaign cited more than 19,000 Palm Beach County ballots that had been thrown out because they were marked for more than one presidential candidate.

The Gore campaign criticised the ballots used in the county as confusing, and asked for a hand count of votes cast there and in Dade, Broward and Volusia counties - some 1.78m votes.

Democrats also suggested they may call for a new election in Palm Beach County. Republicans expressed outrage at the Democratic demands, but suggested they might seek recounts in Iowa and Wisconsin, two states where Mr Gore won narrowly.

Oregon, still counting, was so close that the secretary of state said the likelihood of an automatic recount was "pretty high"

"The Democrats, who are politicising and distorting these events, risk doing so at the...expense of our democracy," said Don Evans, the chairman of Mr Bush's campaign. "Our democratic process calls for a vote on election day; it does not call for us to continue voting until someone likes the outcome."

Eight lawsuits have been filed in state and federal courts to challenge the Florida results, including six in Palm Beach County and two in Tallahassee.

Democratic party-backed lawsuits won't be filed until next week, party officials said.

As for the two would-be presidents, Mr Gore was in public only briefly yesterday, emerging from a Nashville, Tennessee, hotel to jog with two of his daughters and his brother-in-law.

"We're having a great run here," the vice president shouted to reporters, then waved off all questions.

Mr Bush was in Austin, Texas, where aides said he was toiling over transition plans. His running mate, Dick Cheney, who is expected to head any transition team, and Andrew Card, likely chief of staff in a Bush administration, spent the morning with the governor.
