webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week thirteen

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week thirteen
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. How long can it last?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £170.34, Sean Ingle = £113.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £57.77, Paul MacInnes = £56.46
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £170.34, Sean Ingle = £113.98, Football Unlimited punters collective = £57.77, Paul MacInnes = £56.46

Scott Murray: Preston v Crewe: no goalscorer £5 @ 10/1

Unless David Moyes puts on a pair of "amusing" plastic breasts and waddles up the touchline with his trousers round his ankles, we'll not see much in the way of fun at Deepdale tonight.

Preston get results at home - they've won five out of eight this season - but a goal tally of 11:4 shows they play a cautious game. And while visitors Crewe have a woeful away record - they've lost six of eight matches on their travels already - they've only let in 11 goals while doing so. That's by no means defensively sound, but it hardly makes them Liverpool.

Crewe aren't exactly banging them in at the other end either, so tens on no goalscorer seems a bit excessive. By the way, should the ball ping off Erik Meijer's arse and skid into his own net to hand Crewe a 1-0 win, I'll take back everything I said about the lack of entertainment.

Sean Ingle: £5 double: Bradford v Everton 0 or 1 Goals @ 2/1 and Valladolid to draw with Alaves @ 2/1

After last week's odds-on treble was slated by Blue Square's S.A.D.-suffering (or is that sad) Patrick Murray, I've decided to cheer him up by increasing my value quotient (if such a poncey phrase actually exists) and dabbling on a 9-1 double. What's the betting it loses?

That said, these bets both look reasonable value. Bradford versus Everton has dire game written all over it: Bradford have scored just five times at home all season, while Everton are hardly the Julio Iglesias of the Premiership either. Don't be surprised if it ends up 0-0 or 0-1 to Everton.

Speaking of Mr Iglesias, my second this weekend involves the Primera Liga. Valladoid are the draw experts of Spanish football (six in nine games) and while Alaves are slight favourites, I wouldn't be at all surprised to see this game end up 1-1 - which is Valladoid's score of choice this season. But with Mr Murray's advice from an earlier column about staying away from predicting the correct score, I'm settling on the draw. For this week anyway.

Laith Amiry, who writes for Weekend Football, a betting prediction site: £10 treble -Ipswich to beat Charlton @ evens, Sunderland to beat Southampton @ 4/7, and Chelsea to beat Leeds @ 4/5

Charlton are very strong at home but weak away, whereas Ipswich have been very tight at home and gained more points away. Top of the table United and Arsenal only managed draws at Portman Road, and Charlton play an open game away from home - remember their 5-3 defeat at Highbury in August?

I'm expecting a few goals, despite Ipswich's 7:6 goal ratio in six home games. Ipswich have won this fixture in both of the two equivalent meetings in the last three seasons by two clear goals. As Charlton have only won one of six away games and conceded 15 goals, a record only surpassed by Derby, I predict a home win, 3-1.

Sunderland have the best home defensive record in the Premiership, only conceding two goals in their six home games. They are unbeaten at home with four victories and two draws. Sunderland beat Arsenal on the opening day of the season by 1-0, but have only scored ten goals in their 12 games this season. Sunderland have only lost one of their last six games, but have drawn three. Southampton have lost three of their last six games, scoring six goals and conceding 13. Southampton have only won away at Bradford this season, and that by only one goal.

Southampton surprised us last Saturday with their 3-2 victory over Chelsea at the Dell, but Chelsea have not won away from home this season! Come on Chelsea, get it sorted. Last season, Sunderland won this fixture 2-0. I predict a home win, 2-1.

Chelsea have strong home form with four victories, one draw and one defeat, scoring 18 goals in the process, the second best home goalscoring record in the Premiership, but they are yet to win away from home.

Chelsea have now scored 17 goals in their last six games, more than any other side. Last month, Chelsea put three goals past Tottenham and Liverpool without reply and six past Coventry. Leeds are eighth in the league, but have been let down by their away form, only winning one away from home. Leeds have drawn to Bradford, Derby and Coventry in recent weeks and are unlikely to beat Chelsea who are very strong at home. Last season, Leeds won this fixture 2-0, but with Leeds weak away from home and Chelsea so dominant at Stamford Bridge, I predict a home win, 2-0.

A £10 bet has a potential return of £57.27. That's a profit of £47.27. Would you put a tenner on it? I will.

Paul MacInnes is on holiday.

webTitle: Mail offered Star in mooted Express carve-up

fields.headline: Mail offered Star in mooted Express carve-up
fields.trailText: 1pm update: The £120m bidding war for the Express newspapers took a dramatic twist with a sensational proposal to hand control of the Daily Star to the Daily Mail. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The £120m bidding war for the Express newspapers took a dramatic twist today with a sensational proposal to hand control of the Daily Star to the Daily Mail.

The billionaire Hinduja brothers are seeking a carve-up of the Express titles, allowing rival bidder the Daily Mail & General Trust to take charge of the nation's most downmarket paper.

A source close to the Hindujas said that should their £120m bid to United News & Media be successful, they would be willing to keep the Daily Express and offer the Daily Star to the Daily Mail & General Trust.

"The obvious financial deal is for the two to get together. The Daily Mail can have the Star so it can challenge the Sun, and the Hindujas can have the Express," said the source.

The source added that the Hindujas were seriously considering the idea, but have yet to approach the Daily Mail.

The Daily Star, although derided by the chattering classes, has maintained a reasonable following despite years of editorial cutbacks.

Against all odds, it continues to be produced and has a circulation of around 543,000.

Hollinger International, owner of the Daily Telegraph and rumoured bidder for the titles, would then be offered complete ownership of the highly profitable West Ferry printing plant, which it co-owns with the Express.

The Hindujas feel they have the upper hand in the bidding battle, as their offer would not be referred to the Department of Trade & Industry's competition commission.

The Daily Mail's offer would be referred to watchdogs if successful because the combined circulation of its titles and those at Express newspapers is above 500,000.

webTitle: Traffic rolls out interactive TV division

fields.headline: Traffic rolls out interactive TV division
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: New media agency Traffic interactive has set up a division devoted to interactive television, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
New media agency Traffic interactive has set up a new division devoted to interactive television.

Stewart Atkins, a former producer at BBC Interactive who joined Traffic as operations director in September last year, is heading up the new department, taking on the new role of development director.

As well as interactive TV, Mr Atkins will focus on other emerging technologies such as mobile and intelligent systems.

Katie Purcer, former interactive television producer at Agency.com, joins as head of interactive television.

Martin Child, managing director of Traffic, said it made sense to develop a dedicated department as the agency had been consulting on interactive TV and mobile projects for a while and clients were now working in this area.

Traffic was founded in 1996 by PR gurus Matthew Freud and Alex Johnston, Abbott Mead Vickers and US firm House of Blues New Media.

Freud Communications still owns a third of Traffic, but the remaining two-thirds was bought by Clarke Hooper Consulting at the end of 1997.

webTitle: Mail dismisses offer to buy Star

fields.headline: Mail scoffs at Star offer
fields.trailText: 4.30pm update: The Mail has dismissed suggestions that the newspaper would take over the Daily Star in a carve up of the Express titles.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail has dismissed suggestions that the newspaper would take over the Daily Star in a carve up of the Express titles.

Sources close to the billionaire Hinduja brothers who have made a £120m bid for ailing newspaper group, say that they would be willing to offload the down-market title to clinch the deal.

They believe the Mail would be more interested in chasing The Sun's share of the tabloid market.

"The idea that the Daily Mail is only interested in the Daily Star is well wide of the mark. The company is interested in all of the titles," said one source close to the paper.

The Daily Mail and General Trust's bid has been hampered by concerns over regulatory scrutiny, which is likely to focus on concerns over the political independence of the Daily Express.

It is possible that the board of United News and Media, the owner of the titles, will opt for a quick sale to give shareholders a cash windfall, and choose the bid which will encounter the least delay.

The Daily Mail has already been asked for a non-refundable £60m deposit to view private financial documents concerning the Express group.

webTitle: Love led woman to be Nazi propaganda tool

fields.headline: Love led woman to be Nazi propaganda tool
fields.standfirst:
Wartime MI5 trawled night clubs fronting for brothels, listened to 'cultured voice' of traitor on radio, and tracked Pearl Harbour agent
Recently released MI5 files
fields.trailText: Wartime MI5 trawled night clubs fronting for brothels, listened to 'cultured voice' of traitor on radio, and tracked Pearl Harbour agent.
fields.body:
A schoolteacher was imprisoned after the war for broadcasting on behalf of the enemy after falling in love with a German officer during the Nazi occupation of the Channel Islands.

MI5 files disclosed today at the public record office show how Pearl Joyce Vardon broadcast anti-British propaganda together with Margaret Joyce, wife of William Joyce, the traitor known as Lord Haw Haw who was executed after the war. The declassified papers show prosecutors adopted a much more lenient attitude towards Vardon and Mrs Joyce, and also raise questions about the legality of Joyce's execution.

Vardon, a Jersey resident who spoke German, met Captain Siegfried Schwatlo when forced to work for a German labour organisation in Jersey. Rather than be parted when he was posted to Germany in 1941, she joined him and took a job as an announcer with Radio Luxembourg.

She introduced programmes such as Ladies First, which, according to MI5, criticised the US and the "bad food" Americans were forced to eat, and praised Germany's social security system. Another, Matters of Moment, gave news "from a German point of view", while For the Forces and their Kin described how "bodies of British merchant seamen or RAF men had been washed up on the beaches" after meeting their fate "bombing women and children".

MI5 said she was described by colleagues as a "keen Nazi". There is "every indication that she did it willingly and ... she intended to throw her lot with Germany", it said in a 1945 report. "She is a British subject and probably a traitor," it added. Brought home, she pleaded guilty to breaching defence regulations and was given a nine month sentence.

Mrs Joyce joined her husband in Germany and broadcast in what MI5 described as a "cultured voice". It did not stop acquaintances in Carlisle - where she was a sympathiser of Mosley's British Union of Fascists - from identifying her to MI5.

The couple had become naturalised Germans. William Hartley Shawcross, the postwar attorney general, was advised by government lawyers it was "not treasonable for her to acquire German nationality, as it is not treasonable for a British woman to marry an enemy alien". MI5 took a harder line, claiming she had not lost her British nationality by her marriage. "The obtaining of enemy nationality is an act of treason in itself," it insisted.

However, the papers show both the lawyers and MI5 described her husband not as British but either as an "alien of German nationality" or an "American subject". He was executed on the grounds that, though born in the US, he obtained a British passport before he went to Germany.

The authorities did not know what to do with his wife when brought to Britain after the war. She was sent back to Germany, but British officials there did not want to have anything to with such an embarrassing case. She was allowed back to see her husband before he was executed in January 1946. Officials described her as in a "pitiful state": despite MI5's arguments, she was freed from prosecution "on compassionate grounds". She died in London in 1972 having regained British nationality.

webTitle: Cordiant buys out brand consultancy Bamber Forsyth

fields.headline: Cordiant buys out brand consultancy
fields.trailText: 12pm: Bamber Forsyth has sold out to Cordiant Communications in a deal worth up to £30m, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The brand consultancy whose clients include Kiss FM and Glaxo Wellcome, has sold out to Cordiant Communications in a deal worth up to £30m.

Bamber Forsyth will join Cordiant's existing brand communications business, which includes Fitch and PSD.

The all-share deal could be worth up to £30m to Bamber Forsyth shareholders, depending on the performance of the company over the next four years.

Cordiant chief executive Michael Bungey said: "We are delighted that Bamber Forsyth has agreed to join Cordiant's branding and design division.

"Bamber Forsyth is an excellent fit with our existing operations in this high-growth sector and represents the ideal catalyst to exploit the cross-sell potential with our corporate clients in Cordiant's business communications division."

Bamber Forsyth was set up in 1978 by partners Keith Bamber and Nigel Forsyth to design company reports.

The company employs 65 people and has created new corporate identities for major blue-chip companies including Diageo, British Telecom and Reckitt & Colman.

webTitle: In brief: Billy Elliot heads European Film Awards nominations

fields.headline: Billy Elliot heads European Film Awards nominations
fields.standfirst: Plus: Julia Roberts confirms mysterious project, Julia Ormond in disaster epic and Mario Van Peebles marks X in Muhammad Ali biopic
fields.trailText: Plus: Paul Thomas Anderson and Adam Sandler collaborate in love story, Julia Roberts confirms mysterious project, Julia Ormond in disaster epic and Mario Van Peebles marks X in Muhammad Ali biopic
fields.body:
 Billy Elliot has received three nominations for this year's European Film of the Year Awards: Best Film, Best Actor (Jamie Bell) and Best Actress (Julie Walters). Other films nominated in the Best Film category include the Cannes winner Dancer in the Dark, the French comedy Harry, He's Here to Help, the British animated feature Chicken Run, and the Liv Ullmann-directed drama Faithless. The awards will be presented at a ceremony at the Theatre National de Chaillot in Paris on December 2.

 Julia Roberts has confirmed she will appear in the mysterious Project 3, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Little is know about the project, which has been described as a psychological thriller in the vein of George Cukor's 1944 classic Gaslight. Roberts will begin shooting once she has completed Steven Soderbergh's Rat Pack remake Ocean's 11, and Joe Roth's comedy America's Sweethearts. The project will see her reunited with The Mexican film-makers Gore Verbinski and J.H. Wyman, with whom she has recently finished The Mexican, starring alongside Brad Pitt.

 Julia Ormond is to play the female lead in a Danish disaster epic. Martin Sheen will also star in Baltic Storm, which is based on the real-life tragedy in the 1990s when Scandinavian passenger ferry Estonia sank en route to Finland with the loss of over 1,000 lives. webTitle: Lycos Europe races ahead in battle to be leading European ISP

fields.headline: Lycos Europe races ahead in battle to be leading European ISP
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Lycos Europe has slashed its losses and posted a 226% rise in revenue. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
Lycos Europe has bucked the trend in the European internet service provider market by slashing its losses.

The company reduced its first quarter deficit by 40% to £18m thanks to a canny cut in its marketing budget, and reported a 226% rise in revenues to £9.5m.

Lycos took £13.9m off its advertising spend during the summer season, due to fears that many loyal customers would be on holiday. The gamble appears to have paid off.

German media giant Bertelsmann is a key shareholder in the company alongside Terra Lycos, which was formed by the merger of Terra Networks and Lycos.

Rumours persist that Bertelsmann wants to sell its stake to its partner, although it has a burgeoning e-commerce operation.

Competition is strong in the European ISP sector, with T-Online of Germany, Wanadoo of France and Tiscali of Italy allbattling it out to take the role of market leader.

However, the long-awaited consolidation spree has yet to happen, as the main competitors have been saddled by heavy losses, boardroom upheavals or a downturn in advertising.

Bob Kommers, internet analyst at ABN Amro, said: "The next quarter is crucial, because Christmas is traditionally a good time for internet companies. Everyone will be taking a close look at advertising growth, and subscriber figures."

webTitle: Girls and sport: Getting our kits out for the boys

fields.headline: Girls and sport: Getting our kits out for the boys
fields.standfirst: Why do girls seem to dislike sports at school? Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor explains
fields.trailText: Why do girls seem to dislike sports at school? Education Unlimited editor Ros Taylor explains.
fields.body:
Watch a 12-year-old boy playing football on the school pitch. He's part of a glorification of male sport that stretches all the way from the first Olympic athletes to David Beckham.

But what is his 13-year-old sister doing? Running around in a microskirt and gym knickers brandishing a hockey stick, watched by a bevy of voyeurs more interested in her upper thighs than her passing technique.

The battle of Waterloo was won on the playing fields of Eton, according to the Duke of Wellington. In fact, anyone watching a rugby scrum would probably agree that violent contact sports are a decent preparation for hand-to-hand battle - although a few polo and shooting lessons probably help, too.

But women who attended mixed schools may not remember the camaraderie and the joy of winning the Victrix Ludorum trophy. Instead, many will recall the ordeal of the 'catwalk' - the long hike from changing rooms to swimming pool as male classmates gave us their thoughts on our chest development and bikini line.

Forward rolls and vaulting the horse in the gym came a close second, followed by the indignity of being The Last To Be Picked by the athletic team captains.

And how did everyone know your bra size? Because the class bully stole your bra from the changing rooms, left it by the door to the boys' showers and forced you to go and ask for it back.

I'm not underestimating the blows to male dignity inflicted in communal showers. Nor do I believe that rugby really does develop character and endurance.

But, lads, you can't deny that girls' sport brings out the builder instinct in teenage boys, and I'd like to offer a vote of thanks to the Youth Sports Trust for their Girls in Sport programme, and their efforts to change the PE culture.

Schools will be asked to let girls wear plain tracksuits rather than semi-transparent Aertex shirts and pleated miniskirts. Football, basketball, and girls-only aerobics will be available.

Girls-only clubs and sport conventions are to be organised. And - hooray! - staff will join in activities.

Even better, "quality images of young people of all shapes and sizes being active" will cover the walls of changing rooms and sports centres.

According to sports minister Kate Hoey, the initiatives "will undoubtedly be instrumental in broadening the nation's talent pool."

Well, some of us would never have made it to the school team, let alone the Olympics, but, given the chance, we would have been happy to lose our inhibitions on the playing fields a bit more often.

Boys - doesn't that sound sexier than the sight of a cold, scowling teenager shivering in defence?

webTitle: Tory laughs at cannabis fines policy

fields.headline: Tory laughs at cannabis fines policy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: drugs in Britain
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe faced fresh embarrassment over her drugs policy yesterday when a frontbench colleague dismissed as absurd her plan to fine cannabis users.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe faced fresh embarrassment over her drugs policy yesterday when a frontbench colleague dismissed as absurd her plan to fine cannabis users.

John Bercow, a member of Ms Widdecombe's home affairs team, reopened Tory wounds over drugs when he called for tolerance towards "dope smokers". In a New Statesman interview, he underlined Ms Widdecombe's precarious position when he laughed off her plan to impose a £100 spot fine.

"The idea that the police should raid every home looking for dope smokers is transparently absurd," he said. "Personal use has effectively been decriminalised."

Britain's tradition of policing by consent could be in jeopardy if Ms Widdecombe's policy were implemented. "The police are not interested in launching all-out war on soft drugs. As far as I can see, alcohol and violence are closely related. It is not clear to me that cannabis and violence are."

Mr Bercow's remarks will further undermine the shadow home secretary, whose drugs policy unravelled within hours of its launch at the Tory conference last month. In effect, it was shelved by William Hague after shadow cabinet members admitted publicly that they had smoked cannabis in the past.

fields.headline: Another Champions challenge for Leeds
fields.trailText: Leeds will once again have to overcome Italian and Spanish opposition, after being drawn in another tough Champions League group.
fields.body:
Leeds will once again have to overcome Italian and Spanish opposition, after being drawn in another tough Champions League group.

David O'Leary's side are in Group D with Champions League holders Real Madrid, Italian champions Lazio and Belgian side Anderlecht.

The task facing Arsenal and Manchester United appears much easier. Arsenal were put in Group C with Bayern Munich of Germany, Spartak Moscow from Russia, and French side Lyon, leaving Gunners supremo David Dein delighted.

"Our goal is to win the Champions League. It won't be easy but we are fired up," he admitted. "There's no such thing as an easy game but we are happy with the draw."

Manchester United were also pleased with their draw, ending up in Group A with Spanish side Valencia, Sturm Graz of Austria and Panathinaikos of Greece. "It's a very good draw for Manchester United," admitted chief executive Peter Kenyon, "but we are not going to be complacent against anybody who has reached the last sixteen."

But although Leeds have a job on their hands, at least they're not in the toughest group. Group B is made up of AC Milan from Italy, Deportivo la Coruna from Spain, French side Paris St Germain and Turkish champions Galatasaray.

fields.headline: Give Bangladesh a break
fields.trailText: At 3.30 GMT this morning Bangladesh made their Test debut at the Bangabandhu National Stadium in Dhaka. The opponents were India, the forecast was excellent for each of the five days - or however many are needed - and an entire nation was beside itself with excitement. After years of knocking on heaven's door, Bangladesh were finally rubbing shoulders with the demi-gods of cricket. Blow your trumpets, beat your drums and sing it from the rooftops. And then pause for a moment. Because if you listen carefully, there are some dissenting whispers.
fields.body:
At 3.30 GMT this morning Bangladesh made their Test debut at the Bangabandhu National Stadium in Dhaka. The opponents were India, the forecast was excellent for each of the five days - or however many are needed - and an entire nation was beside itself with excitement. After years of knocking on heaven's door, Bangladesh were finally rubbing shoulders with the demi-gods of cricket. Blow your trumpets, beat your drums and sing it from the rooftops. And then pause for a moment. Because if you listen carefully, there are some dissenting whispers.

The most common complaint is that Bangladesh simply aren't up to it. The truth is, they would probably struggle in Division Two of the County Championship (on a recent tour of South Africa they were skittled for 54 and 51 in consecutive matches). They may have beaten Pakistan in last year's World Cup - a result that was largely responsible for their elevation to Test status - but that game has been tainted by match-fixing rumours so often it has lost all credibility. Their coach at the time, Gordon Greenidge, warned that Bangladesh weren't ready for Test cricket anyway. He was promptly sacked.

This was harsh, but Greenidge, like many others, missed the point. No, Bangladesh may not be good enough at the moment (although they batted respectably this morning to close on 239 for 6). But neither were most sides when they stepped onto the biggest stage. Of the other nine Test teams, only two avoided defeat in their inaugural game: Australia, who beat England at Melbourne in 1876-77 in the very first Test of all; and Zimbabwe, who drew with India at Harare in 1992-93. West Indies lost their first three Tests by an innings, while New Zealand had to wait 26 years and 44 matches until their first Test win. Pakistan and India struggled to get any results away from home until the 1970s, and Zimbabwe, eight years after their debut, have won just three games. This stands to reason: the gap between the Test teams and the best of the rest is huge. Apprenticeships are going to be long and hard, and few countries have the means to emerge at the other end. But Bangladesh are one of them.

In a country that only hits the headlines only when it gets flooded, cricket is more than a mere pastime. It's a potential lifejacket. It tells the world that Bangladesh has more to it than natural disasters, and it provides the people with a welcome distraction from their worries about the next monsoon. This in itself doesn't justify Test status, of course, but it does mean that a tiny country packed to the rafters with 125 million people - most of them cricket nuts - has an extra incentive to succeed. In fact, of the nine other Test nations, only India and Pakistan have larger populations. If Bangladesh can improve their infrastructure, their potential is enormous.

Others are worried that the Asian countries - who now account for four of the ten teams - are becoming too powerful. This argument is usually put forward by apologists for the old Anglo-Australian axis. It's hideously out of touch. Like a language, a sport develops naturally. And you can't get more natural than a group of schoolkids armed with bat and ball in a dusty street on the subcontinent. If Asia is becoming powerful, it's because it has become the home of game (remember how Asian crowds lit up the World Cup in England?). The progress of Bangladesh is just the next logical step in the progress of Test cricket.

ICC wants to spread the gospel. If this means sacrificing some of its short-term quality for the good of the game in the long run, then fine. Bangladesh needs a boost: its first Test could give it just that.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read his previous column, on England's problems against spin, click here

webTitle: Exotic dancers enlisted to trap soldiers

fields.headline: Exotic dancers enlisted to trap soldiers
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Two Cuban exotic dancers were recruited by German agents to entrap British soldiers in the bars and nightclubs of wartime Havana, hitherto secret papers reveal.
fields.body:
Two Cuban exotic dancers were recruited by German agents to entrap British soldiers in the bars and nightclubs of wartime Havana, hitherto secret papers reveal.

Jose Francisco Xavier Pacheco y Cuesta and his wife Diaz were recruited in 1942 in Belgium where they were performing. Mr Pacheco had been arrested in reprisal for the detention of German nationals in Cuba.

An MI5 report described Mr Pacheco as a "Cuban Romeo" who had danced his way to a "second-line stardom". It added: "At his zenith he was billed at the Winter Garden in Berlin and the Piccadilly hotel in London. Success was due as much to his wife as his personal endeavours."

He was, said MI5, "fundamentally a bad man". MI5 continued: "In so far as his wife is concerned, he would have had the world believe in a saga of devotion and affection. Actually, he has given her syphilis."

Mr Pacheco was said to be not above accepting shares in illegal profits or bribes in the form of "bottles of drink which were consumed at his wife's insistence at nightclubs which might well have been brothels".

The couple were instructed to "contact British and Allied officers and men...and obtain information of "naval, military, and air force importance". Transmission, MI5 noted, was to be by secret ink.

MI5 was tipped off before the pair had a chance to test their alternative careers. They were arrested in Trinidad on the way to Cuba and deported to Britain. Diaz was taken to Holloway women's prison in north London. "There is certainly no dancing left in her," MI5 reported somewhat sympathetically.

Mr Pacheco was held in Camp 020, MI5's interrogation centre at Latchmere House in Richmond, Surrey. The couple were deported to Cuba after the war.

webTitle: Disney and NewsCorp hit by falling ad revenues

fields.headline: Disney and NewsCorp hit by falling ad revenues
fields.trailText: 9am: The fall-out from tumbling advertising revenues is sweeping across the media sector, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The fall-out from tumbling advertising revenues is sweeping across the media sector, with Walt Disney the latest high-profile victim.

The US media giant, which owns the powerful ABC TV network, said first quarter profits will show little improvement compared to last year, due to a weak advertising market.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation this week said it expected advertising revenue to fall in November and December, sending its shares down by 11%. The media conglomerate said operating income had fallen by $69m (£48m) to $80m.

Walt Disney said the situation will improve, but the announcement mirrors similar figures from internet company and stock market darling Yahoo!

Shares in Granada Media took a hammering last month following a warning about slow advertising growth.

The problem was underlined by US online advertising companies 24/7 Media and Engage, which said they were suffering from a short-term slow-down in revenues.

The bad news from Disney and the web advertisers was enough to hit AOL and Time Warner's shares, which fell 5% in New York.

Walt Disney's bad luck has even spread to ABC's "Who wants to be a Millionaire" series, which has suffered from disappointing ratings.

fields.headline: 'I looked down - all I could see was white and red'
fields.standfirst:
See the pictures by Eamonn McCabe

The nurse: Penny Feiwel
fields.trailText: The nurse: Penny Feiwel
fields.body:
It is easy to imagine Penny Feiwel 60 years ago working on the front lines. Despite being in her 10th decade, she dashes about her flat easily, quick-witted and relaxed. "That photographer of yours," she says laughing, "he had me grinning like an old fool, so I'll probably look 109 instead of just 91!"

Feiwel (nee Phelps) was raised in a working-class family in Tottenham. She worked in factories from the age of 13 and in 1927 began training as a nurse. She went to Spain in 1936 at the suggestion of a "very left-wing friend" after losing her job at the hospital for nursing the Hunger Marchers. "I said, 'What on earth do I want to go to Spain for?' and she said, 'Don't you know there's a war going on!' So off I went to Oxford Street, where I had an interview with Lord Somebody and Lady Somebody, and 24 hours later, I was in Spain."

Feiwel was immediately posted to republican mobile medical units. She couldn't speak Spanish and was a lone young woman, working in non-English-speaking, makeshift hospitals, just 3km behind the front lines. Wasn't she scared? She dismisses the question with an impatient, "Of course not!" However, as a foreign woman, she was subject to greater suspicion of being a spy and she admits that some of her patients and fellow workers had doubts that "such a slip of a girl" could be of much assistance: "But I quickly brought them round... Some of those soldiers were quite rough as well, I can tell you."

In 1937 she was sent to Quintanar as temporary medical officer to the Italian Garibaldi battalion - an extraordinary posting for a young woman. There, she successfully controlled a fever epidemic and was awarded the rank of honorary medical officer. She became Lieutenant Penny Phelps of the Spanish Republican Army, medical officer to the Garibaldi battalion. Her last posting was in 1938, to an all-Spanish medical unit towards Valencia, up in the mountains. All day she could hear the nearby bombing from fascist planes.

It was here that Feiwel endured her second bombing attack - and her worst injuries. "People had always said that when you get injured in the war, it's so quick, you cannot remember. And you know," she says, eyes widening behind her thick glasses, almost in amusement, "I cannot remember for the life of me what I was doing at the time. All I remember is waking up in a barn full of people, all of them crying out, 'Agua, agua!' And I looked down at my body and all I could see was white and red. I said to the orderly: 'Where am I?' He looked at me and said: 'You were one of the lucky ones.' "

Shrapnel from the nationalist bomb had ripped across her arms and chest, and embedded itself in her abdomen. Her wrists still bear the scars. "I didn't realise it until I got married, but because of my injuries I was unable to have children. Bits of shrapnel were still in my abdomen. I'm quite sure my husband would have wanted children."

At this point her voice quietens and her fingers entwine anxiously. She was flown back to England to recuperate and while convalescing she met physician Michael Feiwel. They played tennis together, took long walks and three months later they were married. They celebrated their diamond anniversary in 1998 and he died the following year.

What was it like returning to England? "Well, it was the oddest thing," she says, surprise still in her voice. "I wanted to talk about Spain, but they were only interested in King George's coronation."

"That photographer of yours," she says laughing, "he had me grinning like an old fool, so I'll probably look 109 instead of just 91!" Feiwel (nee Phelps) was raised in a working-class family in Tottenham. She worked in factories from the age of 13 and in 1927 began training as a nurse. She went to Spain in 1936 at the suggestion of a "very left-wing friend" after losing her job at the hospital for nursing the Hunger Marchers. "I said, 'What on earth do I want to go to Spain for?' and she said, 'Don't you know there's a war going on!' So off I went to Oxford Street, where I had an interview with Lord Somebody and Lady Somebody, and 24 hours later, I was in Spain." Feiwel was immediately posted to republican mobile medical units. She couldn't speak Spanish and was a lone young woman, working in non-English-speaking, makeshift hospitals, just 3km behind the front lines. Wasn't she scared? She dismisses the question with an impatient, "Of course not!" However, as a foreign woman, she was subject to greater suspicion of being a spy and she admits that some of her patients and fellow workers had doubts that "such a slip of a girl" could be of much assistance: "But I quickly brought them round... Some of those soldiers were quite rough as well, I can tell you." In 1937 she was sent to Quintanar as temporary medical officer to the Italian Garibaldi battalion - an extraordinary posting for a young woman. There, she successfully controlled a fever epidemic and was awarded the rank of honorary medical officer. She became Lieutenant Penny Phelps of the Spanish Republican Army, medical officer to the Garibaldi battalion. Her last posting was in 1938, to an all-Spanish medical unit towards Valencia, up in the mountains. All day she could hear the nearby bombing from fascist planes. It was here that Feiwel endured her second bombing attack - and her worst injuries. "People had always said that when you get injured in the war, it's so quick, you cannot remember. And you know," she says, eyes widening behind her thick glasses, almost in amusement, "I cannot remember for the life of me what I was doing at the time. All I remember is waking up in a barn full of people, all of them crying out, 'Agua, agua!' And I looked down at my body and all I could see was white and red. I said to the orderly: 'Where am I?' He looked at me and said: 'You were one of the lucky ones.' " Shrapnel from the nationalist bomb had ripped across her arms and chest, and embedded itself in her abdomen. Her wrists still bear the scars. "I didn't realise it until I got married, but because of my injuries I was unable to have children. Bits of shrapnel were still in my abdomen. I'm quite sure my husband would have wanted children." At this point her voice quietens and her fingers entwine anxiously. She was flown back to England to recuperate and while convalescing she met physician Michael Feiwel. They played tennis together, took long walks and three months later they were married. They celebrated their diamond anniversary in 1998 and he died the following year. What was it like returning to England? "Well, it was the oddest thing," she says, surprise still in her voice. "I wanted to talk about Spain, but they were only interested in King George's coronation."

fields.headline: 'I said I was going to visit an uncle in Paris'
fields.standfirst:
See the pictures by Eamonn McCabe

The secret soldier: Sol Frankel
fields.trailText: The secret soldier: Sol Frankel
fields.body:
Sol Frankel may be 86 but he shows no sign of easing into the slow lane. "I'd almost given up on you," he huffs when we arrive five minutes late at his home in Golders Green, north London. In the dull drizzle he is waiting by the front door, straight-backed and immaculately turned out in jacket and tie, his timeworn International Brigades badge proud on his lapel. Inside, his tiny flat is alive with mementos and memories. Books about Spain are stacked next to Frankel's vivid pastel sketches of the Houses of Parliament. On the wall, a few inches from his late wife Pearl's prized degree certificate from the Open University, is a photograph of Frankel's battalion. The picture has faded, but to him the image is as clear as ever. He seems surprised that I cannot pick him out among the grainy blur of grins and rifles and gel-smoothed hairstyles.

Frankel's involvement in the war began not in Spain but in Hampshire, home to 3,000 Basque children evacuated from areas towards which the fascists were advancing. He still has his pass, dated July 1937, for the North Stoneham Camp for Spanish refugee children. "I went down to help - put up tents, dig latrines.

"One night, it was announced on the Tannoy that the fascists had entered Bilbao. The news caused a riot among the children; they broke camp. They were only kids - the oldest were about 14 - but they ran away. We were up all night looking for them, trying to round them up. They called me fascista , I remember. They wanted to go back to Spain."

By the autumn of 1937, Frankel had decided that he, too, should go to Spain. "I didn't tell my family because being Jewish in the east end, they were dead against politics; they thought it was best to keep to themselves. But I was a member of the Labour party League of Youth, I'd been at Cable Street digging up paving stones to make barricades."

At Dover, passengers suspected of going to Spain were stopped. "I said I was going to visit an uncle in Paris," Frankel recalls. "It was lucky they didn't search me - I had an English-Spanish dictionary in my pocket." He sent his parents a postcard from Paris before leaving for the Pyrenees.

The border crossing was made on foot, at night. "We wore deck shoes because they have a good grip and don't make a noise. I had my first view of the Mediterranean from the top of the mountains, looking down to this beautiful blue sea. I was excited that night, not scared at all." When they finally reached Spain, they met Spanish peasants who gave the clenched-fist salute. "That bucked you up."

Soon after leaving their Albacete training camp, Frankel's battalion was confronted with the terror of the war. "We were marching along when the order was given to dig in on the side of the road. Suddenly the order was countermanded. Well, we ran into an ambush of fascist tanks. Blinking tank was so bloody near me, he couldn't bring his machine guns down to bear on me. He fired right over my head into the side of the mountain. It was my 24th birthday."

Months later, Frankel was wounded while fighting at the Ebro. "I was firing my rifle and took a bullet through the arm. I thought I'd be out for a couple of weeks but it turned out to be more serious, severed nerves and tendons."

His right hand permanently crippled, Frankel returned from Spain to find himself rejected from service in the second world war. He volunteered for air-raid patrols during the blitz, taught himself to draw with his left hand ("I soon discovered it's not the hand, it's the eye") and became an illustrator for the Stepney Worker. There he met Pearl, the magazine's editor; they married in 1943.

"We were both in the communist party then - I joined while I was in Spain. But I left years and years ago; I'm a member of the Labour party now. Back to my roots, I suppose."

fields.headline: 'I expected it to be rough'
fields.standfirst:
See the pictures by Eamonn McCabe

The mechanic: Jack Edwards
fields.trailText: The mechanic: Jack Edwards
fields.body:
I was bought up in a political family," says Jack Edwards, an 87-year-old Liverpudlian now living in Telford. "We went to Young Communist League and Labour League of Youth meetings, so we knew what was happening in Spain. We thought we'd do something a bit better than sit around in England."

The decision to head south in the late winter of 1936 was taken quickly. "It wasn't long thought out," he says. "A few of us got a weekend ticket to Paris, you didn't have to have a passport then, got picked up and taken to Spain."

Edwards had no naive preconceptions of the conditions he was going to face. "I expected it to be very rough, and it was rough."

He was soon wounded at Jarama, but stayed in the country, determined to help. After convalescing, Edwards, a motor mechanic by trade, found himself separated from the International Brigades, working on vehicles with the Spanish republicans around Valencia. "Being with the Spanish people helped me understand what they were fighting for," he says. "They had voted for that government, and there it was being overthrown."

Because of his isolation, Edwards was unaware of the withdrawal of foreign troops. He eventually made it back to Liverpool in March 1939. Straight after his return, Edwards joined the RAF. "It was a continuation. I wasn't fighting against Germany or Italy, I was fighting for democracy. If Germany had won there would have been none."

webTitle: Does Hopkins have an appetite for Hannibal prequel?

fields.headline: Does Hopkins have an appetite for Hannibal prequel?
fields.trailText: Filming has barely finished on the second Hannibal film, but it seems that Anthony Hopkins could reprise his role as Hannibal Lector for a third time, in a prequel to Silence of the Lambs.
fields.body:
Filming has barely finished on the second Hannibal film, but it seems that Anthony Hopkins will reprise his role as Hannibal Lector for a third time, in a prequel to Silence of the Lambs.

The BBC reports that the producers of the Oscar-winning Silence of the Lambs and its forthcoming sequel Hannibal will adapt Thomas Harris's novel Red Dragon for the big screen. Ted Tally, who also wrote the script for Silence of the Lambs, will adapt the 1981 novel, and producers Dino and Martha De Laurentiis are in advanced talks with Universal Pictures to distribute the film domestically.

Red Dragon has of course been previously adapted for the screen by Michael Mann in his 1986 film Manhunter, with Brian Cox as the flesh-eating antihero. However, this film failed to catch the public's imagination in the way that 1991's Silence of The Lambs did, which made £192m worldwide and won five Oscars.

Hopkins's involvement in the new project will depend in the script. Producer Dino De Laurentiis believes that fans of Hopkin's cannibalistic doctor want to know how Lecter - safely enconsed in prison at the start of Silence of the Lambs - arrived there in the first place. "Red Dragon is about the crime Hannibal Lecter committed and the way he was arrested," he said. "Hannibal Lecter escaped in Silence of the Lambs, and in Hannibal, you see him in a new situation in Florence. . . the audience would like to know, once and forever, why, where and by whom Hannibal Lecter was arrested."

Hannibal, directed by Ridley Scott, is due for release next year. It follows the attempts of one of the doctor's former victims to exact a slow and painful revenge - involving mad-eating pigs. Jodie Foster, who won an Oscar for her role as Agent Clarice Starling, pulled out of the project over concerns that the film was too violent, and Julianne Moore is now playing the FBI agent.

webTitle: John Brown mulls launch of new lads mag

fields.headline: John Brown mulls launch of new lads' mag
fields.trailText: 11am: John Brown Publishing, which publishes Viz and Bizarre, is considering launching a new lads' magazine. Jessica Hodgson reports.
fields.body:
The company behind Viz and Bizarre is considering launching a new magazine in the already crowded lads market.

John Brown, chief executive of John Brown Publishing, has confirmed that the company is working on a dummy for the magazine, which sources say is codenamed "Fit".

"We're researching three possible new launches," said Mr Brown. "One of them could be described as a lads' mag, although we prefer to see it as general lifestyle."

A new, out-and-out lads' launch would face tough competition in a market dominated by FHM, which sells 700,000 copies, and its rivals, Loaded and Maxim.

But recent circulation figures suggest that the lads' mag format could be staging a comeback against new "mature" men's titles. From January to June FHM increased sales by 2.1%, while Maxim's sales rose 5.2%.

However, the men's magazine market has declined over the past two years, with launches such as IPC's Later and Cabal's Mondo targeting a more mature "post Loaded" market and lads' staples such as Loaded adopting a "grown-up" policy.

Loaded, IPC's flagship title, is still without an editor followign the departure of Tim Southwell earlier this year.

There is still speculation that Front editor Piers Hernu was being lined up for the job, but it is thought that the appointment would not be made until after the reorganisation of IPC's Music & Sport department under new managing director Mike Soutar.

Mr Hernu was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: Gore cries foul and fights on

fields.headline: Gore cries foul and fights on
fields.standfirst:
Democrats prepare legal challenge to US election results as margin narrows in Florida recount

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Democrats prepare legal challenge to US election results as margin narrows in Florida recount.
fields.body:
The United States faces the prospect of further weeks of uncertainty over the outcome of Tuesday's presidential election after the George W Bush and Al Gore camps both dug in yesterday for prolonged legal and political battles over the disputed result in Florida.

The fate of American democracy's ultimate political prize is increasingly likely to depend on the outcome of legal challenges which were mounted by angry Democrats on Mr Gore's behalf in Florida's Palm Beach county yesterday, with the distinct possibility that a partial re-run might yet be ordered before Bill Clinton's successor can finally be known.

Mr Gore made clear that he was refusing to concede the election to Mr Bush. As evidence of a succession of irregularities mounted, events in Florida took the US ever deeper into uncharted political and constitutional territory, threatening domestic and international consequences if the situation remains unresolved as the January 20 2001 expiry of Mr Clinton's term draws near.

In Austin, Mr Bush continued to act as though the election were done and dusted, setting up a presidential transition team under his running-mate Dick Cheney, indicating that General Colin Powell would serve in a Bush administration and conducting talks with the foreign policy adviser Condoleezza Rice.

The Bush campaign's announcements came while Florida officials were conducting the official recount in the state which will ultimately put one of the candidates over the top in the 538 seat electoral college which meets to decide the fate of the presidency on December 18.

An announcement of the result of that recount was scheduled for last night. With 62 of the state's 67 counties recounted the Bush lead was cut to just 341 out of nearly 6m votes. With Florida accepting overseas postal votes until the end of next week, the definitive result is several days away, irrespective of legal challenges.

Officials for the Gore campaign angrily dismissed the Bush actions as "bluster and arrogance", as the earlier tone of mutual respect began to fray into bitterness over the extraordinary events in Florida.

Mr Gore himself was preparing to leave his Nashville campaign headquarters and fly to Washington, an indication that he was not planning an early concession in the contest, whatever Mr Bush might say.

Mr Gore's campaign chairman, William Daley, announced in Tallahassee, the Florida state capital, that his side intended to bring a legal challenge to the validity of the election in the Palm Beach area, where 19,000 votes were declared invalid after officials issued voters with a potentially confusing two page ballot that has been the focus of hundreds of complaints.

The Gore camp wanted a further recount in Palm Beach county, to be conducted by hand, Mr Daley said. Recounts should also be held in Broward, Dade and Volusia counties, Mr Daley said.

"I would assume that the courts will take a serious look at an injustice unparalleled in our history," Mr Daley said in an earlier interview.

The Reform party candidate, Pat Buchanan, who was a beneficiary of the confusions on the Palm Beach ballot paper, said he too was suspicious of the results there, in which he won 3,400 votes, three times more than in any other county in Florida. No ally of Mr Bush, Mr Buchanan said: "I probably got some votes that really did not belong to me and I do not feel well about that."

The attorney general, Janet Reno, said there was not yet a good enough reason for federal investigators to "jump in", but she would review any complaints about voting irregularities that were brought to her.

While Florida counted its votes a second time, the national count from Tuesday's exceptionally close election neared completion, showing Mr Gore still slightly ahead, with 48.94m votes to Mr Bush's 48.75m, the closest contest since 1960. Mr Gore remained ahead in the electoral college by 255 to 246, with the 37 votes from Florida, New Mexico and Oregon undecided.

A further consequence of the furore in Florida began to make itself felt as officials of both parties in other states, including New Mexico, Wisconsin and Iowa, began to float the possibility of other recounts.

Meanwhile, as Mr Bush and Mr Gore manoeuvred over their fates, past, present and possibly even future presidents turned out for a dinner in Washington to mark the 200th birthday of the White House. Mr Bush's father and mother have made many visits to the house they occupied from 1989-93, but few can have been in such bizarre circumstances.

webTitle: AOL/Time Warner given three weeks to save mega-merger

fields.headline: AOL/Time Warner given three weeks to save mega-merger
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The blockbuster merger between AOL and Time Warner hangs in the balance after US regulators sent the £91bn deal into extra time, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The blockbuster merger between AOL and Time Warner hangs in the balance after US regulators sent the £91bn deal into extra time.

US watchdog the Federal Trade Commission has given the internet giant and media conglomerate three weeks to rescue the deal.

Anti-trust officials want Time Warner's cable network to be made available to other internet service providers, since the company controls around 20% of the US cable market.

The companies have agreed to the regulator's demands in principle, but have clashed with the FTC over enforcing them.

Sources close to the negotiations claim that the open access dispute is the tip of the iceberg, and that the parties remain some way apart.

Both partners are being encouraged to sign a deal with a rival ISP to soothe the concerns of smaller players in the internet market, and the three-week stay of execution gives them time to seek out a suitable company.

AOL and Time Warner said they expected the merger to go through by the end of the year, but the management at both companies are known to be shocked at the resistance to a deal announced last January.

The world's biggest media merger also struggled to get past European regulators, who demanded that AOL drop all links with German rival Bertelsmann.

European competition commissioner Mario Monti also effectively killed off the £12bn joint venture between record company EMI and Time Warner subsidiary Warner Music because of fears that AOL would capitalise on the deal.

fields.headline: The upside down lottery
fields.standfirst: Community worker Bob Holman calls for a drastic change in the way lottery money is distributed
fields.trailText: Community worker Bob Holman calls for a drastic change to the way lottery money is distributed.
fields.body:
The 10-member House of Commons culture, media and sports committee, chaired by Gerald Kaufman, is currently considering who will take over the running of the national lottery. I think a more valuable focus would be on how lottery money is distributed.

I have submitted evidence to the committee on how people who live in deprived areas such as mine would like to see lottery funds distributed. In it, I propose that the distribution system be turned upside down.

At present, lottery money is allocated by a number of quangos divided between the Millennium Commission, the National Heritage Memorial Fund, the arts council, the sports council and the Charities Board. Their members contain the usual establishment figures characterised by their affluence, status and powerful connections.

Much lottery money has gone to opera, ballet, art galleries, stately homes, posh rowing clubs and the wretched Millennium Dome. £13m went to purchase the Churchill papers and other benificiaries include Eton College and other public schools.

There are few poor people on the quangos so it is not surprising that small community projects in housing estates and inner ring areas have been excluded from the lion's share of the money.

These projects, whose staff are usually residents, run breakfast clubs, cafes, youth schemes, holiday programmes, credit unions and food coops. They improve the quality of life for vulnerable children, support debt ridden parents, keep kids out of care, divert teenagers from trouble and counsel drug users.Yet they are strapped for cash.

Local authorities direct much of their voluntary budget to national voluntary agencies, which are already rich, and give less to small organisations. Neighbourhood fundraising is difficult when so many are on low wages or benefits. A few projects, having managed to complete the national lottery's complicated forms, do win awards, but that assistance is not enough to meet their long term needs.

I propose that this system be turned on its head. People on low incomes spend more on the lottery than the wealthy so it seems just that their money should support deprived areas. Ticket buyers should be able to indicate whether they want their contributions to go to local causes. I believe that most would say yes.

Committees should be elected by the local population to allocate grants to existing and new projects which are controlled by residents and aimed at increasing quality of life in the neighbourhood.

The upside-down approach would have these advantages:  Deprived areas would receive substantial grants. The Social Exclusion Unit estimates that there are over 300 deprived neighbourhoods in Britain so a large number of places would benefit.
 Long-term funding would be possible as long as the Lottery continued.
 Projects would provide better services of the kind wanted by the community rather than those imposed from outside.
 Projects would reduce unemployment by taking on more residents whose salaries would then boost the local economy.
 Residents--most of whom are on incomes below half average income--would not be contributing to the Tate Gallery in London, the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art in Edinburgh, the Lawn Tennis Association, the High School in Glasgow and other institutions which do not benefit their children.
 Democracy would be promoted as elected figures replaced those appointed by patronage.
 More residents would be empowered.The consistent record of local projects is that the involvement of even the most deprived citizens as volunteers, helpers and workers, does much for their self-confidence and functioning.They begin to exert some control over their circumstances and this contributes to better family and neighbourhood life.

If transformed into a bottom-up agency, the national lottery could help deprived residents transform their neighbourhoods. Whether this happens will depend much upon my proposal getting the backing of the commons committee.

 Bob Holman lives in Easterhouse, Glasgow. He is the author of Kids At The Door Revisited, Russell House Publications, 2000.

fields.headline: Springer returns to British TV
fields.trailText: 8.30pm The controversial chat show host Jerry Springer is being given a semi-permanent berth with Channel 5, writes Jason Deans .
fields.body:
The controversial chat show host, Jerry Springer, is being given a semi-permanent berth with Channel 5.

And the station has also signed up Evening Standard editor Max Hastings to present a new series on the war.

Late Night with Jerry Springer has been commissioned for a six-part run, beginning on Wednesday November 22. Guests for the show, which begins filming tonight at Teddington studios, will include Steven Berkoff, Louise, Billie, Dani Behr, Marc Almond and Faye Ripley.

The series order follows a one-off pilot that went out at 11.05pm on Saturday October 7. The Wednesday night show is expected to be broadcast around the same time.

Mr Springer has linked up with Carlton to produce the show, in a deal brokered by the William Morris Agency. Carlton controller of entertainment Mark Wells is executive producing, with Mark Tinkler producing.

A documentary on Hitler's Third Reich will be presented by Mr Hastings.

The Third Reich In Colour, a 60-minute documentary about Hitler's Germany, features colour footage shot by his mistress, Eva Braun.

The documentary is due to go out at 8pm on Sunday December 3. It has been co-produced by United Productions and Spiegel TV, which has supplied the rare colour footage from German and American sources.

Georgina Harvey has directed and produced the show for United.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 10
fields.trailText: November 10: Financial PR agency Finsbury has been approached by several marketing services groups after takeover talks with WPP collapsed.
fields.body:
Financial PR agency Finsbury has been approached by several marketing services groups including Interpublic and Chime after takeover talks with WPP collapsed.

The Abbey National has called on Bell Pottinger Financial for PR advice over its plans to merge with the Bank of Scotland. Incumbent agency Brunswick could not handle the brief because it also acts for Bank of Scotland.

Stephen Lock, the former managing director of Ludgate's public affairs division, is launching his own consultancy called Cicero Consulting.

Turkey farmer Bernard Matthews has hired financial PR consultancy Citigate Dewe Rogerson to handle the PR for its planned buyback of the company he founded.

The Football Association has appointed Paul Newman, a BBC sports correspondent, as its head of communications.

Karen Moyse, former deputy chief executive of Hill & Knowlton, has started her own PR consultancy called Kinetic Public Relations.

Teletext is looking for a new head of PR as it prepares to reposition itself as a digital information provider.

American energy giant Amerada Hess has hired City PR firm The Maitland Consultancy to handle its £2.4bn takeover of UK oil company Lasmo.

Outgoing schools inspector Chris Woodhead is joining Bell Pottinger Public Affairs in an advisory capacity.

webTitle: Media rights battle for horse racing

fields.headline: Media rights decision put on hold
fields.trailText: With the Racecourse Association advising its members to hold back, today's deadline for deciding whether Carlton or the Go Racing consortium will get the media rights contract is due to pass without any decision being made.
fields.body:
With the Racecourse Association advising its members to hold back, today's deadline for deciding whether Carlton or the Go Racing consortium will get the media rights contract is due to pass without any decision being made.

Both tendering parties, although naturally exasperated by the delay, have now given the racecourses until Monday.

David Cameron, spokesman for Carlton, said: "Our offer which will give the racecourses more cash straight away - £350m against Go Racing's £320m - is on the table but time is running out."

Many of the smaller courses are said to be attracted by Carlton's regional programming although the company's influence does not extend to the north or Scotland.

Go Racing, comprising Channel 4, BSkyB and Arena, seem to be promising more nationwide terrestrial coverage and indications are that they have the support of the bigger tracks.

Stephen Atkin, chief executive of the Racecourse Association, said: "It would not be sensible for the racecourses to enter a period of exclusive negotiation with either party at this stage and we have advised them accordingly. We need more detailed discussion and a lot of questions still need to be answered."

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 10
fields.trailText: November 10: The Ministry of Sound has got together with LWT Entertainment to take its dance brand onto TV.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Sound has got together with LWT Entertainment to take its dance brand onto TV. Under the deal, LWT parent company Granada Media will have rights to exploit the deal internationally.

Reed Elsevier is pumping £70m into an investment fund, Reed Elsevier Ventures, that will take stakes in technology and internet companies.

Former Initiative Media chairman Tony Manwaring, now at the Manwaring Partnership, has launched a new creative communications consultancy via a webcast.

Zenith Media managing partner Tap Chauan has left to join Beyond Interactive as an account director. He is one of several new senior appointments as the agency beefs up for European expansion.

Granada Media is combining its two programming units, LWT Productions and United Productions, under a single management team headed by John Willis, now managing director of United and LWT Productions.

Outdoor specialist Portland's new site evaluation system has come under fire from rivals who claim it could devalue the industry's Postar currency. The issue is expected to be raised at the next Council of Outdoor Specialists meeting.

Dawn Airey, new chief executive at Channel 5, has made her first changes to the station's management structure.

The Sunday Times has signed a reciprocal deal with schools website Schoolsnet. The site will provide content for the broadsheet's school league table supplements in return for branding and advertising.

Transport For London has put its outdoor advertising contract up for review, inviting various contractors to submit tenders to run the advertising on 300 large-format billboard sites.

Future Publishing is launching a spin-off title from .Net called .Net Business, priced at £4.99.

Profile: Owen Gibson profiles Simon Shaps, chief executive of Granada Broadband.

webTitle: Comment:  Race for the White House

fields.headline: Split down the middle
fields.standfirst:
Race for the White House

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: America's election result is no surprise. If two centrist parties compete for the same small group of independent voters, they are likely to split the result down the middle. That cursed arithmetic confronts Tony Blair as well - and any other social democratic leader seeking to move toward the centre.
fields.body:
America's election result is no surprise. If two centrist parties compete for the same small group of independent voters, they are likely to split the result down the middle. That cursed arithmetic confronts Tony Blair as well and any other social democratic leader seeking to move toward the centre.

The American Democratic party began its trek rightward nearly 20 years back, convinced that "old democrats" - ecologists, believers in a strong welfare state, the young would remain, if unhappily, in the party. Elections would be won by capturing the affections of suburban "soccer moms", young professionals, and other voters with no strong political sentiments and so likely to vote either way.

For a while this strategy seemed to work. Bill Clinton's amazing personal gifts made it happen. Indeed, the greater his troubles, the greater his hold over the imaginations of just these voters. For better or worse, Al Gore lacked Clinton's charisma; his only assets are his integrity and his competence. Absent a candidate who could arouse the emotions of "swing" voters, the raw arithmetic of splitting the middle has asserted itself.

Rightwing pundits such as William Kristol have long understood that this strategy could hold a political party hostage to a relatively small group of confused or indifferent voters in the centre. But the leaders of the republican revolution in the 1990s misread the American public. While we tend to hate government bureaucracy, Americans want the fruits of government: good schools, adequate pensions, a well regulated environment. The opportunities for the Democratic party lie just there, in making the government work better.

The current leadership of the Democrats has failed to respond to that desire. In the election, the New Democrats made two strategic errors. The first was obvious: they treated the Green party and its leader Ralph Nader as traitors. Rather than ask what had driven the Greens out, the New Democrats tried to tame them through guilt; a vote for Nader is a vote for Bush. Which was not news to the Greens. The guilt-trip failed, the demand for better government persisted - on Green terms - and this fringe group received an unprecedented 3% of the vote, making the contest for the centre all the more fraught.

The second error was more important and more subtle. Only about half the American electorate votes; this past week the number is about 51%. A big slice of the non-voters consists of people who are apathetic, but another big slice comes from those for whom not voting is a political statement of sorts. They are "rejectionists," and most of them are young.

Young Americans who won't vote are your nice nephew or niece who believes the political system is corrupt. They aren't social isolates; many believe in, and many practice, volunteer work, which is their version of self-government. When I taught in America, I encountered them again and again - good citizens for whom politics has little to do with real life.

The New Democrats have largely ignored this pool of young people. The effort to capture the middle ground instead sent politicians in pursuit of the middle aged. On the campaign trail Gore seemed baffled when asked about policies aimed at young people, and he retreated into banalities. The failure to connect particularly lost him young male voters, aged 18 to 30, perhaps the most disaffected group in the American political spectrum.

However the final result turns out, the Democratic party has set its own course to become ever more fragile, ever more at the mercy of a relatively small group of the middle class, the middle aged and the muddled, ignoring in the process the aspiration for good governance which broadly marks the American public. Why, then, has New Labour in Britain, or the "New Middle" tendency in Germany, sought to follow in the path of the New Democrats in America, in obsessing about this unreliable middle?

The answer lies again in maths. All these centrist social democrats believe that the policies which appeal to the young, or have appealed to the old left, are likely to lose them votes in the centre. This is politics conceived as a zero-sum game: to gain new appeal you have to lose your old appeal. Certainly if Labour had retained clause four, it would not today be in power; not even Clinton could have remained in office if he had run on the programme which kept Franklin Roosevelt in office.

But this way of doing the numbers has put nothing of new substance in place of the old. The zero-sum game is a confession of intellectual poverty, as well as a practical disaster; it assumes that a social democratic party can contrive no political programme which might appeal to the public as a whole, to the young as well as the middle aged, to Greens as well as to entrepreneurs. Roosevelt managed to do so. New Democrats, like New Labour, have not. The result is that we will see in the future, and here, repeats of the pathetic drama now unfolding in the United States.

 Richard Sennett is professor of sociology at the LSE

webTitle: Command Audio to launch on-demand interactive radio

fields.headline: US firm to launch on-demand radio in UK
fields.standfirst: Nov 9: BBC mulls Radio 4 on demand
fields.trailText:
A US technology firm is set to bring on-demand interactive radio to the UK, reports Amy Vickers.
Nov 9: BBC mulls Radio 4 on demand
fields.body:
A US technology firm that has developed a TiVo-like system for radio is planning to launch in the UK.

California-based Command Audio is setting up a UK office and has held talks with the BBC and all the major commercial stations about putting deals in place by the end of the year.

Its plan is to license its personalised on-demand software to digital radio broadcasters such as the BBC, Virgin, GWR, Talk Radio, NTL and pull in TV stations and publishers to turn their content into radio broadcasts.

In the US, Command Audio has signed up a number of publications including the Wall Street Journal, Business Week, Fortune, Time, USA Today and TV shows such as Nightline and The NewsHour, which it has converted into audio material.

The TiVo-like devices will store eight hours of content and cost around £10 per month for the subscription.

"On-demand interactive audio offers a new dimension of media," said Don Bogue, co-founder and CEO of Command Audio, which raised £39m in venture capital at the start of this year.

"What we do in the UK is entirely dependent on other businesses but we're aiming at getting a number of different types of devices on the market by the middle to the end of next year."

The type of devices Command Audio anticipates being launched in the UK include a car radio, a separate hand radio and software pre-installed on digital radio devices.

Mr Bogue said the reception so far in the UK had been "great" and that he would be announcing some deals very soon.

Command Audio started testing its service with more than 200 users in Denver and Phoenix five months ago.

Mr Bogue said feedback had been positive with users quickly becoming addicted to controlling their experience of radio.

The software, which has already picked up awards for innovation in the US, took four years to develop.

In the US, Command Audio has signed up a number of publications including the Wall Street Journal, Business Week, Fortune, Time, USA Today and TV shows such as Nightline and The NewsHour, which it has converted into audio material. The TiVo-like devices will store eight hours of content and cost around £10 per month for the subscription. "On-demand interactive audio offers a new dimension of media," said Don Bogue, co-founder and CEO of Command Audio, which raised £39m in venture capital at the start of this year. "What we do in the UK is entirely dependent on other businesses but we're aiming at getting a number of different types of devices on the market by the middle to the end of next year." The type of devices Command Audio anticipates being launched in the UK include a car radio, a separate hand radio and software pre-installed on digital radio devices. Mr Bogue said the reception so far in the UK had been "great" and that he would be announcing some deals very soon. Command Audio started testing its service with more than 200 users in Denver and Phoenix five months ago. Mr Bogue said feedback had been positive with users quickly becoming addicted to controlling their experience of radio. The software, which has already picked up awards for innovation in the US, took four years to develop.

fields.headline: Hot-house nurtures billion dollar brains
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Stanford University is situated just a mile from Highway 101, the permanently clogged artery that each day somehow manages to pump the car loads of entrepreneurs, venture capitalists and programmers through Silicon Valley.
fields.body:
Stanford University is situated just a mile from Highway 101, the permanently clogged artery that each day somehow manages to pump the car loads of entrepreneurs, venture capitalists and programmers through Silicon Valley.

The wooded campus on the western edge of Palo Alto might as well be in a different state from the high-octane corporate dog fight of the valley. With its palm fringed quadrangles, expansive car-free avenues and groups of preppy students cycling to and from lectures it feels like a Californian version of Oxford or Cambridge.

Yet Stanford is Silicon Valley, and without the university the region's main revenue generator would probably still be the apricot and plum orchards that grew where countless hi-tech business parks now stand.

The figures are startling. Stanford start-ups - companies in which both the technology for the first product and a majority of the founding team came from the university - account for around 60% of total Silicon Valley revenues.

The class of 99 at the business school commanded a median compensation package of $135,000 per annum (£95,000), up 13% on the previous year. Almost half stayed to work in the Valley.

The list of Stanford start-ups reads like a roll-call for the US's biggest and most influential technology firms: Sun Microsystems, Hewlett Packard, Silicon Graphics, Cisco and hundreds of smaller firms started life in the labs on campus.

With the allure of the valley greater than ever, the university has become a mecca for the next generation of would-be leaders of corporate America. First daughter Chelsea Clinton underlined Stanford's desirability two years ago when she chose it over Harvard, her parents' alma mater and the traditional destination of the political elite.

Trying to pinpoint the precise role Stanford has played in the growth of the valley is not as easy as it might seem, says Dr Jim Gibbons, a senior academic who witnessed many of the most important milestones at first hand.

Dr Gibbons was dean of the school of engineering between the mid-80s and mid-90s when Netscape founder Jim Clark, a lecturer in the department, set up Silicon Graphics. Dr Gibbons is close to Bill Hewlett of the eponymous PC firm and in his spare time he sits on the board of Cisco and several start-ups.

"Stanford's contribution is research and the formation of new companies that can bring new products to market quickly," Dr Gibbons said.

"For established firms in hi-tech markets, it is graduate education which, on the one hand, replenishes the intellectual pool and on the other provides through distance learning programs, continuing education for engineers in industry."

Hewlett-Packard, born in a garage on the edge of campus in 1939 thanks to the efforts of students Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard, maintains close links with the university. About one quarter of its 8,000-plus engineers have at least one degree from Stanford; all engineers at HP's consumer PC base in Grenoble, France, study Stanford distance learning programmes.

"There is something very special about this region," Dr Gibbons said. "Good ideas can be had anywhere, quality teams of people can be built, money travels but Stanford and the Valley has a unique culture. People here have always been pioneering because that is how they got here; they have a positive attitude to risk, they aren't afraid of failure and they move very fast. The attitude to wealth creation and success is different from elsewhere. The valley is a place that finds talent and uses it well."

The Stanford phenomena has created a virtuous circle and the university is itself being fed by the valley's culture, wealth and infrastructure. Hewlett Packard, and Microsoft founders Bill Gates and Paul Allen have funded several multi-million dollar buildings.

However, getting in is not easy; and paying your fees is even harder. An MBA costs around $100,000 over two years. You must apply over the web. Of course.
