webTitle: Osman being wooed for top BBC job

fields.headline: Osman being wooed for top BBC job
fields.trailText: 8.30am : BBC press chief Sally Osman has been formally invited to apply for the top marketing job at the corporation, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BBC press chief Sally Osman has been formally invited to apply for the top marketing job at the Corporation.

The BBC recently briefed headhunters to find a replacement for Matthew Bannister, the outgoing director of marketing and communications.

Ms Osman, who reports directly to Mr Bannister, is understood to be the front runner for the job. She refused to comment, saying it was a personal matter.

Mr Bannister announced his resignation from the BBC last month, just six months after he took on the job.

His departure at the end of this year will come at a difficult time because the BBC is in the middle of a major overhaul of its marketing activities, including a review of its advertising agency roster. This could mean the BBC would look more favourably on an insider for the role.

Ms Osman helped launch Channel 5 before moving to the BBC as controller of publicity.

Former Channel 5 colleague Jim Hytner is also in the running.

webTitle: Mars flies in its ad teams for radical repositioning

fields.headline: Mars flies in ad teams for radical repositioning
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Mars Bar, the brand made famous with its 'Work, Rest and Play' advertising slogan, is getting a radical repositioning, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Mars Bar, the brand made famous in the seventies with its 'Work, Rest and Play' advertising slogan, is getting a radical repositioning.

Creative teams from six Mars ad agencies from around the world are being flown to London to create the next big campaign, which will air worldwide in March next year.

The result will be the most significant global advertising for the brand yet.

Chris Palengat, European board account director at D'Arcy, a Mars roster agency, said: "We want to reawaken the sleeping giant that is the Mars brand.

"The brand isn't as modern and in your face as it should be. Instead everyone's asking Whassup? Mars needs new advertising to give it a shot in the arm."

Mr Palengat and his team at D'Arcy in London have hand-picked the cream of the network's creative talent, who will devise a campaign to run across the confectionary giant's key global markets.

Mars spends £10m in the UK alone promoting Mars Bar.

"There isn't anyone who has eaten a Mars Bar and thinks it's anything other than delicious," said Mr Palengat. "It deserves great advertising."

fields.headline: BSkyB to launch digital business channel
fields.trailText: 8.00am: BSkyB is to launch a digital TV business-to-business channel aimed at the financial services industry, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB is to launch a digital TV business-to-business channel aimed at the financial services industry.

The broadcaster has recruited David Walker from Barclays' international business development division to oversee the channel, which is due to launch next year.

The service will be targeted at an audience of more than 22,000 independent financial advisers, as well as other professionals working in the financial services industry.

Programming will include news, analysis and training relevant to the financial services sector.

The channel is being launched by BSkyB's business division, which has invested in a TV studio in Middlesex and already launched business-to-business channels dedicated to the motor industry and the health sector. Later this month the outfit will also be launching the Pub Channel.

Bruce Cuthbert, head of development for BSkyB's business division, said: "A business TV channel for those involved in marketing financial products will help to raise standards through improved communication of information and training."

webTitle: Controversial 11 0'Clock Show faces axe as Channel 4's new line-up launched

fields.headline: Controversial 11 0'Clock Show faces axe as Channel 4's new line-up launched
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Channel 4's satirical series, the 11 O'Clock Show, which featured the spoof rapper Ali G, is facing the axe, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Channel 4's satirical series the 11 O'Clock Show, which featured the spoof rapper Ali G, is facing the axe.

The channel fears the show has lost its edge since the departure of Sacha Baron Cohen, the creator of Ali G, who now has his own series. The presenters, Iain Lee and Daisy Donovan, have also left.

When the series started last year it quickly drew a cult following. "It seems that we always do better when we do something new," one Channel 4 executive said. "If we decide the show has become atrophied, then we should stop it."

Yesterday, at the launch of the channel's winter season line-up, Tim Gardam, director of programmes, said: "I haven't decided yet", in answer to questions about the show's return.

The new line-up appears to be dominated by sex and death. There is a three-part documentary on cannibalism, which looks at killers Jeffrey Dahmer and Issei Sagawa, who ate their victims.

The channel will also screen three dramas "designed to shock". Shot in a Blair Witch Project-style, the Shockers series features a mother who takes a brutal revenge on school bullies.

Two new drama series will concentrate on personal relationships. Metrosexuality features an unconventional set of friends in Notting Hill, London, and Teachers, starring This Life's Andrew Lincoln, is described as "Ally McBeal set in a comprehensive school".

Mr Gardam said that the line-up was distinctive, and he attacked BBC1 and ITV for their programmes, saying: "The future of quality television does not have to be two episodes of EastEnders sandwiching The Weakest Link."

webTitle: Looking for justice as Palestinians continue to die

fields.headline: Looking for justice as Palestinians continue to die
fields.standfirst: Israel has been condemned for using too much force against Palestinians, and Brian Whitaker questions whether any legal action can be taken against them
fields.trailText: Israel has been condemned for using too much force against Palestinians, and Brian Whitaker questions whether any legal action can be taken against them.
fields.body:
A few days after the intifada began, an Israeli official explained to me the reasons for using disproportionate force. It was, he said, to make the Palestinians "re-calibrate their calculations".

In other words, live bullets against stones might seem harsh, but it would save lives in the long run because, once the Palestinians saw the Israelis meant business, they would quickly back off.

It didn't work out like that, though. Six weeks later, with more than 150 Palestinians dead, the officials have a different argument.

Protecting the lives of Israeli soldiers must come first, and unfortunately, Israel does not have effective non-lethal methods for riot control, they say.

It is remarkable that, in the 13 years since the outbreak of the first intifada, nobody in Israel has given much thought to riot control.

However, according to the Israeli press, scientists are now hard at work developing slippery chemicals and sticky chemicals that, one day, may stop rioters in their tracks.

The result, in the meantime, is that soldiers are protecting themselves by shooting Palestinians dead from distances of 650 or more - well beyond the reach of stone-throwers.

Yesterday, the killing took a new turn, with the extra-judicial execution of Hussein Abayat, a Fatah activist - apparently with the blessing of prime minister Ehud Barak.

Executing people without trial is bad enough, but executing them in the street, by a rocket fired from a helicopter, is even more appalling.

The rocket also happened to execute two elderly Palestinian women nearby and injured 10 other people - a possibility that Mr Barak could reasonably have foreseen when approving the mission.

Culpability for such actions does not lie just with the person who pulls the trigger.

Under international law, a military commander or political leader can also be held responsible if he knew (or should have known) about the action and failed to prevent or punish it.

Last week, a report by Amnesty International urged both sides in the conflict to show restraint, but reserved most of its criticism for the Israelis.

"There is a pattern of gross human rights violations that may well amount to war crimes," a spokesman said.

A few weeks earlier, the Arab summit in Cairo also talked about war crimes and called for unnamed Israeli leaders to be put on trial.

But are such trials a realistic possibility? I asked an international lawyer, who outlined five different legal routes, although none of them looks very promising.

 Option 1: Israel and the Palestinian National Authority could agree to set up a war crimes tribunal, jointly. That, I think it's safe to say, is a non-starter.

 Option 2: The United Nations Security Council could establish an ad hoc international criminal tribunal based on its powers to maintain international peace and security, under Chapter VII of the UN Charter, as it did with Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. As a permanent member of the council, the United States has the right of veto and would almost certainly use it.

 Option 3: The new International Criminal Court (see http://www.igc.apc.org/icc/) could take action, but the court will not become operational until 60 countries have ratified the Rome Statute which established it.

Although the pace of signatures (115 so far) and ratifications (22) has been faster than expected, the statute is not expected to come into force until the end of 2001 or early 2002.

Among the Arab League countries, despite their apparent enthusiasm for prosecuting Israelis, only Jordan, Kuwait, Sudan, Morocco, Djibouti and Comoros have got as far as signing, and none has ratified.

The court could, however, become operational almost immediately if the 54 members of the Islamic Conference Organisation, who are, this weekend, holding a summit which will doubtless condemn Israel, collectively agreed to ratify it as soon as possible.

One reason for the general reluctance is that the court is a double-edged sword. Once a country ratifies, its citizens become liable to be prosecuted in it. This naturally worries those leaders who have a shady past (or, in some cases, a shady present, too).

Israel itself has not signed up, which would make prosecuting Israelis in the court difficult. But it would not be impossible because crimes committed by citizens of a state that has failed to ratify can still be referred to it by the Security Council - unless prevented by a member's veto.

 Option 4: The Israeli and Palestinian authorities could separately prosecute their own citizens, either for crimes under local law (such as murder) or under international law.

A few cases involving relatively unimportant people are, in fact, already under way in both Israel and the Palestinian territories, but, although both have occasionally investigated or prosecuted human rights abuses, neither side has much incentive to pursue them vigorously.

Local prosecutions under international law could also be problematic for technical reasons. For example, the extent to which international law has been incorporated into Palestinian law is uncertain, and for historical reason, the parts of it that apply in Gaza may differ from those that apply in the West Bank.

 Option 5: The Pinochet syndrome. Leaders who travel abroad could be arrested and prosecuted in other countries for torture, crimes against humanity and war crimes.

Although approximately half the countries in the world are known to give their courts universal jurisdiction over one or more of such crimes, much of this legislation is defective.

For example, not all crimes are included or their definitions are inconsistent with international law. They may also leave the final decision on whether to investigate or prosecute to a political official. In any event, we can be reasonably sure than anyone arrested would follow Pinochet's lead by developing an incurable illness or producing medical evidence of brain damage.

Despite the rhetoric, nobody in power in the Middle East is particularly keen on going down this route. The prosecution of a major figure on, say, the Israeli side might easily lead tit-for-tat prosecutions on the other - and there are plenty of officials in the PLO and Syria, for example, who could find themselves in trouble.

Prosecution, too, is mainly a way of showing public disapproval and exacting retribution, but it doesn't help the victims of crimes, especially when they're dead.

Prevention would be a lot better.

In the current situation - with little chance of an agreed ceasefire - the best hope for prevention may lie in establishing an international presence on the ground.

But that is something the United States, Europe and Israel refuse to contemplate at present.

webTitle: ECB tries to exploit American jitters

fields.headline: ECB tries to exploit American jitters
fields.standfirst:
Summers blunts bank's latest attempt to prop up the euro

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Summers blunts bank's latest attempt to prop up the euro.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank sought yesterday to exploit foreign exchange market jitters caused by the deadlocked American presidential race when it stepped in to defend the euro for the third time in less than a week.

With its strategy of propping up the single currency given strong backing by a new report from the International Monetary Fund, the ECB again acted alone to raise the euro's value against the US dollar and the Japanese yen.

As with previous forays into the market, the ECB achieved only a limited and short-lived impact, with an initial rally in the euro followed by a retreat to its pre-intervention level.

The single currency rose from 85.60 cents to the dollar at the time of yesterday's move to 86.30 but then fell back to 85.70 by the close of trading in London.

Remarks by Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary, that Washington believed a strong dollar was in America's interest since it helped to keep down inflation and interest rates, blunted the impact of the ECB's manoeuvre.

Nick Parsons, currency analyst at Commerzbank, said that each bout of intervention since the concerted G7 move in late September had resulted in a lower peak for the euro. It reached almost 90 cents in September, 87.95 last Friday and 86.90 on Monday.

"But I think the ECB has achieved what it set out to do," Mr Parsons said. "It has got a more symmetrical market, and taken away the notion that the euro is a one-way bet. It has bought itself some time."

The IMF said yesterday that the ECB-led concerted intervention in September was well-judged and that the "misalignment" of the fledging currency compared to the dollar would eventually correct.

In an upbeat annual assessment of the economic and monetary policies of the 11-nation single currency zone, the IMF said Europe should use its improving outlook to address structural problems and ensure long-term growth.

"Directors agreed that the September concerted intervention in support of the euro had helped in stabilizing the exchange rate by sending a signal that market participants will have to bear in mind in the future," the IMF said in a report completed on October 16, well before the ECB embarked on its solo effort to defend the single currency.

The IMF made clear that it shares the view of the ECB that the 30% decline in the value of the euro since its launch less than two years ago does not reflect economic fundamentals.

webTitle: Police will exclude truckers' from London

fields.headline: Police will exclude truckers' from London
fields.trailText: Police will form a massive exclusion zone around London to prevent fuel protesters in lorries from entering the centre of the capital, Scotland Yard said today.
fields.body:
Police will form a massive exclusion zone around London to prevent fuel protesters in lorries from entering the centre of the capital, Scotland Yard said today.

Lorry drivers campaigning for a cut in the fuel duty left Tyneside earlier today in a "go-slow" convoy expecting to arrive in London next week.

Between 40 and 50 lorries and tractors left Birtley service station shortly after 9am. Initial estimates had suggested that hundreds of vehicles could be involved, but organisers struggled to determine which drivers were actually taking part in the demonstration and which were simply staying over at the truck stop.

The convoy travelled first to Newcastle, causing major disruption in the city centre, before rejoining the A1 and travelling south to Leeds.

Protesters are pressing ahead with the demonstration despite Chancellor Gordon Brown's £1bn hand-out for the haulage industry in his pre-Budget speech on Wednesday.

Northumbria Police have invoked powers under the Public Order Act 1986 to restrict the convoy to 100 lorries. The limit has only been imposed for the Newcastle section of the procession and will not prevent hundreds more joining elsewhere in the country.

Organisers have complained of increasing friction between themselves and the police.

A letter to the drivers said that the force recognises an individual's right to freedom of expression and assembly, as defined in articles 10 and 11 of the Human Rights Act. But it reminded the protestors that article two of the same act obliges the police to protect life and enforce the law.

John Coxon, from the People's Fuel Lobby, said: "We did have a good rapport with the police when we were demonstrating at Jarrow in September, but it seems that relationship has waned a little bit since then."

Last week, civic leaders on South Tyneside urged the protesters not to start their convoy in Jarrow, as they feared it would tarnish the memory of the famous marchers who walked to London in the 1930s in their fight against poverty.

The convoy will head for Manchester on Saturday, Stoke and Birmingham on Sunday, Northampton and Milton Keynes on Monday, before reaching the area around London on Tuesday.

Transport minister Lord Macdonald urged those lorry drivers joining the demonstration to think again.

"It is running up to Christmas, the busiest time of the year for them, there is flooding around - we have got enough disruption around without adding to it," he said.

Around a dozen environmental campaigners were at Birtley today making the case for higher fuel taxes.

Tony Juniper, policy and campaigns director at Friends of the Earth, said that he had been trying to engage organisers in a debate ahead of today's planned convoy.

Friends of the Earth intends to follow the protest around the country, calling for the retention of high fuel duties to prevent further global warming.

"We are here basically to try to widen the discussion away from the price of fuel so that we can talk about the longer-term costs to society of cheaper fuel," Mr Juniper said.

webTitle: Fuel tax convoy off to slow start

fields.headline: Fuel tax convoy off to slow start
fields.standfirst:
York and Cheshire police warn protesters off

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: York and Cheshire police warn protesters off.
fields.body:
The fuel tax protesters' long-heralded mass convoy was reduced at one stage yesterday to a solitary cement mixer and a four wheel drive Toyota, as it headed south from the border town of Berwick-upon-Tweed on the first leg of a planned five day haul to London.

That was two vehicles down on what had set out at 30mph from Berwick on what had been billed as the truckers' answer to Gordon Brown, a go-slow that would bring the motorways to a standstill before a rally in Hyde Park on Tuesday.

But protest organisers are hopeful that numbers will pick up today, as what they call the new Jarrow crusade formally kicks off near the Angel of the North outside Gateshead.

Andrew Spence, one of the leaders of the People's Fuel Lobby, said there was nothing in Mr Brown's pre-budget statement on Wednesday to help farmers and hauliers now. "The protest will go ahead as planned," he said.

A Northumberland farmer, Charlie Armstrong, said he was expecting anything between six and 600 lorries to join the protest, while the fuel lobby vice-chairman Mark Francis predicted between 10 and 15 trucks would set off today.

Mr Armstrong said the aim was not to cause disruption, but to get a "gentle message across to the government".

North Yorkshire police defended their decision to take powers under the Public Order Act to bar the truckers from flood-stricken York, saying the force was "extremely stretched".

The deputy chief constable, Peter Walker, said he "always made sure people have the opportunity to make their point - just this once I am asking them to leave us to deal with the crisis".

John Pratt, a Farmers for Action leader, said the ban "smacked of a police state", but David Handley, chairman of the People's Fuel Lobby, said the protesters would respect it.

Police in Cheshire, where the convoy is expected in a couple of days, took a tougher stand, saying they would deal "robustly" with any obstruction. "If drivers persist in taking unlawful action, the Cheshire constabulary will prosecute and if necessary arrest offenders," the assistant chief constable, Graeme Gerrard, said.

The convoy also faces the prospect of counter demonstrations by environmentalists. Tony Juniper, campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, said: "Road transport is one of the biggest contributors to the problem of climate change and cheaper fuel will only make the problem worse."

webTitle: Brown defends cut in face of green protests

fields.headline: Brown defends cut in face of green protests
fields.standfirst:
Pump labelling hinders hunt for cleaner fuel

Special report: the petrol war
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Ultra low sulphur petrol has been heralded as the green fuel for the future by the government. But just how readily available is the new 'greener' fuel at Britain's 12,000 forecourts?
fields.body:
Ultra low sulphur petrol has been heralded as the green fuel for the future by the government. But just how readily available is the new 'greener' fuel at Britain's 12,000 forecourts?

The Guardian yesterday visited several stations to hunt for the greener fuel. The first stop, at a Texaco station on Clerkenwell Road, central London, offered doughnuts, gourmet coffee and a jet wash but there was no sign of ultra-low sulphur petrol. "We'll get it in a couple of weeks," the sales assistant said. "A lot of our customers have asked for it today."

Twenty minutes later, in Kennington, south London, at a BP station, Salimonu Adegoroye had just filled up his Mercedes with "unleaded" petrol. Until yesterday he had never heard of ULSP. "I've got no need to change. But if I saw it, I'd buy it," he said. The fore court manager said Mr Adegoroye's purchase was USLP. But it is labelled Cleaner Unleaded on the pump. So is it cheaper? "No, not yet. But after what the chancellor said, it will be," he said.

At a nearby Texaco station, the sales assistant has not heard of the greener petrol. "You just mean unleaded, yeah?". He suggested trying "the Esso up the road."

Many petrol companies have chosen not to brand the fuel as a different product from their unleaded petrol, which has confused many of their customers about exactly what they are putting in their tanks.

A spokeswoman for Shell, who make ULSP in its own refineries, said: "There's no reason to rebrand it. It's effectively the next generation of unleaded."

More than half of Sainsbury's petrol stations one of the first companies to stock the low-sulphur petrol in 1998 - now sell it. "It's not a niche market. We sell it as our standard unleaded fuel," a spokesman said.

Six hundred of TotalFinalElf's 1,400 stations in the UK have stocked the greener fuel since October. The company is one of the few who have branded it USLP. "It replaces unleaded fuel. We stock one or the other," a spokeswoman said.

Consumer ignorance about whether the pump marked "unleaded" contains USLP, is not helped by the fact that they are not benefiting from the 1p cut that the chancellor pledged in October. Many petrol companies, including TotalFinalElf have failed to pass on the cut, arguing that it is more expensive to produce than 'old' unleaded petrol. "The current 1p concession barely covers the cost of the manufacturing and marketing expenses," the spokeswoman said.

fields.headline: 'We aim to make a point, not cripple London'
fields.standfirst:
Grassroots demonstrators deny fractures in movement

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: A mood of calm has descended on the nation's fuel protesters, or so says their deputy chairman, Mark Francis.
fields.body:
A mood of calm has descended on the nation's fuel protesters, or so says their deputy chairman, Mark Francis.

The People's Fuel Lobby did not like what Gordon Brown's pre-budget statement had to offer them, but still they were "happy".

Mr Francis said the mood within the group was one of confidence. He did not seem to think that this grassroots fuel lobby had run out of gas.

"We have made some headway in so much as the chancellor addressed the fuel issue, and [it shows] that the government have admitted that they have got a problem," he said. "We need to move on now from the schoolyard bickering and muck-throwing between government and protesters."

He is less reactive, and certainly less reactionary, than some of his colleagues in the PFL. He is the counterbalance to its chairman David Handley, a militant farmer from south Wales who enjoys a spat with anyone from the government or with people he believes are new Labour.

The PFL is a collection of hauliers, farmers and other protesters, headed by a seven-member committee. Mr Handley and Mr Francis, its effective leaders, are constantly on their mobile phones to each other, agreeing on tactics and hatching plans, but rarely meet.

On the eve of the pre-budget statement, they sat down in a London restaurant with other committee members and, in high spirits, dismissed any talk of fractures in their movement.

These men had come from nowhere and here they were, in the capital, making guest appearances on Newsnight and Kilroy and countless other programmes, and they were enjoying it. Their voice was being heard and they had no doubt that the government was beginning to listen.

There was no big plan and "no hidden agenda". They would wait and see what Mr Brown had to offer.

Some of those at the table have been involved in the group Farmers for Action. But before the pickets of oil refineries which almost crippled the country, Mr Francis and many others within the PFL were "just your average blokes". His father was the first of the family to turn up at the Stanlow oil refinery in Ellesmere Port, and the son followed a few days later.

After Brynle Williams, the figurehead of the protest, had gone home, Mark Francis found himself thrust into a position where he was checking the tankers' paperwork, and when it was suspected that unruly elements were about to cause trouble he was asked to address the crowd.

"After that there was no going back. My involvement with the protest suddenly escalated," he said. "I have never been involved in anything like this before. I have never been on strike."

Now, he said, he spoke for the nation, or the majority of it.

The government had stopped listening, he said, but he was keen to point out that the protest was not aimed at this government but government in general.

There would be no return to the barricades at the refineries. There would just be the so-called Jarrow convoy and a couple of rallies, including one in Hyde Park on Tuesday. The aim was not to cripple London but to make a point.

"I don't want the convoy to create mass chaos and pandemonium. We could have blockaded the refineries, and we could have had hand to hand combat with the police, but we don't want to do that.

"The convoy will travel at a safe and sensible speed. But we have got to create some sort of impact so that the government say, 'Bloody hell, they are here'."

Mr Francis believes the real problem is not too many foreign hauliers. "Everybody has jumped up and down and have said this fuel price has put us out of business - that's bullshit. The deep-rooted problem is over-population [in the British haulage industry].

"There are too many wagons on the road."

webTitle: Pump labelling hinders hunt for cleaner fuel

fields.headline: Pump labelling hinders hunt for cleaner fuel
fields.standfirst:
Backlash for Chancellor after his pre-budget report as environmentalists accuse him of trying to disguise road lobby surrender

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: The chancellor yesterday faced a backlash over his highly political pre-budget report as green groups claimed he had tried to disguise the scale of his surrender to the motoring lobby.
fields.body:
The chancellor yesterday faced a backlash over his highly political pre-budget report as green groups claimed he had tried to disguise the scale of his surrender to the motoring lobby.

Gordon Brown also came under attack from the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, for smuggling a £200 a year increase in national insurance for anyone earning £29,900 or more.

Mr Portillo said the change was "yet another stealthy tax which makes people such as top nurses and senior teachers around £200 a worse off".

He complained that the small print of the Treasury's accompanying documents show people earning £575 a week or more will pay national insurance at 10% on an extra £40 a week of their earnings and stop paying national insurance on an extra £3 on their earnings. As a result, they lose £4 a week and get only 30p a week.

Meanwhile Mr Brown denied he had caved into pressure from fuel protesters and throughout yesterday worked hard to defend his surprise 2p cut in duty on ultra low sulphur petrol in face of criticisms from environmentalists.

Greenpeace claimed "low sulphur fuels are not green fuels. They are still oil and do nothing to combat climate change".

The Treasury responded that the spread of ULSP was the crucial precondition for the introduction of a new generation of cleaner and more fuel efficient engines.

Confronted by the competing demands of the hauliers and environmentalists, Mr Brown tried in his pre-budget report on Wednesday to square the circle by cutting duty by 2p per litre on this new cleaner fuel. He also cut duty on clean diesel by 3p.

Before his report the chancellor had presented an unyielding political face to motorists by suggesting he would only be freezing duty.

In reality, by the time the 2p cut in ULSP is implemented next March, almost every motorist will be able to take advantage of the cut. Ninety seven per cent of petrol engines can take ULSP, a fuel which will be available in every garage by next spring.

As a result, some claimed yesterday that Mr Brown had in reality bowed to the motoring lobby, but disguised his weakness by dressing it all up as a bogus green move.

Greenpeace argued fuel duty cuts encouraged motoring, so increasing congestion and adding to Co2 emissions. Imperial College, London asserted the cuts will increase traffic by 1.5%.

This analysis was disputed by ministers and by the oil industry which has been discussing ULSP's advantages together for many months on the government's cleaner vehicles task force.

The task force had been set up largely in response to the pressure from the EU for big cuts in engine pollutants by 2005.

The EU wants the sulphur content in fuel cut to 50 parts per million by 2005. The EU has also brokered a voluntary agreement to reduce the Co2 emissions of the average new car by 25% by 2008-9.

Dr Michael Frend, director general of the UK Petrol Industries Association, pointed out yesterday that the real environmental benefits from ULSP will come from enabling lean burn engines, known as gasoline direct injection, to come onto the market from 2002-3.

Dr Frend predicted GDI engines will reduce emissions by 10-15% largely by being more more fuel efficient.

A Treasury paper published this week said: "GDI technology will require the use of exhaust after treatment systems to control regulated emissions and ULSP will be an essential pre-requisite for this."

Greenergy, one of the UK's largest supplier of low emission fuels, said ULSP was the only fuel which will reduce emissions from older pre-catalytic converter vehicles.

Ray Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers Association, said the duty cut would speed the spread of ULSP

It is already said to be available in four out of five Esso stations. Esso has been producing the petrol at its Fawley refinery since October.

BP has the fuel in 60% of its 1,500 stations, marketed as BP Cleaner Fuels. It is estimated that 35% of all unleaded petrol is ULSP, even if many customers do not know this due to the lack of branding.

webTitle: The presidency - a jalopy with failing brakes

fields.headline: The presidency - a jalopy with failing brakes
fields.standfirst: Legal threats, accusations and counter accusations, claims of legitimacy and illegitimacy. Martin Kettle contemplates this newest US entertainment form
fields.trailText: Legal threats, accusations and counter accusations, claims of legitimacy and illegitimacy. Martin Kettle contemplates this newest US entertainment form.
fields.body:
What you begin to sense at a moment like this, the commentator Jeff Greenfield observed last night, is a feeling a bit akin to watching a lovingly maintained vintage car begin to slip slowly and gracefully down a slight incline with no obvious way of ensuring that it stops.

We all know there have been moments like this in earlier presidential elections. We've all boned up on the 1888 precedent and on the 1876 precedent, and we're all suddenly familiar once more with the 1960 race and how Nixon - actually it was Eisenhower, though Nixon later took the credit - manfully decided not to challenge the result when Kennedy pipped him.

But I don't think the precedents help much when the brakes don't work. The old constitutional jalopy is beginning to slip down the hill, gathering momentum while the politicians try hard not to look.

We don't know where it will end, except that it will be a mangle and a tangle at the finish.

There were scenes in West Palm Beach last night that one never thought to see in the US. Protestors demanding a rerun of the election. Angry confrontation between supporters of the two candidates

It all looked more like Belgrade or Lima or Manila than the World's Greatest Democracy. Hunkered down in Austin, George W Bush tried to pretend there wasn't a problem. The Slobodan Milosevic of Texas.

Bush talks all the time about bringing people together, about being a uniter not a divider. There are good judges in Texas who say it's partly true, and a lot of people in the Republican Party believe it with all the sincerity at their disposal.

And when these guys do sincere, believe me, it brings tears to the eyes.

I've been puzzling about this claim for many weeks. It's so patently false and deceitful for the Republicans to claim to be the party of unity. So how come so many of them believe it?

I think the answer lies in how they think about Bill Clinton. The Bushies are still in denial about Clinton. They believe he was illegitimate, politically speaking.

They think they're engaged in a sacred task in trying to get rid of him and his supporters. They pretend this was an election about the surplus or social security or the military. But it wasn't. Not for them.

Almost every Republican I spoke to throughout the campaign said it was an election about "integrity".

Translated, they meant it was about Clinton - or as the more colourful of them call him "the rapist".

A uniter, in Bush-speak, means having the Republicans back in power, a goal the party has very nearly achieved this week. Like the Conservatives in Britain, the Republicans see themselves as the natural party of government. Anything else is, by definition, division.

This goes some way to explain why the Republicans are impatient to get back into the White House. It's why they are already arrogantly talking about the "transition".

It's why they were so willing to intimidate Americans into believing they were steamrolling towards victory. It was just a bully's lie.

Remember all that talk about the narrowing Gore lead in California? Gore won California by 11% on Tuesday.

A true uniter would behave very differently right now to the way that both Bush and Gore are handling the Florida situation. He'd look for a compromise solution like a government of national unity of the sort they sometimes have in Germany, Israel or Northern Ireland and other divided lands.

A true uniter might even take up the suggestion in the Onion this week, and declare the winner president Bush or Gore.

Peter Loge, of the Justice Project, speaking on NPR yesterday morning, took this suggestion further. Give it to both of them, he suggested. A tag team presidency.

If laid-back charm was needed, George could be the president. If specific knowledge was in demand, Al could take over. And with two vice-presidents, well, you could cover twice the number of funerals.

I'm not sure the US is seen at its best when it digs in on a matter of principle versus expediency. It feels too much like the impeachment crisis for comfort.

People who hate Republicans say this is a crisis of legitimacy. People who hate Democrats say this is a crisis of legitimacy too.

But they mean exactly the opposite thing from one another.

The truth is that those founding fathers of theirs have bequeathed another mighty difficult problem to a US that they could never have imagined.

This is a moment when pride and stubbornness in the permanent truths of the constitution are not the most helpful qualities. A bit of practicality would do wonders. A bit more attention to magnanimity would be as effective as checking the brakes more carefully on the aged limo.

As the US political system slips gently but effortlessly down the long hill, the most urgent thing to do is to stop its slide. Unless, like most of us, you secretly like watching disasters.

webTitle: New perks for MEPs bound to rile Eurosceptics

fields.headline: New perks for MEPs bound to rile Eurosceptics
fields.standfirst: Controversial European Parliament proposals would see British Euro-MPs awarded a 24% pay rise and exempted from UK tax. Unsurprisingly not everyone is happy about it, writes Andrew Osborn
fields.trailText: Controversial European Parliament proposals would see British Euro-MPs awarded a 24% pay rise and exempted from UK tax. Unsurprisingly not everyone is happy about it, writes Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
The fabled EU gravy train is once again gathering speed. Its pampered occupants - the 626 Euro-MPs who represent ordinary Europeans -- seem blissfully unaware, however, that they are doing untold harm to their own rather seedy image.

In a move which will do little to dispel the popular image of the European Parliament as a freeloader's paradise, its president Nicole Fontaine has formally proposed that Euro-MPs should enjoy a hefty pay rise and be taxed at a special low 'community' rate.

Euro-MPs should, she argues, be paid a uniform rate of £60,000 per year and continue to enjoy their already generous array of expenses and other allowances.

For many national governments, however, it's just too much for too little and the European Parliament is likely to come under fierce attack behind closed doors.

British MEPs would do particularly well out of the arrangement and would be in line for a pay rise of some £12,000. Nor would they have to worry about UK tax since they would enjoy a special low 'community' rate of around 25%.

That would mean that British MEPs would for the first time earn more than their Westminster counterparts who are on £48,371 after their own pay rise earlier this year.

And if that wasn't enough to get the blood of even the mildest Eurosceptic above boiling point, then the fact that MEPs will also be able to benefit from their full tax allowances in their home countries for lucrative sidelines such as consultancy work undoubtedly will.

Reform of the assembly's notoriously lax pay and conditions regime is, however, long overdue. At the moment all Euro-MPs receive exactly the same salaries as their national counterparts, which means that there are massive disparities in pay.

At the top end, the Italian contingent get about £73,000 a year for example while poorly paid Spanish MEPs make just £24,000 per annum. The idea therefore is that everyone should be paid the same. But the flipside is that in exchange for uniform pay rates, MEPs are looking for large pay rises.

Many argue that Euro-MPs must also be willing to allow their infamously lax expenses regime to be tightened up but these proposals say only that they should be reimbursed for "the costs actually incurred in the exercise of their mandate."

It is therefore unclear whether MEPs will have to start producing receipts to justify their every expense, something which incredibly they are currently not obliged to do.

Every Brussels insider knows that MEPs can claim huge amounts without having to provide proof of their expenses. Some employ their wives and pocket the generous secretarial allowances on offer and the daily attendance payments of around £160 are especially open to abuse.

Simon Murphy, the leader of the Labour party in the European Parliament, has condemned the parliament's proposals as "unacceptable" and believes that the assembly is squandering a unique opportunity to improve its tarnished image.

"I don't think it's acceptable that I pay a different rate of tax to that of my constituent and this kind of pay rise is unacceptable," he told the Guardian. "The European Parliament has been ducking and weaving over the issue of pay and expenses for far too long and it's time it put its own house in order. MEPs must seize this chance to regain the respect of a disenchanted public."

EU ambassadors have discussed the proposals behind closed doors and are also said to have serious reservations about the sheer generosity of what is on the table.

There is a feeling, however, that one way or another a deal will be struck before too long - Mrs Fontaine has just one year left in office and is known to be keen to leave behind some kind of meaningful legacy.

France, current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, will discuss the proposals with the parliament next Tuesday. The parliament has got just one problem: any new pay deal needs to be unanimously approved by EU governments and they are unlikely to swallow the kind of salary hikes and tax exemptions now on the table.

Earlier this year British Tory MEP Robert Goodwill described on the BBC's Today programme how the current expenses system works for him. "I fly from Leeds-Bradford to Brussels and we get a set fee of I think, somewhere around about £500. But I can buy a cheaper ticket, economy class, for between £160 and £250 and I can pocket the difference," he explained.

"And of course as a capitalist, as a British Conservative, I see it as a challenge to buy cheap tickets and to make profit on the system because that is the system."

Many argue that Euro-MPs must also be willing to allow their infamously lax expenses regime to be tightened up but these proposals say only that they should be reimbursed for "the costs actually incurred in the exercise of their mandate." It is therefore unclear whether MEPs will have to start producing receipts to justify their every expense, something which incredibly they are currently not obliged to do. Every Brussels insider knows that MEPs can claim huge amounts without having to provide proof of their expenses. Some employ their wives and pocket the generous secretarial allowances on offer and the daily attendance payments of around £160 are especially open to abuse. Simon Murphy, the leader of the Labour party in the European Parliament, has condemned the parliament's proposals as "unacceptable" and believes that the assembly is squandering a unique opportunity to improve its tarnished image. "I don't think it's acceptable that I pay a different rate of tax to that of my constituent and this kind of pay rise is unacceptable," he told the Guardian. "The European Parliament has been ducking and weaving over the issue of pay and expenses for far too long and it's time it put its own house in order. MEPs must seize this chance to regain the respect of a disenchanted public." EU ambassadors have discussed the proposals behind closed doors and are also said to have serious reservations about the sheer generosity of what is on the table. There is a feeling, however, that one way or another a deal will be struck before too long - Mrs Fontaine has just one year left in office and is known to be keen to leave behind some kind of meaningful legacy. France, current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, will discuss the proposals with the parliament next Tuesday. The parliament has got just one problem: any new pay deal needs to be unanimously approved by EU governments and they are unlikely to swallow the kind of salary hikes and tax exemptions now on the table. Earlier this year British Tory MEP Robert Goodwill described on the BBC's Today programme how the current expenses system works for him. "I fly from Leeds-Bradford to Brussels and we get a set fee of I think, somewhere around about £500. But I can buy a cheaper ticket, economy class, for between £160 and £250 and I can pocket the difference," he explained. "And of course as a capitalist, as a British Conservative, I see it as a challenge to buy cheap tickets and to make profit on the system because that is the system." fields.headline: Centrica tactics queried
fields.standfirst: ScottishPower blames rival for loss of customers
fields.trailText: The energy industry regulator Callum McCarthy is coming under pressure to scale back drastically Centrica's dominance of the domestic gas and electricity supply market.
fields.body:
The energy industry regulator Callum McCarthy is coming under pressure to scale back drastically Centrica's dominance of the domestic gas and electricity supply market.

Ian Russell, deputy chief executive of ScottishPower, yesterday challenged the effectiveness of the new open, competitive market in which Centrica, trading as British Gas, retains 80% of customers.

He said the Scottish group, which also owns Manweb, the north-west of England supplier, had lost 200,000 customers in the past six months - the bulk of them to British Gas.

Mr Russell, who replaces Sir Ian Robinson as chief executive in April, suggested that Centrica was using its national presence to dominate a supposedly competitive market through unmatched spending on advertising.

"There are not too many markets where one player has 80% and yet it's a regulated market which is sup posed to encourage competition," he said.

ScottishPower has 3.5m energy customers and claims to be attracting 46,000 new ones a month, with 693,000 new gas, 274,000 new electricity and 541,000 dual-fuel customers. It has kept 79% of its original customers - from 87% in March.

Mr Russell said suppliers needed 6m-7m customers to be effective competitors to British Gas which has retained 14m gas customers (70% of the market) and attracted 3.5m electricity customers (15%).

webTitle: Job cuts raise storm of protest at Rolls

fields.headline: Job cuts raise storm of protest at Rolls
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce, the engine-maker, yesterday ran into a storm of protest after saying it would axe up to 1,300 jobs under a £150m restructuring programme designed to restore investor confidence.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce, the engine-maker, yesterday ran into a storm of protest after saying it would axe up to 1,300 jobs under a £150m restructuring programme designed to restore investor confidence.

Union leaders accused the firm of kow-towing to the stock market, when a record order book should lead it to create employment, and of threatening up to 3,000 job losses in Derby, Coventry and Bristol over the next three years.

But the group said the re- organisation of its businesses would continue, with further outsourcing of components manufacture likely to lead to more job losses. Around 60% of components are bought in from suppliers.

John Rose, the Rolls chief executive, said the business was being reshaped to "meet market demands" and "the reduction in jobs in 2001 will continue at a rate no greater than in the last year or so."

The group has been shedding around 2,000 posts a year, with its British labour force now down to around 30,000, as it seeks to return to double-digit growth in earnings and dividends.

It shocked investors in August with a 76% fall in pre-tax profits during the first half of the year to just £38m after taking a £120m charge to make its Trent family of aero-engines more environmentally friendly and warning of a further full-year hit.

Rolls said it would concentrate its gas turbine business for the global energy market in Montreal and transfer 600 posts from Ansty, near Coventry, to Canada, where the plant is more modern.

A further 50 posts in the group's naval marine engine business at Ansty will shift to Bristol, now to be the centre of that operation and close to the ministry of defence's Abbey Wood facilities.

Rolls said it was also reviewing 650 posts in operations at Ansty but insisted 550 jobs in aero-repair and overhaul would remain at the plant.

Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU union said:"This is a bitter pill. We will be fighting to save as many jobs as possible and oppose any compulsory redundancies _ There is no need to cut any jobs."

Roger Lyons of the MSF union said Rolls had won £3.7bn of new business in the first half, bringing orders for 2000-2001 to £12.75bn. "Our members are entitled to expect an order book this strong to provide job security." Rolls shares fell 4p to close at 180.5p.

fields.headline: Wetherspoon cheer
fields.trailText: JD Wetherspoon, the pubs group, yesterday gave some cheer to the City when it reported a better-than-expected increase in like-for-like sales in the first 13 weeks of the year.
fields.body:
JD Wetherspoon, the pubs group, yesterday gave some cheer to the City when it reported a better-than-expected increase in like-for-like sales in the first 13 weeks of the year.

They grew 6% on the back of wet but mild weather, a small improvement on the previous quarter and well ahead of chairman Tim Martin's prediction of a 2-5% increase for the full year.

The Wetherspoon founder said he now believed a level of 6% could be maintained over the whole 12 month period "if we run the business well".

But the first sales figures for August to October were down from a level of 18% increase for the same period of 1999. Last night shares in the company finished the day up 9p at 307.5p. Total sales in the first quarter hit £110.3m, up 32% but the figures were flattered by the opening of 20 new pubs including Wetherspoon's first two in northern Ireland, at Belfast and Ballymena. The company plans to open in 100 new locations a year, increasing from its present 450 pubs.

fields.headline: Sidney Salkow
fields.standfirst: First-class master of the second-feature movie
fields.trailText: First-class master of the second-feature movie
fields.body:
Sidney Salkow, who has died aged 89, was the kind of Hollywood director who turned out scores of genre movies and no masterpieces, yet who formed the backbone of the film industry. Most of his pictures were "programmers" - cheaply-produced, fast-paced, 60-minute action features, made to fill the first half of double bills in the 1930s and 1940s. During the 1950s, he directed some solid westerns, generally dismissed, unfairly, as "routine" when they appear in the television listings, but which offer many unexpected pleasures.

Born to Hungarian parents in New York - his father was a tailor for Western Costume, a major film industry outfit ter - Salkow worked as a child actor in the theatre. He attended City College of New York, got a master's degree at Columbia University, and entered Harvard law school. But he was determined to work in show business, and arrived in Hollywood, aged 24, as a screenwriter. He was soon directing featurettes, finding his niche at the recently-formed Republic Pictures, whose output was mainly B-movies.

Between 1938 and 1940, Salkow turned out 11 pictures, ranging from Storm Over Bengal, in which Patrick Knowles, the poor man's Errol Flynn, fought for empire in India, to Girl From God's Country, which had Chester Morris ministering to the medical needs of the Inuit in the frozen north. In 1940, he moved to Columbia Pictures and much better films, starting with four in the entertaining Lone Wolf series, starring Warren William as an elegant jewel thief, with Eric Blore as his valet and partner in crime.

Two years later, Salkow was entrusted to direct two longer features - of more than 80 minutes - starring Glenn Ford, the studio's resident young star. Flight Lieutenant had Ford as the pilot son of Pat O'Brien, an ex-flyer who had caused the death of his co-pilot. The Adventures Of Martin Eden was based on Jack London's tale of a seaman, played by Ford, aboard a "hellship".

Competently handled as these melodramas were, Salkow was back to making programmers the following year, such as The Boy From Stalingrad, a curiosity in which a group of children helped defend a small Russian village against German attack, and City Without Men, set in a boarding house near a prison, where women waited for their husbands.

During the second world war, Salkow rose to the rank of major in the US marines, suffering shrapnel injuries to his back when Japanese planes attacked an aircraft carrier, where he was part of a documentary film unit.

In the 1950s, he made several gripping westerns, among which were three with strong, taciturn George Montgomery: The Pathfinder (1952), based on the James Fenimore Cooper novel, Jack McCall Desperado (1953), and Robber's Roost (1955). The Iron Sheriff (1957) starred Sterling Hayden, who always lent some angst to his roles, and The Quick Gun (1964) featured Audie Murphy. During this time, he also delivered some enjoyable swashbucklers, including The Golden Hawk (1952), with Rhonda Fleming as a pirate, and Prince of Pirates (1953), in which John Derek leapt around with panache.

Towards the end of his career, Salkow directed two horror vehicles for hammy Vincent Price: Twice Told Tales (1963), based on three of Nathaniel Hawthorne's scary stories, and The Last Man on Earth (1964), in which Price is the sole survivor of a global plague, trying to prevent the dead victims claiming his blood.

In the early 1970s, Salkow began teaching film at California State Northridge University. "He really put our film programme together," said a fellow professor. "He mobilised his studio contacts to secure donations for film equipment for the fledgling programme. He taught kids that, if they wanted to succeed in the film industry, they had to meet deadlines. This business is so young- oriented. It was good for him to come and teach because that kept him young."

Salkow is survived by his wife, six children, eight grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

 Sidney Salkow, film and television director, born June 16 1911; died October 18 2000

fields.headline: Eric Morley
fields.standfirst: The man who sustained Miss World in sickness and in health
fields.trailText: Eric Morley, who has died 82, had a genius for publicity, which sometimes blew up in his face. He was the promoter of Mecca dancehalls and BBC television's Come Dancing series, and, most conspicuously, the creator of the Miss World contest - for which he was the object of hostility from feminists who thought the show demeaning to women, and of many other people who thought it merely tacky.
fields.body:
Eric Morley, who has died 82, had a genius for publicity, which sometimes blew up in his face. He was the promoter of Mecca dancehalls and BBC television's Come Dancing series, and, most conspicuously, the creator of the Miss World contest - for which he was the object of hostility from feminists who thought the show demeaning to women, and of many other people who thought it merely tacky.

Morley was a voluble, self-made Cockney with an ability to put people's backs up without consciously trying, and then turn the resultant fracas into publicity. The bureaucrats at Grand Metropolitan Hotels, the conglomerate which took over his Mecca interests and him, tried to bring him into line with its traditional hierarchies, but it was some years before they managed to oust him.

Morley recalled with pride that he had been born in an East End warehouse - or at least to humble parents in Holborn, central London. He was educated at Whitstable grammar school and the royal naval training ship, HMS Exmouth. His father died when he was two and, before he was 12, his mother and stepfather had also died. On Exmouth, he distinguished himself by splitting toffee bars into squares and selling them to fellow trainees. At 14, he became an army boy bandsman, playing the French horn.

Morley claimed later to have been promoted, in the Royal Fusiliers, from private to sergeant in six weeks, and also to have been at Dunkirk. He was undoubtedly in Norway after the war, where he took over - as a lieutenant - when the sports and entertainment officer went sick.

Demobbed in 1946 as Captain Morley, Royal Army Service Corps (Motor Boats), he remembered himself as an acting major. He took charge of publicity at Mecca, then run by Carl Heimann and Alan Fairley. With the BBC, he started Come Dancing in 1949, as a welcome relief from the dowdiness and austerity of the war years.

When he heard that the 1951 Festival of Britain was to feature a beauty contest, Morley saw himself as the ideal man to handle the publicity. He then assumed responsibility for the whole event.

By the following year, he was general manager of Mecca's dancing division, the year after that he was a director, and, in 1954, he joined the board of the parent company, Mecca Ltd. In 1960, he married Julia Rogers, a former model he had met at Mecca's Leeds dancehall and who was to become his righthand woman in running Miss World.

By 1962, Morley was Mecca's joint assistant managing director and, in 1969, he became managing director and a director of Grand Metropolitan Hotels, which took over Mecca the following year. He became joint chairman and managing director of Mecca and, in 1971, sole chairman and managing director.

The number of these "joint" appointments suggested that the view of him as a usefully berserk NCO had adherents within Mecca and Grand Metropolitan; while the appointments of extremely short duration suggested that he did not suffer equals gladly.

B ut Maxwell Joseph, head of Grand Metropolitan - and himself a quiet operator - nevertheless recognised Morley's value sufficiently to allow him to report to him directly, bypassing two accountant deputies. At one stage, he controlled 100 dancehalls and 700 betting shops.

Morley had little respect for accountants, who he saw as incapable of creative leadership in the entertainment field. But he did not bother to disguise that lack of respect, which was his fatal mistake. The staff bonus scheme he devised was certainly not accountant-led, but was understandably popular with the rank and file, as was he. In the early 1970s, his own bonus was put at £100,000, though it was reported that he had waived it.

It was perhaps his uneasiness within the bureaucracy that led him to seek fresh fields. He stood as Conservative candidate for Dulwich in 1974, although Labour's Sam Silkin saw him off, as he did again in 1979. Nonetheless, Morley's Who's Who entry, presumably self-written, declared that he "reduced the majority of the then attorney-general from 7,500 to 122". The national swing may also have had something to do with it.

By 1978, the pressure to unseat him at Mecca and Grand Metropolitan had become explosive. Morley resigned from the Mecca chairmanship and the Grand Metropolitan board with a £200,000 handshake, and the promise that he could run Miss World for another five years. When Grand Met pulled the plug on the BBC's use of Mecca ballrooms for Come Dancing, Morley's wife said it was only because it was her husband who was running it.

The beauty contest was rather more lucky. The 1970 Miss World, compered by Bob Hope at the Royal Albert hall, coincided with the birth of the women's liberation movement, and became the target of feminist protest and flour-bomb attacks. It was a public relations disaster which focused public unease about the event. Yet despite demonstrations and scandals, Miss World tottered on, even when, in 1980, the BBC decided to leave her to the embrace of more commercial arms.

That Who's Who entry emphasised Morley's charitable work - with his wife, he raised more than £100m. It revelled in the size of the Miss World television audience (more than 1.5bn in 115 countries in 1995) and in his introduction of commercial bingo to Britain in 1961. It did not mention his age, any more than his sleek hair was ever allowed to go grey.

Determined, self-hyping, slightly innocent, Morley was a maverick. Julia and four sons survive him. His daughter predeceased him.

webTitle: Let's hear it for action man Brown

fields.headline: Let's hear it for action man Brown
fields.standfirst: Commendable duplicity
fields.trailText: Andrew Dilnot, director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the nation's oracle when it comes to tax and spending, is not much given to hyperbole. So when he says Gordon Brown's package for pensioners amounts to the biggest dose of redistribution in 20 years for a large group of the population his words carry weight.
fields.body:
Andrew Dilnot, director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies and the nation's oracle when it comes to tax and spending, is not much given to hyperbole. So when he says Gordon Brown's package for pensioners amounts to the biggest dose of redistribution in 20 years for a large group of the population his words carry weight.

That the chancellor's largesse was greeted with a cautious welcome by pensioner groups is only to be expected because there was no surrender to their main demand, the restoration of the au tomatic link between the state pension and earnings growth. More interesting, perhaps, is that the other group which might have been expected to sit up and take notice at a big slug of redistribution - the City - could barely stifle its yawns. There was no run on the pound, no rush for the exit by those Harold Wilson dubbed the Gnomes of Zurich.

A cynic might say that Brown has just been plain lucky. A sustained period of growth has meant the public finances are in amazingly good shape, so the financial markets are happy to turn a blind eye to a bit of old-fashioned redistribution. They might be less impressed should a domestic or a global downturn transform the government's hefty surplus into a deficit. In those circumstances, the chancellor's generosity could come back to haunt him.

But let us not be too churlish. If the point of having a Labour government is that help should be given to those who need it most then Brown appears to be doing just that. If the price is that the chancellor has to be Janus-like and sweet talk the markets while he is doing it, then what's wrong with that? It is certainly preferable to promising a lot and delivering nothing.

Partly right

So British Telecom stopped short of a full break-up and opted for a new Labour-esque third way: part flotations of its four business under the umbrella of a new holding company.

Chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield is promising the best aspects of separation with the synergies of sitting inside a single group. But the consensus on a phoney break-up yesterday was "too little too late" and the share price, which BT had hoped to stimulate, simply fell further.

Some of the troubles facing BT are outside its control; others are clearly of its own making.

When Sir Peter Bonfield took control of BT, he notes, only 4% of revenues were from overseas. Yet the rush to make the business into a global player lacked strategy. Most telecoms companies of any size recognised some time ago that minority stakes in a patchwork of companies were not the way forward.

That said, the company does now seem to be showing some humility and getting to grips with its debt, swollen by overstretching itself and the vast cost of third-generation mobile phone licences.

It is easy to offer a knee-jerk reaction and say they should have gone further, yet part flotation has to be a step in the right direction. Exposing the separate divisions to outside investors should galvanise thinking at the four businesses and, at worst, dilute the bureaucratic culture of the parent company.

It also frees them to use their own paper to make acquisitions.

Similarly, scaling back its overseas ambitions by selling off most of its Asian assets makes sense.

But there may be one important dividend for Sir Peter that has nothing to do with the City. He may have found a way of stopping newspapers from dividing annual profits by 525,600, dialling up a per-second earnings shocker. The sly man.

When Lord Sterling first talked about splitting Peninsular & Oriental into cruise and "other" operations there were wild cheers from the City. At last we could stop calling it a conglomerate - a tag that stuck even after businesses such as Bovis Homes were jettisoned.

Demerger promised real focus at a time when cruise stocks were riding high in New York. But no sooner had the break-up decision been made than investors began to fret that the ports and ferries side would be seen as an ugly duckling next to the beautiful cruise swan. The only thing that would keep the stock market interested in the remaining P&O group would be the likelihood of a takeover, some analysts argued.

What has happened since P&O Princess Cruises was floated two weeks ago at 310p? Well, the price has plunged to 252p while the "rump" has soared - with no potential bidder to be seen.

It is unlikely that P&O would have performed better if it had not been demerged. But the timing of the demerger could not have been worse, with tons of new cruise capacity coming into the market. With the bungled float of the bulk shipping arm fresh in the memory, Lord Sterling looks accident-prone.

fields.headline: P&O Princess profits slump
fields.trailText: P&O Princess Cruises, demerged from the rest of P&O a fortnight ago, yesterday saw its shares sink further after admitting like-for-like yields would be down 13% and operating profits reduced to zero in the fourth quarter.
fields.body:
P&O Princess Cruises, demerged from the rest of P&O a fortnight ago, yesterday saw its shares sink further after admitting like-for-like yields would be down 13% and operating profits reduced to zero in the fourth quarter.

The company will be under further pressure because of ticket discounting by competitors, higher fuel prices and a $3m hit from suspending calls to Israel because of the intifada.

Chief executive Peter Ratcliffe said the first quarter of 2001 would also be tough but considerably better than the preceding period. Analyst forecasts of a rise from 40 cents per share this year to 45 cents next year should prove correct "While pricing conditions for the next two quarters are challenging, the market is continuing to grow and the fundamentals of the cruising industry remain sound."

P&O Princess reported pre-tax profits up from $164.7m (£119m) to $175.0m in the third quarter, to September 30, despite taking extra costs of $6m on fuel and $3m on foreign exchange. Passenger cruise days increased by 26% and earnings per share rose 6% to 22.1 cents. Turnover increased from $666.3m to $778.1m.

The shares closed 3p down at 252p as the City continued to fret about the effects of new shipping capacity. Mr Ratcliffe plans a to cut unit costs by 2% a year over the next two years.

webTitle: Letter: Alan Blyth's obituary of  Walter Berry

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: In his obituary of that fine bass-baritone Walter Berry (October 30), Alan Blyth mentions that, while he sang his most celebrated role of Papageno throughout the German- speaking world, he did not sing it in London.
fields.body:
In his obituary of that fine bass-baritone Walter Berry (October 30), Alan Blyth mentions that, while he sang his most celebrated role of Papageno throughout the German- speaking world, he did not sing it in London.

Whilst I am sure Alan Blyth is right that he did not sing it on the stage, Berry did perform the role in a couple of concert performances, on May 1 and 3 1961 at the Royal Festival Hall in London, under the conductor Otto Klemperer with the Philharmonia orchestra.

His Papagena on those oc casions, almost four decades ago, was another famous interpreter of her roles, Lisa Otto. There was also Nicolai Gedda, Agnes Giebel and Ingeborg Hallstein to sing Tamino, Pamina and the Queen of the Night.

With other fine singers in smaller roles, such as Walter Kreppel, Franz Crass, Heather Harper and Hilda Konetzni, there cannot have been many performances of The Magic Flute at London's Covent Garden to match such a truly spectacular cast.

If Alan Blyth missed those performances, I bet he will be kicking himself.

fields.headline: Berlin stands up against racism
fields.standfirst: Up to 200,000 at anti-Nazi rally
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of Berliners crammed the streets of their city yesterday to take a stand against the neo-Nazi violence that has left at least three people dead in Germany this year.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Berliners crammed the streets of their city yesterday to take a stand against the neo-Nazi violence that has left at least three people dead in Germany this year.

On the anniversary of Kristallnacht - the attack on Jewish businesses and property in 1938 which heralded the Holocaust - Chancellor Gerhard Schröder led a vast procession through the darkened streets of the capital from pre-war Berlin's main synagogue to the Brandenburg Gate, a symbol of its militaristic past.

With him walked leading politicians and personalities from the worlds of culture and sport, including tennis legends Boris Becker and Steffi Graf.

The organisers, who had hoped to rally 100,000 people, claimed 200,000 had taken part. Police said "far more than 100,000" had turned up for the demonstration, which was organised to show that, beyond the stories of race-hate murder, there lay "a humane and tolerant Germany, open to the world". Tens of thousands of others joined other demonstrations across the country.

Germany's president, Johannes Rau, told a rally at the Brandenburg Gate that almost 100 people had fallen victim to the neo-Nazis since 1990.

Mr Schröder and his ministers have been working to raise awareness of the problems posed by Germany's extreme right. On Wednesday, the cabinet endorsed a decision by regional administrations to seek a ban on the most radical rightwing party, the National Democratic party of Germany.

"You have to take a stand against racism," said Regina Horst, who works on a youth project in west Berlin. Flavia-Victoria Mai, a philosophy and music student, had come along "to make a symbolic gesture and try to give another picture of Germany".

For months, politicians and commentators have been focused on the prevalence of overt racism, especially in eastern Germany. Underlying their debates has been a growing acceptance that a steep increase in immigration will be necessary to sustain Germany's welfare state and make good a skills gap.

A Turkish woman at the march said she had "lots of good German friends and colleagues". But the woman, who declined to give her name, said she had been forced to put up with daily jibes since arriving 17 years ago. "At the kindergarten where I put my children, there were mothers who said 'We don't want to leave our children here among so many foreign kids'."

The demonstration was to conclude with a performance by the Berlin Staatskapelle orchestra of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, conducted by Daniel Barenboim, an Argentine-born Jew.

Last night's events overflowed with symbolism. Before the march, Mr Schröder attended a service for Germany's Jewish victims at the New Synagogue, which was targeted on Kristallnacht, though saved from the destruction wreaked on Jewish sites elsewhere.

It took place on a day which is also the anniversary of numerous other turning points in Germany's history, including the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. It was on November 9, too, that the doomed Weimar Republic was declared in 1918 and that the Nazis launched their first violent bid for power five years later.

In an interview with the tabloid Bild Zeitung, Mr Schröder yesterday kept up the pressure for a change in attitudes. "We cannot, and we will not, put up with people falling victims to violence because of the colour of their skin, their religion or position in society", he said.

The disabled and homeless are favourite targets for Germany's neo-Nazi skinheads, along with Jews and immigrants.

webTitle: Catholics order Big Mac to go

fields.headline: Catholics order Big Mac to go
fields.trailText: The empire-building of the restaurant chain McDonald's hit a snag in Italy yesterday when a Catholic newspaper declared fast food to be fit only for atheists, or perhaps Lutherans.
fields.body:
The empire-building of the restaurant chain McDonald's hit a snag in Italy yesterday when a Catholic newspaper declared fast food to be fit only for atheists, or perhaps Lutherans.

Munching a Big Mac with fries was the antithesis of receiving communion and should be spurned by Catholics, declared Avvenire.

McDonald's, already bruised from clashes with employees, environmentalists, communists and gourmets, found itself accused of promoting selfishness. "The excommunication of the hamburger," as the newspaper La Repubblica described it.

In a full-page attack, Avvenire denounced eat-and-run habits for lacking the communitarian aspect of sharing: "It is not Catholic. It completely forgets the holiness of food."

The author, Massimo Salani, a lecturer at Pisa's centre for theological studies, said McDonald's was better suited to the Lutheran mentality of an individual relationship between man and God.

Eating food in the fastest possible way, often alone, satisfied only the self, not others, he said. During Mass, Catholics approach the altar to take Eucharist at the same time.

Monsignor Domenico Sigalini, of the CatholicBishops' Conference, endorsed the article but cautioned that fast food was not sinful. "To reduce everything to zero, to eliminate conversation for the sake of speed, is to lose a sense of the family," he said.

A survey for La Repubblica said the average Big Mac in Italy was served within 90 seconds and eaten within 10 minutes.

McDonald's later issued a statement to reassure Catholics. "Fast food does not mean eating quickly, but being served quickly. We serve sandwiches to cater to all religions and nationalities and we adapt to every culture in the world."

Pasta salads and pizza slices have given the chain a local flavour.

When the chain opened its first restaurant near the Spanish Steps in Rome in the mid-80s, gourmets predicted Italians would never succumb.

They were wrong. Hugely popular with families and students, the chain now has 272 outlets and plans to almost double that number in the next two years, bringing Italy closer in line with France and Britain.

Despite its imminent expansion the past few months have been rough for the restaurant group. Riot police were mobilised in October when thousands of demonstrators in 20 cities declared war on the fast-food chain.

Chanting "Better a day of tortellini than 100 days of hamburgers", they vowed to emulate French resistance to the symbol of Americanisation.

Where France has the anti-globalisation protester, farmer José Bové, Italy has Fausto Bertinotti, leader of the Refounded Communists. He told 100,000 protesters last month that he understood why people attacked the restaurants.

The coalition of family-run bars, gourmets, trade unions and environmentalists was galvanised by a spate of walkouts by disgruntled McDonald's staff. Appealing for calm, the centre-left government has promised to draw up a charter of principles to guide the behaviour of multinationals.
