fields.headline: Clarence Myerscough
fields.standfirst: Gifted violinist whose modesty belied his talent
fields.trailText: The violinist Clarence Myerscough, who has died aged 69, was a gifted soloist, a much-respected teacher and a founder member of the Fidelio Quartet. He loved performing and toured extensively, but never gained the recognition he deserved, perhaps through being too self-effacing
fields.body:
The violinist Clarence Myerscough, who has died aged 69, was a gifted soloist, a much-respected teacher and a founder member of the Fidelio Quartet. He loved performing and toured extensively, but never gained the recognition he deserved, perhaps through being too self-effacing. His tone was distinctive, rich and warm, yet with a characteristic lightness and charm, which drew comparisons with Fritz Kreisler.

He was also highly regarded as a chamber musician; in the Fidelio Quartet he played alongside his brother, the viola player Henry Myerscough, cellist Dennis Nesbit and second violinist Charles Meinardi. The ensemble's authoritative recordings included quartets by Benjamin Britten and Michael Tippett.

Myerscough came from an artistic family. His French mother was a painter, as was his grandfather on his mother's side, Ferdinand Marcks, who belonged to the 19th-century Barbizon school of landscape painters. His father, a violinist, studied at the Paris Conservatoire.

Myerscough was born and grew up in Islington, London, in the house where he lived all his life. He began a long association with the Royal Academy of Music at the age of 12, studying there throughout his teens, and, as a senior, learning with Frederick Grinke.

He came to public recognition while he was still at the RAM, winning the all-England violin competition in 1951, and taking second prize in the Carl Flesch international violin competition the following year. In 1953, a French government scholarship took him to the Paris Conservatoire to study with René Benedetti; he came away with the prestigious diploma Premier Nommé a l'Unanimité.

With the Fidelio Quartet, Myerscough recorded Britten's first two string quartets, and the first three of Tippett's, under the composer's direction. Other recordings include Delius's String Quartet and Arriaga's String Quartets Nos 1 and 2. As a soloist, he recorded Alun Hoddinott's Sonata No 1, with pianist Martin Jones.

During 40-odd years as a teacher at King's School, Canterbury, Myerscough became friends with the composer Alan Ridout, whose works for him included the Aubade for violin and orchestra, and Ferdinand The Bull, for violin and narrator, which he recently recorded with the actor Martin Jarvis, for release early next year.

Myerscough was an esteemed, if unorthodox, teacher, and a professor of the Royal Academy from 1964 until his death. He could be fiercely critical of pupils who did not practise, but was profoundly generous with his time with those who worked hard.

His quartet's commitment to new music has been taken to new levels by successor ensembles like the Arditti Quartet, whose leader, Myers- cough's pupil Irvine Arditti, remembers him as "a real character, though not someone who forced you to do things in a certain way. I was able to remain an individual, but learned a lot just by watching him play and seeing the way he did things."

Other pupils included the viola-player Paul Silverthorne and his own violinist daughter, Nadia, who studied with him between the ages of seven and 20, in her teens performing double concertos and chamber music with him in the Far East, Switzerland and France.

The rich fluency which characterised Myerscough's playing in his 40s and 50s never left him, and he continued to give concerts around the world on his rare Maggini instrument. Numerous engagements abroad in recent years included a five-week trip to Peking in 1997, and recitals in Poland in 1998 and 1999.

Last September, he gave a well-received performance of the Tchaikovsky concerto in Canterbury, and plans for the coming year included a tour of Spain with Nadia. He had a real power for communicating with his audiences, so much so that, after he gave a series of recitals at El Escorial near Madrid earlier this year, one young player turned up on his doorstep in London to ask for lessons.

Myerscough had a zest for life, and was equally passionate about everything he did, whether it was performing, teaching or indulging his passion for collecting antiques, which saw him scouring junk shops around the country. He is survived by his wife Marliese, his son, the violin maker and restorer, Lucian Myerscough, and his daughter.

 Clarence Myerscough, violinist, born October 27 1930; died October 8 2000

Numerous engagements abroad in recent years included a five-week trip to Peking in 1997, and recitals in Poland in 1998 and 1999. Last September, he gave a well-received performance of the Tchaikovsky concerto in Canterbury, and plans for the coming year included a tour of Spain with Nadia. He had a real power for communicating with his audiences, so much so that, after he gave a series of recitals at El Escorial near Madrid earlier this year, one young player turned up on his doorstep in London to ask for lessons. Myerscough had a zest for life, and was equally passionate about everything he did, whether it was performing, teaching or indulging his passion for collecting antiques, which saw him scouring junk shops around the country. He is survived by his wife Marliese, his son, the violin maker and restorer, Lucian Myerscough, and his daughter.  Clarence Myerscough, violinist, born October 27 1930; died October 8 2000

fields.headline: One strike and he's out
fields.standfirst:
The courts say Mr Howard was wrong

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The courts say Mr Howard was wrong.
fields.body:
The ugliest criminal justice act in the last 50 years was yesterday duly amended. The sentencing bill Michael Howard introduced to boost his party's chances of winning the 1997 election was even tougher than the practice of the toughest American states. Instead of three strikes and you're out, Mr Howard introduced a "two strikes" rule. Anyone found guilty of a second serious offence, unless there were "exceptional circumstances", would have to be given a life sentence.

The country's most senior judges, leading criminal justice officials, Liberal Democrats and even a succession of former Conservative home office ministers now in the Lords all contested what he was doing. A special debate called before Lord Taylor, the seriously ill lord chief justice, retired in 1996 sealed Mr Howard's reputation as the worst home secretary since Henry Brooke 40 years earlier. The predictions of injustice made then were confirmed in the cases reviewed yesterday, including that of an immature 36-year-old, possibly with a learning disability, who held up a building society with a toy gun, but had the £800 he snatched taken from him by a woman customer. He had to be given a life sentence under Mr Howard's law. But the incorporation of the European convention on human rights into English law in October made the Howard act reviewable. The appeal court ruled yesterday that the judges should have taken into account the level of public risk posed by the man. It cut his life sentence to the three years he has already served.

The court had two options: to rule the Howard act in breach of human rights, which would have required a reluctant Labour government to produce something different; or to amend the act through interpretation. Wisely, it chose the second. By reducing the risk of blatant injustice, the court will have increased public support for the criminal justice system - a consideration which Mr Howard should never have ignored.

webTitle: Comment: Martin Woollacott on US elections

fields.headline: America's empire may be invisible, but it's still there
fields.standfirst:
Race for the White House

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: At the beginning of the 20th century, prescient Americans wondered what was to become of the British empire, the contradictions and weaknesses of which seemed evident to them just as they were acquiring their own first imperial possessions.
fields.body:
At the beginning of the 20th century, prescient Americans wondered what was to become of the British empire, the contradictions and weaknesses of which seemed evident to them just as they were acquiring their own first imperial possessions. It is a question which could now be raised with equal or greater force about the American empire which presidents inherit just as surely as they do the west wing, that extraordinary network, as Arthur Schlesinger Jr once put it, of "troops, ships, planes, bases, proconsuls, local collaborators, all spread wide around the luckless planet".

This garrisoning of the world has become so familiar that it is barely noticed, at least by Americans, until some dramatic incident - a rape in Okinawa, an American aircraft cutting a cable-car wire at an Italian ski resort, or an attack on a US destroyer in a Yemen port - reminds us that it is there. Or, others would say, until it is needed, as it was in the Gulf or in Bosnia. What this empire is for, whether it is a force on balance for good or ill, or for what admixture of the two, whether the world could manage without it, and whether, in any case, it is sustainable these are issues which could be before America and the rest of us sooner than expected. They intertwine with more familiar issues like intervention, but are not the same. Those concern choices in the abstract, but empire is a tangible structure of people and plant, and also a history of many things done over the years, with precedents and consequences reaching into the future.

Opposition to American empire, or to American predominance, for those who prefer to avoid the word "empire", does not go unremarked. But because it is usually slotted into particular pigeonholes, ranging from "terrorism" at one extreme to "differences of policy" at the other, the cumulative strength of that opposition may be underestimated. Those who oppose the American empire do so with varying degrees of anger. But even those who run it are troubled. Admiral Dennis Blair, until recently one of the four American military proconsuls who, as regional commanders in chief, divide up the world between them, told a Washington Post writer: "What's the US going to do with its superpowerhood? It drives me crazy. We're looking at our wake instead of looking ahead."

Blair's own position is indicative of how haphazardly American power evolves. The regional commanders in chief jobs were created, after some notable blunders, to ensure effective joint operations by the American services, but now underpin a quasi-independent military diplomacy in which American soldiers cultivate special relationships with governments and armed forces in "their" areas. These military chiefs, with large staffs and a budget which has grown like Topsy, certainly moderate policy and sometimes make it. They do so sometimes in opposition to elements in both the Pentagon and the State Department, and they have also sometimes taken a more liberal line on particular issues. It recalls the rivalries and "rings" of British imperial days, and is perhaps to be expected: where else but in an empire would empire building flourish ?

A degree of incoherence arising from the existence of different power centres has always been evident in American foreign policy, but it may have got worse under Clinton, with Congress exerting greater influence as it reclaims its rights, as legislators see things, in international affairs. But, for critics and defenders of American empire alike, it is less the incoherence than the fragility of the structure that is the most obvious characteristic. Paul Kennedy identified the problem of "overstretch" many years ago in The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers. That book's cogent analysis of America's imperial problems was at first embraced, and then rather forgotten as the end of the cold war seemed to leave the US in a position of unprecedented strength. But, under Clinton, it has become clearer that America's empire has enormous reach but only limited punch.

Militarily, it often seems perverse, favouring military solutions when they are wrong or inappropriate, but tending to duck them on the few occasions when they are required. Protection from communist threats no longer figures on the balance sheet for most countries. Yet the costs of the worldwide military presence are high and attempts to extract some of those costs from supposed beneficiaries - by way of payments for troops, by way of arms sales, by way of market advantages for the US - are frequently resented. The economic benefits that the American relationship was supposed to bring may always have owed more to local efforts than to American policy, and, after the Asian economic crisis, look far less certain.

Politically, America's help in establishing or restoring democracy has been real enough in some places and at some times, yet often the reverse has been true. The big Asian democratic breakthroughs in South Korea, the Philippines, Thailand, and Indonesia, for instance, came after years of US support of the undemocratic or quasi-democratic regimes that had gone before.

The Japanese expert Chalmers Johnson, now a professor at the University of California, is the author of a comprehensive recent attack on American empire. His thesis, bolstered by his view that the Asian economic crisis was largely America's fault, is that America has been storing up trouble for itself - in particular in Asia. He calls this "blowback", a term which the Central Intelligence Agency first coined to describe the unintended consequences of American policies and activities, often covert ones. Blowback can be anything from a terrorist operation to a sudden refusal, after years of compliance, to go along with American requirements. It links both elite and popular resentments. "The United States," he writes, "now faces an agenda of problems that simply would not exist except for the imperial commitments and activities, open and covert, that accompanied the cold war." It has added to those problems, he further argues, by some of its policies in the post-cold war years.

Blowback has a nice dramatic touch, but seems too catchall a category to explain as much as Johnson wants it to. His argument that the US should simply dismantle its empire has to be set beside Schlesinger's weary wisdom, which is that something like empire will always exist wherever there are stronger and weaker nations. Among those who do not wish to simply tear down the structures of American power, most have some attachment to it. That is because it is familiar, because they have seen it used for good as well as ill, and because nobody knows what life would be like without it. But the defects of a system that has never been rationally examined are obvious, and a thoroughgoing debate about the purpose of empire is overdue, both inside and outside America.

Blowback by Chalmers Johnson is published by Little, Brown and Company .

webTitle: Leader: the sinking of the dome

fields.headline: The sinking of the dome
fields.standfirst:
One amazing sequence of blunders

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: One amazing sequence of blunders.
fields.body:
It is the most popular pay-to-visit attraction in the UK, with satisfaction ratings among the highest in the industry. It was built on time and housed within an acclaimed structure. But that is about it. The report by the national audit office on the Millennium Dome is one of the most damning indictments of a government-led project in recent memory. It defies belief that many of the standard criticisms of big projects - like the failure to put in proper management, gross overestimation of ticket sales and financial naivety on a grand scale - should loom so large in the NAO's report.

Having spent £628m of lottery money, £229m more than forecast, the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC) had hardly anything left for marketing. It was mainly left to word of mouth and free media publicity. The trouble was that when the dome got a bad press, sales inquiries dropped by 30% and to 50% the following week. And once the dome became symbolically linked with New Labour, the bad mouthing from the Conservatives and the tabloids ensured that the going would be tough.

Clearly, as even Tony Blair has admitted, if the inherent instability of the project had been known when the decision was taken in cabinet to proceed (in June 1997), then it should not have gone ahead - though even then it was so advanced in planning that to have cancelled it would have cost £200m. Fatally, the content never remotely lived up to massaged political expectations that it would be the experience of the century. Yes, the vast majority of visitors enjoyed it: viewed as an enjoyable day out for £20, it was, and is, good value for money. But that was not why it was built. It was meant to lift the nation's spirits - while helping to carry New Labour to election victory.

Inevitably, there have been calls for heads to roll, even though some - those of Jennie Page, the original chief executive and Robert Ayling, the chairman - have done so already. The Conservatives, though they want to forget it, put the show on the road. The cabinet, the prime minister and Peter Mandelson, his first "dome secretary", are ultimately responsible for authorising it and not taking remedial action. Lord Falconer, its present custodian, cannot be blamed for what happened before, but has patently not been able to do much about it and did not come clean about the seriousness of the financial situation. He is one of many tarred by the millennium experience.

fields.headline: Girls given sporting chance
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Forty percent of girls drop out of school sports lessons by the time they are teenagers because they do not like wearing frumpy PE kit, showering communally and having to take part in competitive games.
fields.body:
Forty percent of girls drop out of school sports lessons by the time they are teenagers because they do not like wearing frumpy PE kit, showering communally and having to take part in competitive games.

Speaking at the start of a nationwide campaign yesterday to encourage girls to take part in sport, researchers claimed that schools needed to develop alternative teaching methods in PE lessons to combat the high drop out rate among teenage girls.

The Girls in Sport campaign, which has been launched by the sportswear firm Nike and the Youth Sports Trust, a sports charity, is backed by the government and aims to make PE teachers more aware of how they can make sport attractive to girls.

Following a two year pilot study in 74 secondary schools around the country, research has found that allowing girls to shower privately and giving them permission to wear fashionable tracksuits increased their participation in sports lessons.

Many girls, it was found, had a negative body image and dropped out of PE lessons because they did not want to shower with other girls. Others were put off by having to wear traditional gym skirts, which they considered unfashionable.

Non-competitive individual sports, such as trampolining and aerobics were also more attractive to girls.

In some schools where these changes were implemented, the high drop out rate in PE lessons among teenage girls was almost halved. Research also showed that participation in sport benefited not only the health of pupils but also their academic performance.

webTitle: Toulouse-Lautrec portrait of Oscar Wilde resurfaces

fields.headline: Toulouse-Lautrec portrait of Oscar Wilde resurfaces
fields.trailText: A portrait of Oscar Wilde by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, painted on the night before the writer's life collapsed into ashes, has resurfaced after half a century, anonymously loaned to a British Library exhibition to mark the centenary of Wilde's death.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A portrait of Oscar Wilde by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, painted on the night before the writer's life collapsed into ashes, has resurfaced after half a century, anonymously loaned to a British Library exhibition to mark the centenary of Wilde's death.

The watercolour, estimated to be worth at least £1m, was believed lost half a century ago. It was delivered under tight security to the library on Wednesday night. The owner, a continental collector, has loaned it on condition that not even his country of residence is identified.

Sally Brown, curator of the exhibition, had learned through another Wilde collector that the picture had survived and might be made available.

In the exhibition, which opens today, are many other discoveries, including a trial transcript which had been unknown to scholars - again a very private loan.

Toulouse-Lautrec had befriended Wilde in Paris and had drawn him several times. He was in London on the night before Wilde's trial for gross indecency in May 1895, and asked to make another portrait.

They met, but Wilde, who knew he was facing ruin but had refused the pleas of friends and family to flee to the continent, was too nervous to sit. Toulouse-Lautrec went back to his hotel room and drew from memory the haggard anxiety and premature ageing of a man still only 41.

He added the background sketch of the houses of parliament to locate the portrait in London, but it was a prophetic touch: in the trial Wilde was asked about the location of a male brothel in Westminster. It was, he told the court, near the House of Commons.

fields.headline: Exclusion penalty for secondaries
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Secondary schools that expel unruly 14 or 15-year-old pupils are being penalised in annual performance tables, the government has confirmed, a change condemned by teaching unions.
fields.body:
Secondary schools that expel unruly 14 or 15-year-old pupils are being penalised in annual performance tables, the government has confirmed, a change condemned by teaching unions.

Overall GCSE performances will be depressed because of a new rule that schools retain any excluded pupils on the roll, but lose the benefit of any exam results, affecting not only pupils' average scores, but also the benchmark of the percentage achieving five or more good GCSEs. A school accepting an expelled pupil will get the benefit of any exam results.

Tables ranking secondaries and local education authorities according to this summer's GCSE results will be published by the education department next Thursday, and are keenly awaited by schools and parents alike.

Also for the first time, adjustments have been made so primary and secondary schools accepting large numbers of refugee children who speak little or no English are not penalised. Primary tables will be published next month.

This year 1,546 secondaries excluded 3,006 pupils in the age group. Nigel de Gruchy of the National Association for Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said of the change: "It's wholly corrupt system, another example of how league tables can distort the education process."

John Dunford of the Secondary Heads Association said it was "a complete nonsense".

 Hackney council in east London has appointed Alan Wood as director of education. The acting director of Lambeth starts in the new year. Graham Badman, chief officer for Oxfordshire, will cover when Hackney's current director, Elizabeth Reid, leaves at the end of the month.

webTitle: Leader: Gore should hold out for a rerun

fields.headline: Fight the Florida fix
fields.standfirst:
Mr Gore should hold out for a rerun

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Mr Gore should hold out for a rerun.
fields.body:
The fraudulent shambles otherwise known as Florida's presidential poll is an affront to American democracy that must be urgently and scrupulously addressed. With an estimated 24,000 ballots in question after Tuesday's election and amid proliferating allegations of lost-on-purpose ballot boxes, bamboozled voters and disenfranchised minorities, the recount due to be completed last night cannot be the end of the matter.

Apart from the unresolved issues of whether or not there was deliberate malpractice in a state governed by Jeb Bush, brother of the Republican candidate, George W Bush, there is also the matter of absentee ballots cast by Floridians living in other parts of the US or abroad. The margin separating Mr Bush from the Democrat, Al Gore, while fluctuating, was a mere 795 votes at one point last evening, in Mr Bush's favour. With such a slim margin, with so many imponderables and so much at stake, all proper measures must be taken to restore shattered confidence in Florida's and America's electoral process.

Some individuals in Palm Beach county, scene of the most egregious irregularities, have already begun to file private lawsuits challenging the outcome. Mr Gore would also be fully justified in these extraordinary circumstances in lending his name to a formal legal challenge demanding that a rerun be held in in Palm Beach. Despite much brouhaha about the contradiction between Mr Bush's supposed victory in the electoral college and Mr Gore's triumph in the popular vote, the central issue here is not one of good or bad constitutional arrangements but of possible wilful fraud and/or gross incompetence.

The US is expected to set an example and a standard of legitimacy for others to follow. webTitle: UK gives extra £25m to fight Aids

fields.headline: UK gives extra £25m to fight Aids
fields.trailText: Britain is to increase spending on the fight against HIV and Aids in the developing world by nearly 45% this year.
fields.body:
Britain is to increase spending on the fight against HIV and Aids in the developing world by nearly 45% this year.

The extra £25m is to address a "contraception crisis" and reduce alarming numbers of unwanted pregnancies and pregnancy related deaths, according to Clare Short, international development secretary.

The one off payment, on top of the £55m budgeted by Ms Short's department for spending on reproductive health, will be channeled through the UN population fund, which says a serious decline in support from donor countries is threatening availability of condoms and other contraceptives.

Use of contraceptives worldwide in the past 35 years has risen from 10% of couples to 60%. In countries badly hit by HIV/Aids, the UN fund expects a further 40% increase in 15 years.

About 34m people worldwide are living with HIV. Pregnancies in the developing world are believed to cause the death of 600,000 women a year.

webTitle: An aspirin a day poses health risk

fields.headline: An aspirin a day poses health risk
fields.trailText: Millions of people who take aspirin regularly to help stave off heart disease or strokes may be doing themselves more harm than good, researchers warn.
fields.body:
Millions of people who take aspirin regularly to help stave off heart disease or strokes may be doing themselves more harm than good, researchers warn.

Many over-50s who take the drug because of "granny's example" rather than their GP's advice, are nearly doubling their chances of suffering from ulcers and internal bleeding, which can lead to death, according to an analysis of 24 studies on aspirin involving 66,000 patients.

Even low doses over long periods can cause such serious damage that patients need to consider closely the trade-off between the possible benefits and harms, say Yoon Kong Loke and Sheena Derry, of the Radcliffe infirmary, Oxford, in the British Medical Journal.

They found that "about one in 100 patients taking aspirin over a 28 month period will experience a gastrointestinal haemorrhage. No evidence exists that dose reduction or the use of modified release formulations significantly lowers the risk." Their analysis of all studies over longer periods suggested that bleeding occurred in 2.5% of patients taking aspirin compared with 1.4% who were not.

Men over 50 and women after the menopause are frequently advised to take aspirin, which thins the blood, reducing the chances of thrombosis. But thinning the blood also increases the chances of bleeding.

Over the past 10 years doses recommended for such preventative therapy have been reduced from about 300mg a day to 75mg, while short treatments for headaches can involve 600mg to 900mg.

Martin Tranter, an anaesthetist at the Geneva University hospitals, Switzerland, in an editorial in the journal, says the message of the new paper was "there is no gain without pain" and "it may be more appropriate for some to eat an apple rather than an aspirin a day."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: When Harry Met Sally | Barbarella | Scanners | A Short Film About Killing
fields.body:
When Harry Met Sally

(Rob Reiner, 1989)

9.15am, Carlton Cinema

Despite the screen's most celebrated orgasm - which Sally (Meg Ryan) demonstrates to Harry (Billy Crystal) in a busy cafe - there's something of an old-fashioned feel to Reiner's romantic comedy. It's sparky, funny and light of touch; and so is the acting. There's a nice story, as well: the couple meet intermittently over 12 years, showing that, yes, it is possible for a man and a woman to have a good platonic relationship. Then, of course, they shrug their shoulders and jump into bed together.

Barbarella

(Roger Vadim, 1967)

This is a camp adult fantasy of a movie, with 40th-century space beauty Jane Fonda travelling to distant worlds in an attempt to recover the deadly positronic ray. Along the way she has a sexual encounter with David Hemmings, gets tortured by an evil Anita Pallenberg (who has the voice of Fenella Fielding) and ultimately proves her immorality by failing to die of pleasure.

Scanners

(David Cronenberg, 1980)

10pm, FilmFour

This blackly comic sci-fi tale has a high yuk-factor, with a bunch of telepathic warriors who can explode minds in colourful detail (oh, see those veins pop!) David Cronenberg conjures a sinister, menacing world, and then heads helter-skelter towards an apocalyptic final confrontation. Stephen Lack, Patrick McGoohan and Michael Ironside are the thinking man's terminators.

A Short Film About Killing
(Krzysztof Kieslowski, 1987)

1.50am, FilmFour

In a grim, grey Warsaw a young man murders a taxi driver and is in turn executed by the state. Both killings are ugly and brutal acts, and both are shown in dispassionate detail. Extended from an episode in director Krzysztof Kieslowski's television film series, Decalogue, which is based on the ten commandments, this is an extraordinarily powerful and bleak vision, and it was highly effective too - as a result of the film the Polish government actually introduced a five-year moratorium on capital punishment.

webTitle: Help for poorest pensioners 'most generous for 20 years'

fields.headline: Help for poorest pensioners 'most generous for 20 years'
fields.standfirst:
Think tank praises size of package
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's package to boost the incomes of poor pensioners was yesterday hailed by a leading independent think tank as one of the most generous redistributive measures for 20 years.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's package to boost the incomes of poor pensioners was yesterday hailed by a leading independent think tank as one of the most generous redistributive measures for 20 years.

Andrew Dilnot, head of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, said: "These are very, very substantial changes. It really is a dramatic change... I can't think of any economic measure giving such a large group of the population gains on this scale in 20 years of tax and benefits policy."

To quell anger over last year's 75p a week rise in the state pension, the chancellor unveiled concessions to the elderly worth a total of £2.6bn. While refusing to bow to calls for restoration of the link between the state pension and earnings, Mr Brown announced an above-inflation rise in the state pension from next April which will be worth £5 to single pensioners and £8 to couples, with a further increase of £3 and £4.80 the following year.

On top of these rises, he also increased this winter's fuel allowance from £150 to £200 and gave a major boost to the incomes of poor pensioners by increasing the minimum income guarantee - the government's top up to the state pension - from £78.45 to £92.15, and to £140.55 for couples. Mr Dilnot said the overall impact of the package was to boost the household incomes of the poorest pensioners by over 8% next year and by more in future years, a truly enormous increase. "That's a key part of what this government has done to the redistribution of income in this country and it will be important and interesting over the next few years to see what it does to the lifestyles of pensioners.

"If something like this does not impact on their diet and heating then I think we can be pretty sure that redistribution through money is not the way forward."

The IFS's analysis takes no account of the extra cash to be channelled to pensioners through the government's new pensioner credit, designed to help those with small occupational pensions who at the moment get no help beyond the basic state pension. Mr Dilnot said he had reservations about the perverse retirement incentives it might introduce to the tax and benefits system.

On the concessions made to hauliers, farmers and motorists, the IFS estimated that most of the gains from cutting duty on clean fuel would go to the rural rich. Rural households in the top 40% of the distribution of income see their budgets boosted by around 0.3%. By contrast, poor urban households gain less than 0.1%. However, the poor benefit disproportionately from proposed reductions in vehicle excise duty for cars with smaller engines. The poorest 10% of the urban population will gain just over 0.1% of household income while the poorest 10% of the rural population will be over 0.3% better off.

The IFS's Zoe Smith said vehicle excise duty changes might encourage people to switch to smaller, cleaner cars but the incentive was small in comparison to the cost of buying a car. Mr Brown's measures essentially made motoring cheaper which would harm the environment, she said.

Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the King Pot Noodle ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the King Pot Noodle ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
A bloke is in a bar with his giant Afro-haired mate, finishing up a pint. "Come on Big Dave, let's get some tuck." We realise that silent Big Dave is his imaginary friend, whom only he can see. They go to a shop and buy a huge King Pot Noodle snack, and our bloke reassures the shopkeeper it's not all for him. "Big Dave's sharing it," he says, pointing to thin air. We then cut to the bloke's kitchen, where he's finishing off the noodley snack just as his girlfriend walks in. "A whole King Pot Noodle? You fat bloater," she says, ignoring his claims that Big Dave had some too. She turns to leave, asking him saucily if he's coming to bed. With which Big Dave gets up in hot pursuit.

The jargon:
This ad is aimed at launching the new, larger Pot Noodle "for the heartier appetite". Apparently research shows that a huge section of Pot Noodle fans are never satisfied by the size of the existing snack, so they've brought out the King Pot Noodle (in the two top favourite flavours: chicken and mushroom; beef and tomato), which is over one third bigger.

Personality:
You're an 18-34-year-old male who goes out a lot, likes his pints and generally comes home starving. Over 50 per cent of Pot Noodles are consumed by women, but the agency HHCL says that this is aimed more at fellas because "it's a bigger eat".

Financial status:
The "snack" only costs 99p, so you can fill yourself up for under a pound.

Telling lifestyle detail:
Chances are you're a student (Pot Noodles are extremely popular in student circles). You also probably don't have a very well-equipped kitchen - all you need to "cook" these things is a kettle.

Other relevant data:
The two actors were apparently cast because they have small hands, thus emphasising the giant size of the King Pot Noodle. And Big Dave's not that big either - it's just that the other bloke is really small.

webTitle: Ministers warned £200m changes may confuse old 'maze'

fields.headline: Ministers warned £200m changes may confuse old 'maze'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Nearly 9m pensioners and 350,000 disabled people and their carers will benefit from £200m worth of changes to the tax and benefit system announced by the government yesterday, despite what critics condemned as their "Hampton Court Maze" of complexity.
fields.body:
Nearly 9m pensioners and 350,000 disabled people and their carers will benefit from £200m worth of changes to the tax and benefit system announced by the government yesterday, despite what critics condemned as their "Hampton Court Maze" of complexity.

Twenty four hours after Gordon Brown's pre-budget report, his cabinet colleague, the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, put the flesh on details of the chancellor's plans to increase pensions substantially ahead of the coming general election.

His statement was welcomed by pensioner groups and even by David Willetts, the Tory spokesman. But they joined forces to warn that what Age Concern called "good intentions" are threatened by over-complexity which daunts the elderly - what Mr Willetts dubbed a "Hampton Court Maze". Yesterday Mr Darling's main target was to rectify "the fundamental flaw in the system" by rewarding modest savings. That will help "nearly poor" pensioners, those who have small occupational pensions, enough to take them above the minium income guarantee (MIG), but not enough to make them comfortable.

At present a pensioner with an occupational pension worth £20 a week on top of the state pension - up by £5 to £72.50 next April - could find him herself just £1 or £2 better off than someone who has not saved at all.

As expected, Mr Darling confirmed that most national insurance benefits will rise by 3.3% in line with inflation from next April, income-related ones by 1.6%. But he won cheers from relieved Labour MPs when he targeted a range of needy claimants who will get more - rises in line with earnings in some cases.

Mr Brown this week promised "transitional" arrangements which will see single pensioners get £8 a week extra over two years, £12.40 for a couple, until the introduction - in 2003 - of the pensioner credit, designed to help those with modest savings or personal pensions.

The example offered by ministers yesterday states that for every pound saved, a pensioner would receive an additional cash credit. "This will mean extra cash on top of the basic state pension - sums of between £1 and £23 a week," Mr Darling said. With an occupational pension worth £20 a week, the credit would leave a pensioner £15 a week better off.

Among other significant changes capital limits (people's savings, not the income from them) will be raised for the first time in 10 years from next April - from £3-8,000 to £6-12,000 - and scrapped entirely from 2003.
The speech in full
Part 1: the economy
Part 2: the fiscal stance
Part 3: families and pensioners

fields.headline: Education, training, training
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor's pre-Budget report was accompanied by a Treasury document which emphasises the importance of productivity

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: The public spending announcement this week with most significance for the country's future was not the chancellor on pensions - politically nifty though that was. It came instead from Education Secretary David Blunkett and referred to those shadowlands, out of the public's sight, where most of the nation's young people acquire skills or not, as is too often the case.
fields.body:
The public spending announcement this week with most significance for the country's future was not the chancellor on pensions - politically nifty though that was. It came instead from Education Secretary David Blunkett and referred to those shadowlands, out of the public's sight, where most of the nation's young people acquire skills or not, as is too often the case.

Mr Blunkett upped, by £600m to £5.5bn, the annual budget of the learning and skills council due next April to take over from the Tories' training and enterprise councils. In fact it will not be much different. It too will deploy business folk on local committees answerable to a national council, charged with spending public money across the field of post-16 education (including school sixth forms). Its mission is a typical New Labour mix of aspiration (fulfilling the potential of young people who might otherwise lose out) and economic functionalism.

Just why further and vocational education are so important is spelled out in a Treasury document published with the pre-budget report*. It is productivity. Other countries extract more from their people - 45% more per head in the US, 18% in France, 11% in Germany. "If the UK were to match the productivity performance of the US," Gordon Brown told industrialists this week, "output per head would be over £6,000 higher." Enough to buy a small, low-sulphur petrol guzzling motorcar each.

Back in the mists of time when Labour was last in power, workers' capacity to produce was held to be something governments could do something about. There was even a Whitehall department called "employment and productivity"; Harold Wilson's memoirs are spattered with references to raising the nation's skills. Largely a dead duck under the Tories, productivity has been enjoying a renaissance in official circles.

The intellectual underpinning is - this is the phrase that got Mr Brown into trouble for pretentiousness when he first uttered it - endogenous growth theory. In this post-socialist world, it says, the state cannot do with the private enterprise economy. It must squeeze into a fiscal corset, keep its hands off interest rates and make sure markets are competitive... not much beyond that except maybe education.

The trouble is no one is quite sure whether there is any stable relationship between state spending on schools and colleges (increasing by 5.4% a year in real terms between this year and 2003-4) and economic achievement. What we do know is that the Germans did well in the era of manufacturing thanks to their strong tradition of apprenticeship and vocational training.

And the Americans seem to have a good training formula for the hi-tech age. Look at the chart. The US has only limited numbers of workers with German-style "intermediate" skills but American productivity has lately been up, up and away. That is, it seems, down to an American propensity to innovate as well, of course, as having more productive machines and equipment.

The vast size of American universities ensures there are more Americans with degrees but also, oddly, large numbers lacking skills. Despite the lack of hard and fast associations between skills and success, some are passionate believers that the state must do more. DeAnne Julius, an industrial economist and member of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee, calls workforce skills "the biggest microeconomic challenge we face".

Some of her purist colleagues might dispute the collectivist language - decisions about training, they say, are down to individuals and their employers; the state's past efforts at matching people and jobs have not been successful. Labour half accepts that. Its experimental "individual learning accounts" let school leavers choose where they spend their £150 grant. The University for Industry, on the go from next year, is meant to utilise the internet and a string of local access points to help unemployed people gain certs and skills online.

Productivity also depends on how well companies tool themselves up. Mr Brown has been a devotee of tax credits, especially for internet- related investments by smaller enterprises. This week he added further bells and whistles to a tax code looking, say critics, more and more like a Christmas tree.

Official theory says the state can make markets work better. Liberal economists dispute that, saying government should stand back from the labour market and let firms employ (and fire) whom they want, when they want. Apart from the fact the Germans and French manage high levels of productivity amid a highly regulated labour market, beating workers into submission does not sound a civilised mission for a left-centre government.

The Treasury paper is noteworthy in its succinct summary of this government's economic beliefs - "Brownism" you might say. It proffers a long list of measures to enhance competitiveness, handmaiden of productivity. Capital markets work better because corporation and capital gains tax have been lightened and investors been bribed to be more "enterprising"; the banks have been threatened via the Cruickshank inquiry. Yet it is all curiously tentative, as if Labour were riding a beast without much confidence in the reins. Brownism amounts to a curious amalgam of bribery and cajolery with only a hint of a mailed fist in the chancellor's glove. And more subsidised skills training.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Performance On 3 | The Admiral Of The Night
fields.body:
The BBC Symphony Orchestra starts a three-day celebration of the Aaron Copland centenary. This live Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) comes from the Barbican Centre in London, where Marc-André Hamelin is the soloist in the Piano Concerto and Piano Variations. Strangely, we also hear Britain's first-ever concert performance of Copland's Oscar-winning score for the 1948 film The Heiress. The evening ends with the composer's most popular orchestral work, Billy The Kid.

An extraordinary text by Peter Tinniswood and stunning performance from David Bradley make The Admiral Of The Night (9.0pm, Radio 4) one of the season's really memorable dramas. Mr Derbyshire daily recalls, from his bed in an old people's home, his stint with a Pals' Battalion on the Somme. When they went over the top in July 1916, 789 of his friends died within 10 minutes. And now they expect him to attend the home's Remembrance Day dinner.

fields.headline: Travel sickness
fields.trailText: Airport | Horizon
fields.body:
Look at the viewing figures for the last 12 months and you'll see programmes like Airport, Vets In Practice and Garages From Hell regularly scoring 10 million or more viewers. Fly on the wall may be the most discredited form of television, and has surely been eclipsed by the wider ambitions of Castaway 2000 and Big Brother, but that's not to say that those same 10 million people didn't switch on for the new, fifth series of Airport (BBC1) last night

Jeremy Spake is a distant, glittering memory now, and it says much about the new series that one almost began to think fondly of his wit and repartee. (Please note: only almost. Not actually.) The new cast of characters were presented during the opening credits in a way that was strangely reminiscent of The New Avengers but, sadly (for all 10 million of us), John, Karen and Stuart ain't no Steed, Purdey and Gambit.

John, the QANTAS duty manager at Heathrow, had to find the Irish Olympic team, who were lost somewhere en route to Canberra. Dapper John/Steed had short cropped grey hair, a neatly trimmed moustache and bags of personality; little wonder that he went into the airport business. He smoothed furrowed brows, he had a cheery word for every passenger, and he even managed to find a lost passport. In short, he was a model of positive thinking, as is anyone who can retain a shred of common humanity in an airport. But even John couldn't quite get bubbly over the good luck cake that had been baked specially for the squad. "Oh," he said, peering at some nasty-looking icing in a box, "that's quite good." Fortunately there was a junior QANTAS employee dressed as a koala bear to distract our attention.

Meanwhile, Stuart/Gambit was chasing across the tarmac in pursuit of an escaped dog, and Karen/Purdey was striding purposefully around in search of a non-existent fire. The camera crew gamely tried to inject drama into the situation with a bit of Blair Witch Project shaky hand-held filming, but ultimately no end of technique can mask the fact that a faulty fire alarm and an upset dog aren't very exciting.

You've got to admire the Airport team for their tenacity. They must know, surely, that every last drop of novelty has been squeezed out of the format. But while the show continues to deliver ratings, they will be forced to spend more months buzzing between terminals in search of elusive character and incident. Was there a note of self-parody creeping into John Nettles' voice-over? "A pet on on the runway is a serious matter," he declaimed. And later: "But Gordon's got two bags. The search goes on." The next-week trailers promised even less. Didn't these people ever watch That Peter Kay Thing, Channel 4's spoof documentary at the start of the year? If they did, one can only marvel at the thickness of their skins.

Another returning series delivered something truly gripping, beautiful and infuriating. Horizon (BBC2) reopened with The Secret Treasures 0f Zeugma, a heartbreaking film about the discovery and subsequent loss of substantial ancient ruins in eastern Turkey. Archaeologists have been pottering about on the banks of the Euphrates for years, gently exploring the Graeco-Roman city of Zeugma, which was once an important trading point on the Silk Road and a substantial, wealthy community. Just as they were about to hit gold in 1999, the Turkish government announced that they had only six weeks before the entire valley was to be flooded by a brand new hydroelectric dam.

Archaeological etiquette flew out of the window as time began running out; digging that should have been done with trowel and brush was gouged out by massive earth-shifting plants. Treasures came up with every shovelful, then frescoes emerged, and then, finally, what they'd all been looking for: mosaics. "An absolute masterpiece," gasped one of the team, gazing wet-eyed on a huge floor depicting the legend of Pasiphae. "We are in the presence of a great artist." More and more was revealed, each floor more beautiful than the last. The team raced against time to lift the mosaics and cart them off to the local museum, but the Turkish government was inflexible, and in June the valley was submerged. A displaced population of 30,000 was added to Turkey's homeless hordes - and the still-hidden treasures in scores of undiscovered villas were lost for ever.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
A walk along the banks of Upper Coquetdale brings us to a mass of little streams, all flowing into the main water. From Coquet Head, on a clear day, you have a view of the great northern agricultural plains, the North Sea shining like burnished steel in the sun. Coquet was once the name of a forest, the old word "cocwudu" meaning a place frequented by cocks and wild birds - Northumberland was once known as the cradle of the blackcock. Despite having the dogs with me, Labrador at heel and dachsund leading the way, I identified a dipper, two sandpipers, a ring ousel and a heron standing on one leg on a rock. The Coquet isn't deep, but my father, a keen amateur gemologist, hunted for stones in its tumbling waters and left a collection of quartz pebbles - chalcedony, carnelian, agate, jasper, citrine and onyx.

The road alongside the Coquet was banked by hedges ablaze in red and bronze with rowan and wild gean, until I came to more open country near the river's source, close to the border at Chew Green, where fortified Roman earthworks still mark the hillside. The dogs and I, exhausted by now, were climbing some tumbled rocks, locally known as torrs, upon which to have a rest, when a shaggy creature with long horns and a trailing beard shuffled away indignantly. A wild billy goat, he made our weary walk worthwhile. Feral goats in small herds inhabit the Cheviots but it's rare to see one alone, unless accompanied by a shepherd. I gathered up the dachsund, collapsed on the torrs, and fumbled for my binoculars. The billy climbed a precipitous slope behind us to reach a clump of bracken alongside a burn, where he disappeared.

fields.headline: Pinochet confined to Chile
fields.standfirst: Court bars general from leaving country after extradition request
fields.trailText: The Chilean supreme court has ordered General Augusto Pinochet and six security agents to be placed under court supervision and ruled that he must not leave the country.
fields.body:
The Chilean supreme court has ordered General Augusto Pinochet and six security agents to be placed under court supervision and ruled that he must not leave the country.

The measure, agreed late on Wednesday, followed an Argentine extradition request for the former dictator, who ruled Chile from 1973 to 1990.

An ongoing investigation in Buenos Aires has named Gen Pinochet as a main suspect in the planning of a 1974 car bombing in the city which killed Carlos Prats, a Chilean army general, and a leading opponent of the dictator.

Argentina wants to question Pinochet specifically about his role in the bombing.

Prosecuting lawyers said that the Argentine extradition request was incomplete, but that once a fully certified order of arrest had arrived from Buenos Aires, supreme court judge Luis Correa Bulo would most probably order Gen Pinochet to be placed under house arrest.

Since his return to Chile earlier this year, Gen Pinochet has been free to travel both in Chile and abroad - although numerous international warrants for his arrest limit the latter option.

The supreme court-imposed travel restriction was seen as an immediate step towards cornering Gen Pinochet in Chile.

Gen Pinochet received the news in a Santiago military hospital where he is allegedly fighting acute pneumonia. Whether the 84-year-old general is actually sick or merely seeking to foil the increasing number of judicial investigations remains unclear.

Chilean human rights violators have a habit of holing up in either the military hospital or army barracks whenever a judicial investigation advances, while medical tests to determine whether the former leader is fit to be tried have been repeatedly delayed.

Investigations against him are now moving forward, both in Argentina and Chile. In Buenos Aires, investigating judge Maria Servini de Cubria has successfully broken the code of silence among Chilean army commando teams.

As the lower-level officers begin to accuse their superiors, the evidence increasingly points to the highest levels of the chain of command, and Gen Pinochet.

The focus on the execution of Prats has opened a long-simmering feud among the Chilean armed forces. At the time of his murder, Prats was emerging as a leading voice calling for an end to the year-old military regime and advocating a swift return to civilian government.

This clashed with Gen Pinochet's ambitions to radically restructure Chilean society, with military leaders governing everything from high schools to film censorship.

After weeks of anonymous death threats, Prats and his wife Sophia Cuthbert were killed in a massive car bomb outside their flat in Buenos Aires.

Surviving members of the family applauded this week's advances. "I think Pinochet will be a prisoner within a week," said Maria Angelica Prats, daughter of the assassinated general.

Chilean officials are unlikely to approve extradition of Gen Pinochet to Argentina, however. But a host of other legal charges are trapping him in Chile.

With a radically invigorated judiciary, the elite commandos are now scrambling to pass the blame and, in an unprecedented wave of revelations, are providing evidence of General Pinochet's direct role in the repression that gripped Chile for much of the 17 years of military rule.

webTitle: World's youth sees Britons as racist drunks

fields.headline: World's youth sees Britons as racist drunks
fields.standfirst: Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Britons are seen by young people in other countries as arrogant, xenophobic and frequently drunk, according to a poll conducted by the British Council in 17 countries and published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britons are seen by young people in other countries as arrogant, xenophobic and frequently drunk, according to a poll conducted by the British Council in 17 countries and published yesterday.

A British Council report accompanying the poll said that in general "young people overseas have a positive image of the UK as a country but are less admiring of Britons as a people".

The pollsters, Mori, carried out face to face interviews with 3,505 people aged 24-40 between January and June this year. Those interviewed tended to be well-educated and were targeted as the next generation of leaders.

The British Council said a big factor in Britain's reputation for drunkenness was the scenes of violence by football supporters abroad.

Other factors contributing to a negative view of Britain were the royal family, violence in Northern Ireland and racial intolerance. Pictures of English fans rioting at Marseilles during the 1998 World Cup went round the world.

In a focus group discussion, an Italian among those being interviewed portrayed the British as "having tea at five o'clock, having a Queen and always drunk".

Overall, the view of British society is ambivalent. "On the whole, they see it as fair, caring and democratic, but also as divided by class and, in the eyes of some, racially intolerant," the report said.

David Green, the British Council director, said he was concerned "by the high proportion of young people who associate us British with an arrogant and condescending view of other countries. Anyone who watched, for instance, the scenes at Charleroi during Euro 2000 can understand how these perceptions arise. Countering them will not be easy."

A task force has begun trying to knit together a presentational policy for the various departments and organisations involved with Britain's image overseas, such as the Foreign Office, the British Council, the British Tourist Authority and the Design Council.

The poll showed Britain had a good reputation for higher education. The view of British business was also good, though businessmen were regarded as cautious or complacent.

British scientists are seen as among the best in the world but there is puzzlement abroad at the failure of the country to exploit their innovations.

According to the poll, Britain was least liked by young people in China, which may partly have been a reaction to the Nato bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. Britain was most popular in Nigeria.

Among European countries, Britain was least popular in Greece, again possibly a reaction to the Nato bombing. After Greece, Britain was least popular with German youths. It was most popular with France.

The report, Through Other Eyes 2; How the world sees the United Kingdom, follows on from a similar exercise last year in which interviews took place in 13 other countries.

One of the biggest changes is in the way young people obtain their information about Britain, with 21% finding out through the internet.

Tony Blair is the best known Briton, followed by the Spice Girls (except in the Far East where they come top), Naomi Campbell, Hugh Grant and Kate Winslet. Eighteen per cent claimed to have heard of William Hague, a high recognition factor for someone not in office.

Do they mean us?

Naomi Campbell 24%
fields.bodyText: Britons are seen by young people in other countries as arrogant, xenophobic and frequently drunk, according to a poll conducted by the British Council in 17 countries and published yesterday. A British Council report accompanying the poll said that in general "young people overseas have a positive image of the UK as a country but are less admiring of Britons as a people". The pollsters, Mori, carried out face to face interviews with 3,505 people aged 24-40 between January and June this year. Those interviewed tended to be well-educated and were targeted as the next generation of leaders. The British Council said a big factor in Britain's reputation for drunkenness was the scenes of violence by football supporters abroad. Other factors contributing to a negative view of Britain were the royal family, violence in Northern Ireland and racial intolerance. Pictures of English fans rioting at Marseilles during the 1998 World Cup went round the world. In a focus group discussion, an Italian among those being interviewed portrayed the British as "having tea at five o'clock, having a Queen and always drunk". Overall, the view of British society is ambivalent. "On the whole, they see it as fair, caring and democratic, but also as divided by class and, in the eyes of some, racially intolerant," the report said. David Green, the British Council director, said he was concerned "by the high proportion of young people who associate us British with an arrogant and condescending view of other countries. Anyone who watched, for instance, the scenes at Charleroi during Euro 2000 can understand how these perceptions arise. Countering them will not be easy." A task force has begun trying to knit together a presentational policy for the various departments and organisations involved with Britain's image overseas, such as the Foreign Office, the British Council, the British Tourist Authority and the Design Council. The poll showed Britain had a good reputation for higher education. The view of British business was also good, though businessmen were regarded as cautious or complacent. British scientists are seen as among the best in the world but there is puzzlement abroad at the failure of the country to exploit their innovations. According to the poll, Britain was least liked by young people in China, which may partly have been a reaction to the Nato bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. Britain was most popular in Nigeria. Among European countries, Britain was least popular in Greece, again possibly a reaction to the Nato bombing. After Greece, Britain was least popular with German youths. It was most popular with France. The report, Through Other Eyes 2; How the world sees the United Kingdom, follows on from a similar exercise last year in which interviews took place in 13 other countries. One of the biggest changes is in the way young people obtain their information about Britain, with 21% finding out through the internet. Tony Blair is the best known Briton, followed by the Spice Girls (except in the Far East where they come top), Naomi Campbell, Hugh Grant and Kate Winslet. Eighteen per cent claimed to have heard of William Hague, a high recognition factor for someone not in office. Do they mean us? fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dome accused are remanded
fields.body:
Dome accused are remanded

Eight men from London and the south-east appeared before magistrates at Belmarsh in south London to be remanded in custody until Tuesday over the attempted robbery of the Millennium Dome. Six were charged with attempted robbery, and two with aiding and abetting. Armed police guarded the court.
Keith Perry

Sinn Fein's no to flying the flag

Ministers Martin McGuiness and Bairbre de Brun will not order their civil servants to fly the union flag this Sunday, Remembrance Sunday, Sinn Fein said after the high court in Belfast gave leave for a judicial review of the Northern Ireland secretary's regulation.

Dando birthday coincidence

Barry Bulsara, 40, charged with murdering Jill Dando, had an Old Bailey appearance cancelled yesterday, the prosecution service saying that it coincided with the presenter's birthday.

Occupation over animal rights

Peta, an animal rights group, temporarily occupied offices of the British Heart Foundation in London, over the charity's claimed failure to tell donors it funds research using animal experiments.<

A matter of semantics

The Marquess of Bath (Eton and Oxford) has published a book telling how he found a term for his numerous partners beside his wife: "If I had talked about my concubines or mistresses, it might have been regarded by some as a disparagement. We settled eventually for the humorous and affectionate term of 'wifelets'."

fields.headline: Letters reveal concerns
fields.standfirst:
Questions asked behind the scenes

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Questions asked behind the scenes.
fields.body:
Chris Smith to Lord Falconer, February 2000

"The company has faced quite exceptionally difficult challenges over a period of months, but the NMEC board does not appear to us to have played the role we would have expected in confronting the problems and providing leadership.

This is ... extremely serious when it comes to solvency and financial management. Either the board did not see it or chose to discount the warning signs of cashflow difficulties.

As a result it seems possible that it failed to take decisive action until after a date when the company became technically insolvent. We ... want to be convinced that the board will perform its functions more effectively in the future."

Bob Ayling to Chris Smith, March 30 2000

"The commitment of the non-executive directors to good corporate governance ... has not been, and is not, in any doubt. Between February 1997 and March 2000 we have held 43 full board meetings, 54 executive committee meetings, 11 audit committee meetings, 12 health and safety committee meetings, 10 remuneration committee meetings and two legacy committee meetings. In total - 132 meetings over about 275 hours. The professionalism of non-executive directors ... has been consistently high."

Earl of Dalkeith, millennium commissioner, to Lord Falconer, September 6 2000

"Our earlier concerns on corporate governance were set out to you on 7 February ... I have to say we have been disappointed by the company's responses, many of which we have perceived as reflecting unchecked resistance by the executive ... we suggest it will be important for you to review urgently the performance and procedures of the board."

Falconer to Dalkeith, September 21 2000

"Like you, I was shocked by what the PWC [PriceWaterhouseCoopers] report implied about NMEC's financial management and corporate governance. I also share your view that David James and his team have the skills and experience to manage the endgame.

fields.headline: Complex dream running on empty
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Edited extract from the report by the comptroller and auditor general
fields.body:
Edited extract from the report by the comptroller and auditor general

The comptroller and auditor general's conclusions

It is clear that the main cause of the financial difficulties is the failure to achieve the visitor numbers and income required. The targets were ambitious and inherently risky. Managing the project has been complicated by the complex organisational arrangements put in place from the outset and by the failure to put in sufficiently robust financial management.

Visitor numbers

The commission's decision to award a grant to the company [New Millennium Experience Company] took account of estimates of visitor numbers ... that ranged from 8m to 12m. At that stage however final decisions had not been made on the dome's contents, ticket prices, marketing strategies, or whether there would be access by car. Once the dome had been built and much of the production cost incurred, the room for manoeuvre in the face of low visitor numbers was restricted. As the financial situation deteriorated, the only options short of closing the dome and liquidating the company were to rely on receipts from the planned sale of the dome and further grants. It is not clear that going into operation the main parties had agreed a plan of how they would respond if visitor income fell significantly.

The company lacked sufficient operational expertise

During the content development phases the company involved a number of eminent and qualified individuals ... however, the company lacked senior staff with experience of running a large visitor attraction.

Marketing and sales strategies

Marketing in the original business plan had been set at a low level. The reason ... had been that ticket sales would be driven by free media exposure, word of mouth recommendations, and traditional fascination with Expo-style events. The company considered that the negative media coverage of the dome ... had a depressing effect on visitor numbers; the content had not been sufficiently explained or promoted; and there was a perception that travel costs were high and travel times long. The company estimates that each time the dome received "bad press" enquiries dropped by 30% to 50%.

Financial management

There have been weaknesses in financial management and control at the company.

The systems in place and the information available have hindered the company's ability to produce reliable financial forecasts. The company has been unable to track and quantify fully the contractual commitments it has entered into. The company experienced difficulty establishing the full extent of its liabilities through to solvent liquidation and handover to a new owner.

Planned and actual costs

The first signs of financial difficulties emerged early on, with the erosion of cost and revenue contingencies. In November 1998 ... the company forecast its net grant requirement to be £441m, a 10% increase on the original £399m. By November 1999 the company had drawn all but £7m of the commission's £449m grant and had used up all but £5.7m of its costs contingency. The company was heavily dependent on timely receipt of its forecast income.

The financial difficulties were largely the result of the shortfall in income

There were strong indications by mid-1999 that there was likely to be a shortfall in income. Sponsorship income received was below forecast. By the end of December the company had received £74.1m of the £125.5m it had expected - a shortfall of 41%. In the period up to the opening the company received £3.9m of the £18.9m ticket income it expected.

In February 2000 the commission made an additional grant of £60m. In May ... a further £29m. The company considered its solvency ... it drew comfort from the shareholder's [Lord Falconer's] evidence to the select committee on culture, media and sport: "If the dome became insolvent it would be a matter, ultimately, for the government to bail it out in some way or another. However the position would not be reached where the dome was insolvent." In August the company was awarded an additional grant of £43m.

Key factors influencing performance

The target of 12m visitors was a broad estimate and not based on a clear vision of the dome's content. ... The company estimated the dome needed to attract 732,500 paying visitors in January, but achieved 328,821. It considers important factors in the shortfall are:

 Negative media coverage.

 The decision not to allow car parking.

 Difficulty of predicting visitor numbers and the unique nature of the exhibition.

 The strength of the pound, holding back overseas visitors and encouraging foreign travel by British people.

 Competition from other attractions, in London in particular, such as the London Eye and Tate Modern.

Sponsorship income was lower than expected

In May 1997 the company expected to attract £195m in private sector sponsorship. By September 2000 the company had reduced its budget to £115m.

Weaknesses in financial planning and control at the company

During 2000 the company's internal and external auditors and consultants identified concerns about the quality of financial control and forecasting. One of the main reasons ... was the lack of detailed reporting of the expenditure and costs. [PriceWaterhouseCooper] pointed to the absence of an integrated financial model for generating cashflow forecasts and balance sheets. In addition PWC found that many departments within the company were unable to quantify their level of spending.

webTitle: Clinton to fly to Ulster to aid talks on weapons

fields.headline: Clinton to fly to Ulster to aid talks on weapons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: President Clinton is planning a farewell visit to Northern Ireland next month in the hope of achieving a final diplomatic triumph before he relinquishes power in January.
fields.body:
President Clinton is planning a farewell visit to Northern Ireland next month in the hope of achieving a final diplomatic triumph before he relinquishes power in January.

Mr Clinton, who is respected on both sides for his commitment to the peace process, will fly to Northern Ireland only if Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionist party can reach a deal on disarmament within the next few weeks.

Political leaders in the province are in talks after the UUP leader, David Trimble, blocked Sinn Fein from a cross-border ministerial council over IRA "failure" to disarm.

President Clinton is said to be willing to help the negotiations by telephone from Washington in the coming weeks. One Irish official said: "He has done a superb diplomatic job in the past, adding an extra bit to the negotiations."

However, Sinn Fein and the UUP were still poles apart last night on the issue, as the republicans announced they were ready to mount a legal challenge to Mr Trimble's ban. Sinn Fein and the UUP had what was described as a "comprehensive exchange of views" at the first meeting of the power-sharing executive since the ban was imposed.

fields.headline: Westminster sharks encircle tempting target
fields.standfirst:
Blair protege ignored warning signs

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Blair protege ignored warning signs.
fields.body:
Westminster's sharks are circling around Lord Falconer of Thoroton, Tony Blair's old flatmate, now minister responsible for the dome. As such he is the most tempting piece of flesh for the government's critics to take a bite from.

Will they force him to resign? Lord Falconer, Charlie to his many friends in Whitehall and the legal bar, says he has no intention of falling on his sword. Mr Blair, who has known him since their teens, is standing by his man.

But politics is littered with allies whom leaders had to discard to save their larger project - and themselves - when voters demanded a blood sacrifice to assuage their righteous anger. John Major threw over his chancellor, Norman Lamont. Mr Blair cast out Peter Mandelson, albeit only temporarily.

Lord Falconer, 49 and a political novice in 1997, is not the only legitimate target for those who regard the Millennium Dome as a mismanaged and over-ambitious scheme.

Assorted managers and board members at the New Millennium Experience Company who got the dome open - after a fashion - in time for New Year's Eve have also attracted flak.

So do politicians of all parties and members of the great and good who sat on the millennium commission and encouraged the project. Michael Heseltine and Simon Jenkins, former editor of the Times, are easy, tempting targets.

But genial Lord Falconer - Whitehall's sole shareholder on the NMEC board - remains the most tempting target. He did not start the project, and took it over only when Mr Mandelson, the original "dome secretary" (who took the portfolio with him when he went to the DTI) quit over his mortgage crisis in December 1998.

Lord Falconer's offence is to ignore warnings that things were going badly wrong when the dome was trading below "wildly optimistic" expectation. He remained an optimist, at least in public. Unknown liabilities which surfaced later combined with poor income to doom the dome.

Everyone who works with Lord Falconer agrees he is clever and hard-working. He devours paperwork and problem-solves for Mr Blair from his base in the Cabinet Office. All the same his lawyer talents, which serve him well in that capacity, do not make him a project manager, even at one remove, for a £1bn scheme. As Mr Blair admitted at his party conference, with hindsight, politicians should not run entertainment projects.

Lord Falconer's real crime, however, is that he is Blair's mate, a classic patronage appointment. Rivals who would not dare strike Mr Blair directly attack his protegee.

"Patronage is wrong," says one leftwing MP. "When they're good, the principle still stands."

webTitle: European men fell from same family tree

fields.headline: European men fell from same family tree
fields.trailText: Nearly all men in Europe and the Middle East have descended from only 10 male ancestors, research today shows.
fields.body:
Nearly all men in Europe and the Middle East have descended from only 10 male ancestors, research today shows.

And the biggest influence in the European male genes is from the hunter-gathering palaeolithic, the old stone age, 40,000 to 20,000 years ago. Only one male in five in Europe comes from the more settled farming stock of the new stone age.

The news that New Lad is mostly very old lad is published in Science. A team from Pavia University in Italy examined the Y chromosomes, passed only from father to son, of 1,007 volunteers. It found that almost all the volunteers could be linked to 10 ancestral strains.

Two of these lineages - thought to represent 80% of European manhood - turned up during the ice age clutching stone axes and wooden spears, and sat it out until times got very tough. The first appeared between 40,000 and 35,000 years ago, probably from Siberia. The second arrived from the Middle East 25,000 to 20,000 years ago.

The other eight clans arrived either from the Middle East or the Urals 9,000 to 6,000 years ago and fathered perhaps a fifth of European males between them.
