fields.headline: Capital offsets dot.com damage
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Capital Radio yesterday took the slump in the dot.com sector in its stride to report a 14.6% increase in advertising revenues last year.
fields.body:
Capital Radio yesterday took the slump in the dot.com sector in its stride to report a 14.6% increase in advertising revenues last year.

The company, which operates stations including Capital FM and Xfm in London and BRMB in Birmingham, said dot.com advertisers peaked at 10% of group revenues in May and drifted down to 5% by September.

David Mansfield, Capital's chief executive, described the business that remains as sustainable. But he viewed the future with some caution.

"The outlook for advertising over the coming months is uncertain with visibility not that clear, but radio revenues are expected to grow in the industry by between 10% and 15% next year and radio will continue to be a fast-growing advertising medium over the next few years," he said.

Analysts had expressed particular concern about Capital because most of the dot.com advertising spend found its way into metropolitan radio stations. Underlying pre-tax profits rose by 9.5% to £41.3m on revenues which were 17.8% up at £123.9m.

Mr Mansfield echoed comments by his opposite number at rival GWR earlier this week and looked forward to the expected relaxation of ownership rules in the communications white paper. Capital hoped to acquire further assets although he noted the business had not made a hostile bid in its 27-year history.

Mr Mansfield also set his sights on mainland Europe. "We see a number of opportunities but we will only go there in partnership with local players. We believe there are particular territories in Europe which are under-developed and ripe for consolidation."

During the year Capital acquired three Century stations in the Midlands and north of England, and Beat in Scotland. Capital can now reach 58% of the UK population.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Strike threat at Land Rover
fields.body:
Strike threat at Land Rover

Workers at motor group Land Rover - now owned by Ford - have rejected a 4.25% pay offer, raising the threat of industrial action, unions announced today. Members at the Solihull-based firm voted by 71% to 29% against the proposed deal, which would also have given them a £265 holiday bonus payment.

Tony Woodley, chief negotiator for the TGWU, said urgent talks would be sought with the company following the "clear rejection" of the offer.

Cable operator on track

NTL, Britain's largest cable TV operator, said yesterday it was on track to meet its goal of 500,000 digital TV subscribers by year-end.

NTL's digital subscriber base grew about 40% to 325,000 in the three months to September, in which period group revenues totalled £560m, more than double that reported for the same time last year. NTL also said third-quarter earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation rose 54% to £62m.

BAA to keep capital airports

The government has backed away from breaking up London's three main airports - Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted - and disposing of them as separate companies in order to create extra competition. John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said yesterday that the government is allowing BAA, the airports operator, to keep the airports following an 18-month review of airport competition.

Barclays said it has appointed John Varley, an executive director and formerly chief executive of Barclays Retail Financial Services, as finance director with immediate effect, succeeding David Allvey who also ceased yesterday to be a director of those companies.

fields.headline: Misery continues for flood evacuees
fields.standfirst:
Anxious wait as heavy rains are forecast to fall on south

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: A lake as big as Windermere filled the lower Ouse valley in Yorkshire yesterday as hundreds of evacuees faced a second night in bedrolls at friends' houses or on the floors of a local comprehensive.
fields.body:
A lake as big as Windermere filled the lower Ouse valley in Yorkshire yesterday as hundreds of evacuees faced a second night in bedrolls at friends' houses or on the floors of a local comprehensive.

At Sherburn high school, near Selby, weary families took turns to use the school showers and nibble gingerbread donated from washed-out local bonfire parties.

The makeshift rescue centre was in the eye of Britain's continuing flood trauma, with half the 25 remaining severe flood warnings applying to the nearby rivers Ouse and Derwent. Slight falls in the Ouse, which is now lined by 250,000 sandbags between Cawood and Selby, led to 40 families returning home, but a further 30 were evacuated in York because of sewage pollution.

The city is bracing itself for further rainfall on Pennine high ground over the weekend.

Three high capacity pumps from the Netherlands arrived at Selby yesterday to clear the worst affected areas around the hospital, which has evacuated patients, and Brayton school, a rescue centre which itself had to be abandoned.

With the flood insurance bill topping £100 million, according to Royal and Sun Alliance, the environment agency said the level of rain over the next few days would be crucial to chances of restoring stability to river levels. Rainfall is close to the worst autumn total since records began in 1727, but the meteorological office forecast relief for the north for the next two days when heavy rain is more likely in the south-east.

Severe flood warnings remain in force on four southern rivers, including "Millionaires' Bank" near Maidenhead on the Thames, where residents including the actress Kate Winslet and TV chat show host Michael Parkinson have sandbagged their riverside homes.

Severe flood warnings also remain on the Arun between Pulborough and Arundel, the Lavant between East Dean and Chichester city centre and the Ems at Westbourne and Lumley Mill in West Sussex.

Emergency staff are examining the situation at the waste disposal site near Gloucester where the rising river Severn is again threatening the site of an explosion two weeks ago. Waste drums of BSE washings and toxic chemicals including cadmium are likely to be moved to higher ground. The environment agency and the agriculture ministry have launched an investigation into why the drums - filled with solvents used to wash brains from BSE-infected cattle - were not incinerated as intended when they were sent to the plant four years ago

Almost 15 inches of rain has fallen over England and Wales so far this autumn, just three inches short of the highest rainfall recorded for the period, and there are still three weeks of November to go. Railtrack's repairs programme meanwhile closed lines from Devon to Merseyside and all travellers were advised to check with train operators.

Disruption also affected East Anglia, most of the midlands and Yorkshire, where prob lems were compounded by the floods. Heavy rain blocked roads in north Wales and the scenic tourist route of the Horseshoe Pass near Llangollen is expected to remain closed until after Christmas following landslips which carried away part of the road.

The floods' secondary problem of sightseers brought a renewed warning from the environment agency at Worcester and York, where onlookers were accused of hampering rescue efforts and putting themselves in danger.

fields.headline: Guardian fights MI5 trial secrecy
fields.standfirst:
Special report: freedom of information
Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: The trial of David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, raised issues of fundamental importance, including the principle of open justice and the right of the public to be informed by the media, lawyers acting for the Guardian told an Old Bailey judge yesterday.
fields.body:
The trial of David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, raised issues of fundamental importance, including the principle of open justice and the right of the public to be informed by the media, lawyers acting for the Guardian told an Old Bailey judge yesterday.

Michael Tugendhat QC, counsel for the newspaper and other media organisations, objected to the way state prosecutors have warned they would apply for part of Mr Shayler's trial to be held behind closed doors on grounds of national security.

Mr Shayler yesterday pleaded not guilty to three charges of breaking the Official Secrets Act. His trial, which might last up to four weeks, was fixed for April 23.

The case raised the principle of freedom of expression, the right of the public to be informed though the press and the need to maintain the public's confidence in the administration of justice, Mr Tugendhat said in a written submission.

Michael Hyam, the recorder of London, said Mr Tugendhat had made "formidable points" about lack of clarity in the notice. Nigel Sweeney QC, for the prosecution, replied that it was difficult for him to specify what parts of the trial should held in secret. He would not rule out requests for public interest immunity certificates, or gagging orders.

In a related attack on official secrecy, Article 19, the international campaign against censorship, and the human rights group Liberty yesterday described the government's suppression of information as an "international disgrace" and called for the system to be overhauled and brought into line with international standards.

"It is time for the government to drop its national security fig leaf," said Andrew Puddephatt, executive director of Article 19, and John Wadham, director of Liberty.

In a joint publication, Secrets, Spies and Whistleblowers, published today, the two organisations say Britain stands out among established democracies for its lack of constitutional, statutory or judicial safeguards on censorship, confidentiality of sources and taking into account the public interest in cases where national security is concerned.

Successive governments have used a raft of mechanisms to suppress information, obtain documents, compel disclosure of sources and punish those responsible for disclosures, it says.

The report points out that the government is widening the definition of national security to include potential threats to Britain's allies abroad.

fields.headline: Fruitless outcome for semen supplier
fields.trailText: Genus, which specialises in supplying semen for the cattle breeding market, has fired two senior employees whom it holds responsible for losing the custom of key clients, leading the company to issue a profits warning yesterday.
fields.body:
Genus, which specialises in supplying semen for the cattle breeding market, has fired two senior employees whom it holds responsible for losing the custom of key clients, leading the company to issue a profits warning yesterday.

Richard Wood, the chief executive, said the pair were dismissed after the introduction of a new computer system caused a dramatic drop in service levels and the loss of 50 important customers.

"The customers complained they weren't getting the right products at the right time," Mr Wood explained last night.

"It became apparent midway through August, and in September I moved swiftly to cull the management."

Stephen Whetstone, the managing director of Genus's distribution side, and general manager Paddy Chubb have since left the company.

Jim Bowen has been promoted to run the division.

The problems emerged in the York-based Genusexpress operation, which supplies pharmaceutical products, instruments and pet accessories to vets.

In a statement to the stock market, Genus said the difficulties meant its full-year pre-tax profits, due to be announced in March, would be lower than expected, although significantly ahead of last year.

Last night the company's shares had slipped as a result of the warning to end the day down 11.5p, or 7.8%, at 135p.

webTitle: Lamy ups stakes in US trade dispute

fields.headline: Lamy ups stakes in US trade dispute
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: EU trade commissioner Pascal Lamy raised the temperature in the trade row between Brussels and Washington today when he warned the US that it would face massive sanctions unless Congress brought in new laws within days to outlaw export subsidies to its multinational corporations.
fields.byline: Larry Elliott and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
EU trade commissioner Pascal Lamy raised the temperature in the trade row between Brussels and Washington today when he warned the US that it would face massive sanctions unless Congress brought in new laws within days to outlaw export subsidies to its multinational corporations.

In an interview with the German newspaper, Berliner Zeitung, Mr Lamy said that the EU would file an application next week with the World Trade Organisation - the Geneva-based body that polices global trade - for compensation running into billions of dollars. "We are talking about very grave sanctions," he said.

With America in political turmoil, Congress will have just three days next week to enact the new laws following its recess during the elections.

The WTO has already ruled that the US tax breaks are illegal, and has given Washington until the beginning of next month to amend its legislation. Brussels has to hand in a list of sanction proposals to the WTO by November 17, but sources said that a full-scale trade war would be averted if Congress enacted a new law next week.

Amy Stilwell in the US trade representative's office, said that the Clinton administration wanted the legislation to replace the foreign sales corporation passed as quickly as possible.

webTitle: Sportingbet will use AIM entry to fund expansion

fields.headline: Sportingbet will use AIM entry to fund expansion
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Sportingbet.com, the tax-free online betting group, yesterday announced plans to raise funds on the Alternative Investment Market in order to expand and strengthen its global operation.
fields.body:
Sportingbet.com, the tax-free online betting group, yesterday announced plans to raise funds on the Alternative Investment Market in order to expand and strengthen its global operation.

Managing director Mark Blandford said the company, at present listed on Ofex, hoped to raise a "substantial amount" when it transferred to AIM early next year, giving it a market capitalisation of up to £200m.

Funds would be channelled into marketing and acquisitions, with the aim of becoming "the leading online global sports book".

The company intends to develop a network of call centres around the world to cater for regional diversity in sporting interests.

Results for the six months to September showed turnover rising to £114m from £4.6m for the same period the previous year. This was mainly due to acquisition of US company Betmaker - now known as SportingbetUSA.com - although Sportingbet claimed to have achieved organic growth of £44.9m.

Pre-tax losses were also affected by the acquisition, widening to £4.21m from £979,000 in the previous year.

"We have reached a critical mass of customers which means the margins we make now cover our operating costs," Mr Blandford said. "From now on, revenue from new customers will go straight down to our bottom line."

fields.headline: Over-16 skills get extra £600m
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Education and training for teenagers will benefit from a funding boost of £600m, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Education and training for teenagers will benefit from a funding boost of £600m, it emerged yesterday.

Following Gordon Brown's announcement of a £200m windfall for primary and secondary schools on Wednesday for repairs and other capital projects, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday gave details of increased funding this year for the post-16 sector.

The announcement means a 9% increase in the budget of the learning and skills council to over £5.5bn for the academic year 2001-2002. The new body co-ordinates academic and vocational courses available for 16 to 19 year olds, taking over from the disbanded training and enterprise councils.

"The extra money will mean that the council and its 47 local arms can hit the ground running when they start work next April," Mr Blunkett said. "For 2002-3 there will be a further funding increase of £400m- a 5% increase in real terms. This does not include the additional funding we shall be giving to the councils when they take over responsibility for school sixth forms."

Yesterday the LSC chairman, Bryan Sanderson, welcomed the extra funding but warned that the council faced a "colossal task" to improve skills.

Seven million people could not read, write or add up properly, six million had no qualifications and a quarter of the adult population had done no extra training over the last three years, he said.

"Millions of people in the UK have turned off their learning switch. It is our job to help them turn it back on again, to help them realise that learning is a boon, not a burden."

Gwen Evans, deputy general sectetary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "The government is finally matching money to their rhetoric.

"It is an acknowledgment that the on-the-cheap solutions that existed in the past excluded those who are costly and hard to help."

The University and College Lecturers'union urged the LSC to use the extra cash to "remotivate, reprofessionalise and decasualise the teaching force in the country's colleges and training centres".

webTitle: British flying ace was spy for Japan

fields.headline: British flying ace was spy for Japan
fields.trailText: A highly decorated British flying ace spied for Japan in the years leading up to the outbreak of the second world war, papers declassified today reveal.
fields.body:
A highly decorated British flying ace spied for Japan in the years leading up to the outbreak of the second world war, papers declassified today reveal.

Frederick Rutland, who won the Distinguished Service Order for daring low-level attacks on German cruisers during the Battle of Jutland in 1916, was initially recruited by Japan as an adviser on naval flying techniques.

Papers released at the Public Record Office also show Japanese naval intelligence paid him to set up a spy base in Hawaii years before the surprise attack on Pearl Harbour in December 1941.

Rutland first came to the notice of MI5 in 1922 when he suddenly decided to end his glittering career and resign from the RAF. The agency received what it called "reliable information" from a "very delicate source" - known only as BJ - that the Japanese had secret talks with Rutland.

MI5 noted that Rutland possessed "unique knowledge of aircraft carriers and deck landings".

GCHQ, which had already broken Japanese naval codes, intercepted a string of communications to and from Japan's naval attache in London and naval intelligence headquarters in Tokyo.

They paint a picture of an ineffective businessman and spy who continually haggled over money and expenses. In the 1920s he sailed with his wife and child to Japan where he apparently failed to land a job with Mitsubishi.

"Shinkawa" - Rutland's code name - later travelled to the US. Intriguingly, given how the US was so surprised by Japan's attack on Pearl Harbour in December 1941, the intercepts reveal that in 1935 Rutland told his Japanese spymasters that "everyone" he met in America "thinks a war with Japan is inevitable, many even say it will be their way out of a depression".

The intercepts note that Tokyo had paid Rutland to set up a "small agency in Hawaii". A horrified MI6 - Britain's secret intelligence service which operates abroad - discovered that Rutland had come to the attention of the US authorities.

MI6 warned of the "scandal which would be caused by the arrest of a former Air Force officer on charges of espionage ..." MI5 made it clear that, in its view, Rutland should be arrested.

There was no doubt that Rutland was a "paid agent of the Japanese", said a report signed by AF Blunt - the MI5 officer Anthony Blunt, who was later knighted for his work as surveyor of the Queen's pictures and exposed as a Soviet agent in 1979.

Rutland saved everyone's embarrassment by returning to Britain where he was quietly interned in 1941.

webTitle: Arab suspects linked to big operation against US

fields.headline: Arab suspects linked to big operation against US
fields.trailText: Kuwait said yesterday that it was holding three Arabs and was seeking a fourth on suspicion of plotting to attack American interests in the Gulf.
fields.body:
Kuwait said yesterday that it was holding three Arabs and was seeking a fourth on suspicion of plotting to attack American interests in the Gulf.

An interior ministry statement said three Kuwaitis had been arrested and a north African man carrying a forged passport was still at large. It said the suspects had five hand grenades and 133kg of high explosives.

A security source said the suspects were believed to be Islamists. Several other people who were earlier arrested had now been released.

"Out of all those investigated, so far only the three Kuwaitis and the north African are expected to face trial. They led authorities to where they had hidden their explosives and gave other information," the security official said.

The newspaper Al-Qabas quoted a security source as saying that the suspects were linked to the Saudi fugitive Osama bin Laden, and had been planning "a big operation" inside Kuwait, as well as attacks on US targets elsewhere.

The arrests came after the US, on a heightened state of alert because of "credible" but unspecified threats, tightened security around its troops in the region.

US and British troops are deployed in Kuwait to enforce the no-fly zone over southern Iraq and to protect the tiny oil-rich state from perceived threats from Baghdad.

About 5,000 American and 600 British troops live in Kuwait, as well as 8,000 American and 4,000 British civilians.

Meanwhile, the US embassy in Yemen confirmed that American experts working to rid Yemen of its landmines had left the country, but gave no explanation. A Yemeni newspaper reported that they had left because of threats.

More than 40 FBI agents, investigating last month's suicide attack on the warship USS Cole in the Yemeni port of Aden, recently left their hotel following threats and are now based offshore, travelling to the mainland by helicopter.

Yemeni investigations into the Aden bombing have so far concentrated on local Islamists, though Iraq and Bin Laden have also been suggested as possible culprits.

The inflatable which exploded alongside the warship is believed to have been packed with between 180kg and 320kg of C-4, a military explosive. Although C-4 is difficult to acquire, quantities have been stolen.

Yemeni investigations suggest that planning of the Aden attack began at least six months ago - which would rule out a direct connection with the current Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

It appears to have been motivated by a more general opposition to US involvement in the Middle East - which is often voiced by Islamist groups, especially in Yemen where the government has made a point of cultivating relations with the Americans.

Most armed Islamist groups claim some connection with Bin Laden, though the links can be tenuous and usually arise out of contacts made during the Afghan war. They do not necessarily indicate Bin Laden's involvement in specific actions.

Although early reports suggested the bombers must have acquired advance warning of the Cole's arrival, some Yemeni sources consider it more likely that they simply lay in wait for the first suitable target.

The Yemeni authorities have rounded up more than 60 people for questioning, and about 10 are still believed to be held.

Those questioned include police and officials at a local government office in Lahej, 25 miles north of Aden, where a false driving licence and other documents were issued to a man calling himself Abdullah Ahmed Khaled al-Musawah. He has been tentatively identified as one of the two who apparently killed themselves deliberately in the explosion.

In a country where bribery is rife, the issuing of false papers does not necessarily imply a political motive on the part of the officials concerned.

fields.headline: Dimension Data profits rise 62%
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Dimension Data, the South African computer networking company that moved its primary listing to London in July, yesterday reported a 62% increase in pre-tax profits to $244.6m (£171m) after a string of acquisitions.
fields.body:
Dimension Data, the South African computer networking company that moved its primary listing to London in July, yesterday reported a 62% increase in pre-tax profits to $244.6m (£171m) after a string of acquisitions.

Richard Came, marketing and strategy director, said the spending would continue, particularly in the US where the company was looking to buy a "large interactive commerce player" with a portion of the $1.4bn raised in Dimension Data's listing this summer.

The leap in pre-tax profits for the year to September was broadly in line with analysts' expectations, as was the 71% increase in turnover to £1.94bn. Basic earnings per share rose 35% to 16.1 cents but there is no dividend.

Yesterday's results also revealed that the company suffered a hefty $292m "goodwill amortisation" charge to cover its extensive acquisitions.

Mr Came said that Dimension Data's listing in London had allowed it to raise the capital for a spending programme and offer attractive share options to skilled staff. "Our acquisition programme is designed to consolidate the both sides of our business - IT infrastructure and e-commerce service provision - in markets around the world. We feel that it is this combined business model that has been validated by the results."

He added that, while Dimension Data Europe still had some way to grow following extensive restructuring, attention would now be focused on the US where the company hoped to do half of its business within two to three years.

Ross Jobber, analyst at Deutsche Bank, pointed out that Dimension Data was one of the few European IT companies not to see its forecasts revised downwards over the past year. He said the company had also done a great deal to consolidate its global identity, particularly by unifying its branding in Europe and the US, and by buying out minority shareholders in operations around the world.

Its shares fell 21p to 591p yesterday, largely in reaction to the drop in the Nasdaq index.

fields.headline: Three die as Israel abandons 'restraint'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's combat helicopters assassinated one of Yasser Arafat's activists yesterday, rocketing the car in which he and several other colleagues were travelling, in a deliberate escalation of its war on the Palestinians. The attack also killed two elderly women bystanders,and at least 10 other people were injured.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Beit Sahour, West Bank
fields.body:
Israel's combat helicopters assassinated one of Yasser Arafat's activists yesterday, rocketing the car in which he and several other colleagues were travelling, in a deliberate escalation of its war on the Palestinians. The attack also killed two elderly women bystanders,and at least 10 other people were injured.

The Israeli army said the chilling attack represented a new policy of "initiated" activity against Mr Arafat's Fatah party militias, or tanzim.

Decoded, that means the prime minister, Ehud Barak, has yielded to army commanders clamouring to abandon the policy of "restraint" which has guided the military during the past six weeks in which nearly 190 people have been killed, almost all Palestinian.

Yesterday's attack came on the day Mr Arafat met President Clinton in Washington to demand an international protection force for the West Bank and Gaza. It also promises to extinguish whatever faint hopes there were of ending the killing any time soon, and returning Israel and the Palestinians to negotiations.

In Beit Sahour, a wealthy Christian suburb of Bethlehem, witnesses said three helicopters circled persistently overhead before rocketing a forest green four-wheel drive vehicle almost simultaneously shortly after 10am. There was no warning.

"I cannot describe what I saw there," said Mahmoud Joubran, who watched the attack from his balcony. "There were body parts lying like pieces of meat on the ground." Minutes before the attack, the Fatah men in the car, and the two women, had made separate visits to the home of Jehan Shahabat to see the craters left at the rear of the house by shells fired from an Israeli army camp overnight.

Ms Shahabat was about to drive her aunt, Aziza Joubran, and a companion, Rahma Shaheen, home after their car suffered a flat tyre. As she was leaving the driveway, the rockets hit, killing both women waiting by the side of the road, and seriously wounding her uncle. Hours after the attack, a tow truck arrived, dumping the twisted heap of the Fatah men's car to the spot where it was struck, creating yet another grisly monument.

After weeks of bloodshed, yesterday's assassination of a Fatah activist is bound to further inflame Palestinian anger, fuelling more stone throwing.

"This is an assassination against one of the Fatah leaders in Bethlehem district," said Marwan Barghouti, head of Fatah in the West Bank. "I think this will push Fatah for a reaction."

One man in the car, identified by local Palestinians as Hussein Abayat, was killed outright. Another, Khalid Salahat, was taken to hospital in nearby Beit Jalla, with both arms bandaged and minor head wounds. Doctors said he was an official in Palestinian intelligence, and a swarm of armed men guarded his bed.

"Hussein was a soldier for the Palestinian Authority," said Fadi Salahat, his nephew. "He was patrolling the area to protect the people of Bethlehem and Beit Sahour from Israeli occupiers."

Israeli military officials claimed the attack was "an accurate hit". They said Abayat was "a mastermind of a terrorist network" suspected of involvement in the deaths of at least three Israeli soldiers, and of organising the nightly gunfire against the Jewish settlement of Gilo, on the southern edges of Jerusalem. Palestinians described the married father of six as a baker.

"Hussein Abayt was a central tanzim terrorist activist in the area of Bethlehm and was a merchant of illegal weapons," said Major-General Itzhak Eitan, the army's commander in the West Bank. "He was in possession of many weapons, among them the machine guns which he had used in many acts of terrorism."

Mr Barak has been under increasing popular pressure of late to hit back hard against attacks on settlement in the Jerusalem area. During recent weeks, Israel has regularly shelled the villages of Beit Jalla and Beit Sahour, in punishing retaliatory attacks for gunfire directed at Gilo.

Yesterday, Gen Eitan accused the Palestinian Authority of failing to stop attacks on Jewish settlements.

He said he was unaware of the deaths of the two women, adding, "I don't take responsibility for things I don't know."

webTitle: Disney and News Corp take a beating

fields.headline: Disney and News Corp take a beating
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shares in News Corporation and Walt Disney fell sharply yesterday amid fears that an advertising slowdown would hurt two of the world's biggest media groups next year.
fields.body:
Shares in News Corporation and Walt Disney fell sharply yesterday amid fears that an advertising slowdown would hurt two of the world's biggest media groups next year.

Jessica Reif Cohen, an influential media analyst at Merrill Lynch, prompted the declines after she downgraded both companies.

The unusual move hit News Corp particularly hard as Ms Cohen has always been bullish about Rupert Murdoch's empire.

Her decision to reduce earnings estimates for the next two years and to cut her share price forecast by one third to $60 (£42) comes at a sensitive time for News Corp, which is preparing to list its satellite television operations on the American stock market.

Merrill Lynch is handling the initial public offering.

In a note to investors, Ms Cohen wrote that while News Corp had "a unique and unparalleled portfolio of global content and distribution businesses...we are concerned about the near-term visibility of its key advertising related segments".

Shares in News Corp fell 13% to $38.25 on Wall Street yesterday morning after a 7% decline of the parent company's stock in Australia.

The downgrade followed a disappointing first-quarter earnings announcement for which the company partly blamed poor viewing figures for its Fox television network.

News Corp reported a net loss of A$439m (£163) for the three months to September 30, compared with a profit of A$251m for the same period last year.

Peter Chernin, the chief operating officer of News Corp, indicated that Fox expected single-digit declines in adver tising revenues during the next two months.

In an attempt to ease investor concerns over the flotation of Sky Global Networks, Mr Murdoch told investors to expect a listing in the first quarter of next year. Until a few weeks ago, he had indicated that the listing would come before the end of this year.

Shares in Walt Disney declined 14% yesterday morning, dragging down the Dow Jones industrial average.

In downgrading the company, Ms Cohen said the advertising slowdown would mean that the company could not repeat the success of last year, when its top-rated show, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? helped lift figures. Her warning came despite a 58% increase in fourth-quarter profits.

Michael Eisner, the Walt Disney chairman and chief executive, appeared on US television to give an upbeat outlook for the company.

Responding to a question about advertising revenues, he said: "I feel that the sky is not falling in."

 An internet investment vehicle backed by Rupert Murdoch, eVentures India, is to make a further investment of $150m in emerging businesses in the country's media and technology sectors.

"The new $150m capital will be deployed in 15-20 ventures in four areas: internet-based software and information technology-enabled services, infrastructure, new technologies in areas such as wireless and broadband, andbusiness-to-business enabling services," eVentures stated.

The joint venture involves Softbank of Japan, expatriate Indian tycoon PK Mittal and epartners, which is a subsidiary of News Corp.

The company has already committed $65m to 14 partners in India.2828

fields.trailText: Breach Banking company Credit Suisse Group said a recent security breach at its Direct Net online service, was caused by an unnamed third party, who was testing the service and then left the test data on the system where other users saw it.
fields.body:
 Breach Banking company Credit Suisse Group said a recent security breach at its Direct Net online service, www.directnet.ch, was caused by an unnamed third party, who was testing the service and then left the test data on the system where other users saw it. The bank said it "regretted the incident" in which "data relating to prominent persons was entered in the test area by an external company".

 Settlement Telecoms company AT&T said it has settled a patent lawsuit with Ronald A Katz Technology Licensing LP and paid an undisclosed sum for a global, non-exclusive license under a comprehensive portfolio of patents that Mr Katz owns relating to interactive voice applications.

 Goal ISP Microsoft Network is looking to break the world record audience figure for a live webcast on the internet with Madonna's live performance at the Brixton Academy. Madonna is performing on November 28; MSN said it is looking to break the 3m audience record for Paul McCartney concert in Liverpool earlier this year.

fields.headline: The defiant one
fields.standfirst: The spirit of Ring Lardner Jr - McCarthy victim and last of the Hollywood Ten - lives on
fields.trailText: The spirit of Ring Lardner Jr - McCarthy victim and last of the Hollywood Ten - lives on
fields.body:
Ring Lardner Jr was, with Dalton Trumbo, the most talented of the so-called Hollywood Ten: the nine writers and one director who were imprisoned in the early 1950s for refusing to answer the anti-communist litmus-test question: "Are you now, or have you ever been...?"

"It is a very simple question," the chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee (Huac), J Parnell Thomas, told Lardner when he was summoned to testify in 1947. "Any real American would be proud to answer it."

"Well," drawled a languid Lardner, "I could answer it, sir, but if I did, I'd hate myself in the morning." It was one of the defining moments of the witch-hunt. Lardner, who died last week aged 85, was ejected before he could deliver his prepared statement. "I think I'm leaving by force!" quipped the Oscar-winning screenwriter of Woman of the Year as bailiffs shoved him out of the chamber.

The next time he saw Thomas was in prison. In 1950, while Lardner and fellow Tenner Lester Cole were serving their time; Thomas was jailed alongside them for padding his Congressional payroll. The prisoners dubbed him "Congressman Chickenshit".

If all this seems like ancient history, think again. The Huac hearings, the fate of the Ten, the witchhunts that served to eviscerate the Hollywood craft unions, the persistence of the blacklist throughout movies and TV well into the 1960s - all of it remains an open sore on Hollywood's conscience and its collective folk-memory. The rancour it still provokes is astonishing.

Only three years ago, at a 50th anniversary commemoration of the Ten's appearance before Huac, the Hollywood studios finally made a collective apology for their craven acquiescence to the inquisition and the subsequent purge. That night Lardner finally got to read his 1947 statement, to resounding cheers. It was a bit late: of the Ten, only Lardner and Paul Jarrico were left, and Jarrico died the next day.

A year later came the controversy over the lifetime achievement award presented to director Elia Kazan, who revolted his peers in 1952 by naming names to keep working. Rod Steiger remembered that learning of Kazan's capitulation "was like finding out my father was sleeping with my sister". Kazan has never apologised. And it was barely a year ago that the Academy belatedly restored writing credits to writers like Trumbo and Lardner, who had won Oscars for scripts written under fake identities. Or rather they hadn't won them, because at the time they were, in the land of the free, essentially Un-persons. Restitution took 50 years. The news was coolly received by two men and eight gravestones.

Huac was indefensible, but that doesn't mean it's ever been short of defenders. The 1999 Kazan controversy prompted the formation of the eerily named Committee for Naming Facts, which supported Kazan and by association, the witchhunts themselves. That group was an offshoot of the Ayn Rand Institute, whose quasi-fascist founder herself made a memorable appearance before Huac as a friendly witness. Questioning the veracity of the wartime movie Mission to Moscow, she claimed that, unlike in the film: "In Russia, under communism, the children never smile."

Meanwhile the left fights tooth-and-nail to prevent the rehabilitation of the blacklist by the likes of William Buckley, who in his youth beseeched Evelyn Waugh to defend McCarthy in his National Review. Waugh told him to piss off, but Buckley persists even today. "There were no heroes, only victims," was Trumbo's verdict.

But there were also victors, politicians like Richard Nixon, who made his national reputation as a Huac committee member, as did Robert Kennedy - "a McCarthyite tough" in the words of his lifelong enemy, Gore Vidal. Ronald Reagan sold out his own union, the Screen Actors' Guild, by acquiescing to the blacklist with evangelical enthusiasm. The Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals was a headlong rush to the scaffold, the torchlit last reel of a Frankenstein movie - a pro-witchhunt, pro-blacklist group headed by the likes of John Wayne, Ward Bond (one of my very favourite actors, sadly), Gary Cooper, King Vidor, Victor Fleming, and Hedda Hopper, bitch-goddess of the mid-century fame game.

And there were the losers: the suicides, the exiles, people hounded out of work. Actor John Garfield drank himself to death because, as a friend said: "He was a guy from the streets, and he couldn't bear the idea of people in his neighbourhood yelling, 'There's the fuckin' stoolie!' Sterling Hayden, in a dilemma no one should ever have to face, named names after learning that custody of his children would be awarded to his mentally ill ex-wife if he didn't. He drank a lot after that, too. Can you blame him?

Could it happen again? Probably not, but it's worth bearing in mind that the nine writers who went to jail were not just some loose affiliation of, in the accusatory terminology of the day, "premature anti-fascists". They were the nine most active founders of the Screenwriters' Guild, the first effective, craftsman-controlled union to establish itself in Tinseltown. When they were jailed, the union was eviscerated and swiftly co-opted. So if the Writers' Guild fights rough in its May 2001 contract negotiations with studios and networks, it can cite some grim precedents to back it up.

Only three years ago, at a 50th anniversary commemoration of the Ten's appearance before Huac, the Hollywood studios finally made a collective apology for their craven acquiescence to the inquisition and the subsequent purge. That night Lardner finally got to read his 1947 statement, to resounding cheers. It was a bit late: of the Ten, only Lardner and Paul Jarrico were left, and Jarrico died the next day. A year later came the controversy over the lifetime achievement award presented to director Elia Kazan, who revolted his peers in 1952 by naming names to keep working. Rod Steiger remembered that learning of Kazan's capitulation "was like finding out my father was sleeping with my sister". Kazan has never apologised. And it was barely a year ago that the Academy belatedly restored writing credits to writers like Trumbo and Lardner, who had won Oscars for scripts written under fake identities. Or rather they hadn't won them, because at the time they were, in the land of the free, essentially Un-persons. Restitution took 50 years. The news was coolly received by two men and eight gravestones. Huac was indefensible, but that doesn't mean it's ever been short of defenders. The 1999 Kazan controversy prompted the formation of the eerily named Committee for Naming Facts, which supported Kazan and by association, the witchhunts themselves. That group was an offshoot of the Ayn Rand Institute, whose quasi-fascist founder herself made a memorable appearance before Huac as a friendly witness. Questioning the veracity of the wartime movie Mission to Moscow, she claimed that, unlike in the film: "In Russia, under communism, the children never smile." Meanwhile the left fights tooth-and-nail to prevent the rehabilitation of the blacklist by the likes of William Buckley, who in his youth beseeched Evelyn Waugh to defend McCarthy in his National Review. Waugh told him to piss off, but Buckley persists even today. "There were no heroes, only victims," was Trumbo's verdict. But there were also victors, politicians like Richard Nixon, who made his national reputation as a Huac committee member, as did Robert Kennedy - "a McCarthyite tough" in the words of his lifelong enemy, Gore Vidal. Ronald Reagan sold out his own union, the Screen Actors' Guild, by acquiescing to the blacklist with evangelical enthusiasm. The Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals was a headlong rush to the scaffold, the torchlit last reel of a Frankenstein movie - a pro-witchhunt, pro-blacklist group headed by the likes of John Wayne, Ward Bond (one of my very favourite actors, sadly), Gary Cooper, King Vidor, Victor Fleming, and Hedda Hopper, bitch-goddess of the mid-century fame game. And there were the losers: the suicides, the exiles, people hounded out of work. Actor John Garfield drank himself to death because, as a friend said: "He was a guy from the streets, and he couldn't bear the idea of people in his neighbourhood yelling, 'There's the fuckin' stoolie!' Sterling Hayden, in a dilemma no one should ever have to face, named names after learning that custody of his children would be awarded to his mentally ill ex-wife if he didn't. He drank a lot after that, too. Can you blame him? Could it happen again? Probably not, but it's worth bearing in mind that the nine writers who went to jail were not just some loose affiliation of, in the accusatory terminology of the day, "premature anti-fascists". They were the nine most active founders of the Screenwriters' Guild, the first effective, craftsman-controlled union to establish itself in Tinseltown. When they were jailed, the union was eviscerated and swiftly co-opted. So if the Writers' Guild fights rough in its May 2001 contract negotiations with studios and networks, it can cite some grim precedents to back it up.

webTitle: Bush camp: Relying on dad's old team

fields.headline: Relying on dad's old team
fields.standfirst:
George W plans his cabinet despite recount
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W plans his cabinet despite recount
fields.body:
While votes were still being counted in Florida yesterday, George W Bush adopted a presidential demeanour, summoning members of a "transition team" to the Texas governor's mansion to plan his move to the White House.

As the hours went by, the heavy iron gates at the mansion occasionally swung open for limousines carrying prospective members of a government team which showed strong signs of being a continuation of the last Bush administration, run by the governor's father.

Condoleezza Rice, a foreign policy adviser to the elder Bush, arrived in the morning to discuss the foreign policy team and possibly her future as national security adviser. Bush aides also told journalists to expect an announcement concerning the appointment of Colin Powell, a former four-star general and chairman of the joint chiefs of staff who is tipped for the job of secretary of state.

The focus on international affairs represented an extraordinary and deliberate display of self confidence on Mr Bush's part, at a time when world attention was focused on the intricacies and accidents of Florida's balloting practices.

Earlier visitors included Andy Card, a former lobbyist for the motor industry who was transportation secretary for Mr Bush's father, and who is now tipped to be chief of staff in a new Bush White House.

Dick Cheney, the vice-presidential candidate and former president George Bush's defence secretary, was put in charge of assembling the transition team which is supposed to pave the way for a smooth transfer of power in January.

When it came to choosing a tough political operator to go to Florida to promote George Bush's interests in the ballot recount, the campaign turned to James Baker, who served as secre tary of state and confidant to the candidate's father.

During the campaign, Governor Bush made as much effort to keep a distance from his father, as Al Gore did to stay away from Bill Clinton, especially after the elder Mr Bush referred to George W affectionately as his "boy" in an early campaign rally. But the governor's early, and possibly premature, appointments added weight to critics who said his election would amount to a Bush restoration.

Several observers also remarked on a change in Governor Bush's body language. When he emerged from the mansion on Wednesday to speak to reporters, he seemed to be making a deliberate effort to carry himself in a different manner from Bush the candidate.

His shoulders were held back and square, with none of his trademark shrugging. Also missing was his characteristic smirk. He spoke softly and calmly, using the sort of language normally reserved for victory speeches, thanking his opponent's supporters (who outnumbered his own across the country) for "their hard work and their belief in their cause".

"We feel very good about what our title will be in a couple of days," he said.

In the town of Crawford, Texas, where the Bush family owns a ranch, the local Baptist pastor, Mike Murphy, made no such assumptions.

The sign outside his church was amended yesterday morning to read: "Home of President George W Bush. Maybe."

fields.headline: Anatomy of an obsession
fields.standfirst: At the age of just 13  Peter Conrad  defied the law, his parents, his aunt and his schoolteachers - by sneaking into a cinema to watch a shocking new movie called Psycho. It was to be the beginning of a life-long fixation with the master of suspense
fields.trailText: At the age of just 13 Peter Conrad defied the law, his parents, his aunt and his schoolteachers - by sneaking into a cinema to watch a shocking new movie called Psycho. It was to be the beginning of a life-long fixation with the master of suspense
fields.body:
I cannot recall how my obsession with Hitchcock started; it goes back almost far enough to qualify as an original sin. But there is a specific date that solemnised the affair. One afternoon in 1961, aged all of 13, I lost my virginity at a screening of Psycho. Strictly speaking, it was only my innocence I lost. The technical loss came later, but you spend so long preparing for it - rehearsing the scenes in your head, starting with a jerky silent movie to which you gradually add dialogue - that by the time the occasion arrives, it is probably anti-climactic. Your graduation from innocence to experience occurs when the feverish business of imagining begins, and for me, this raid on a forbidden knowledge will always be associated with Psycho. During my first under-age exposure to the film, the images that thrilled me were those of trespass and guilty surveillance. This, surely, was why the cinema existed: to depict what you were not supposed to be looking at.

An aerodynamic peeping Tom hovers above a city, which drowses in the early-afternoon sun. The people in those faceless boxes are presumably working, or eating their lunch. No, not all of them. The camera, nosing the air suspiciously, swoops towards a certain window on an upper floor of a hotel, nudges the sill and sidles into the room, blinking at the contrast with the glare outside. The couple it spies on think they are safe from scrutiny because they are so high above street level, which is why they have left the blind half-lowered. Here, for a 13-year-old, was a first small and easily soluble mystery: why are they undressed at this time of day?

Psycho starts post-coitally, and leaves the preliminaries to be scripted by us. In 1961, when the world was still blissfully ignorant, you had to work harder. Hitchcock supplied hints, or brief glimpses. Knowing us only too well, he left us to design our own private storyboards. Later comes a view even more privileged than the mid-air assault on the hotel room. Through a peephole drilled in a wall at the motel, there is a momentary sight - curtailed just in time - of a woman unpeeling her bra.

By the end of the film, worked up into a state of high excitement, we are ready to imagine what Hitchcock does not even bother to show us. In the house on the hill, another explorer picks up a leather-bound book that has no title on its ornately-tooled spine. She opens it, and her eyes imperceptibly widen. We are not allowed to see what she has seen. Robert Bloch, in the novel that Hitchcock adapted, offers no particular help, merely confiding that the illustrations clamped inside the covers are "almost pathologically pornographic". It is a dare. When I became familiar with Hitchcock himself, after watching him eerily editorialising on his television series, I could hear his grave, glutinous voice mutter in a clinical description of the book's contents; but that was later, once my capacity to fantasise had come up to speed. Meanwhile, there beside a rumpled, tormented bed in the same room on the screen, was a collection of obsolete toys: a brutalised doll, a rabbit with a wilted ear - the relics of someone else's lost childhood.

On its long journey across the Pacific to Australia, and then on its second, even more tantalising trip from the mainland to the island state of Tasmania where I was born, Psycho had acquired an unwholesome reputation. We had just completed a decade of satisfied suburban niceness and compulsory normality. Since the prosperity of the 50s seemed too good to be true, no questions were to be asked, for fear that the illusion of affluent content might be revoked. My parents, having lived through a depression and a world war, were grateful for this oblivion. My own generation was bound to challenge it - and Hitchcock offered an early inducement.

How normal was Norman Bates, who, according to the psychiatrist in Robert Bloch's Psycho, enjoys an extra identity as Norma, inhabiting the stuffy persona and musty clothes of his own mother? An officious aunt warned my parents to ban me from seeing the film. "It's too hot for his blood," she said. Westerns were thought appropriate, because the violence in them offered a training in virility. But Psycho dealt with seamier matters, about which the grown-ups went into whispered conclave. The moralistic aunt claimed to know of someone who had already seen it in Sydney. He hadn't been able to sleep for a week afterwards, suffered screaming fits, and finally needed a prescription from the doctor. "And he," she said, "was a naval man!" That, supposedly, should have immunised him.

As it happened, there was no need for a parental embargo. The censors saw to this, branding the film with an M. That stood for Mature, which made Psycho all the more enticing. It was, as I soon enough found out, a film about ripening - and also about rotting. I was sure, consulting the physical evidence, that I could pass as mature. But, according to the aunt, you had to prove mental maturity as well, before they'd sell you a ticket; otherwise you risked permanent harm. In advance, Psycho had come to resemble a rite of passage, a visceral, constricted tunnel you had to pass through to get from one age to the next. Ingmar Bergman once imagined the breathless foreboding of those who buy tickets for a film - the audience, collectively tensed, says to itself: "Here I am, seated in the darkness, and, like a woman about to give birth, I want deliverance." Allowing for the transposition of sexes, that was what I required from Psycho. It was to be my blooding; a death from which I might, if I was lucky, recover, since the actual blood would be shed on my behalf by others - a woman whose body is slashed in a shower, a man whose brain is punctured as he climbs a staircase.

The week before Psycho arrived in town, I began to plan my strategy. The censor's certificate precluded a children's matinee on Saturday, and I was not allowed out of the house at night. What choice did I have? Playing truant from school, I intended to see it on a weekday afternoon. I would break the law, and tell lies to cover my trail. It was a life-changing decision. I was already behaving, if I had only known it, like the heroine of the film, who - after her own sweaty matinee in the hotel bedroom - asks her boss's permission to go home early. She then drives briskly out of town with the $40,000 he has given her to deposit at the bank. She feigns a headache: a feminine ailment, inappropriate for adolescent boys. Toothache was the excuse I chose, and I dramatised its onset when I bit into a lunchtime sandwich. Excused from school for the rest of the day, I wondered whether I might not have strayed into perilous territory. If acts had immediate consequences, as we were always being told by those who dosed us with the Bible, wasn't I goading one of my own teeth to ache? It might have made a neatly retributive plot for an episode of Alfred Hitchcock Presents, but in fact my teeth behaved themselves throughout the afternoon. The episode counted as one of my earliest and most valuable moral experiments, investigating how much it was possible to get away with.

I stuffed my school cap and blazer into the satchel that contained my books, and left it in the town library. The few blocks between there and the cinema had their dangers, like a snipers' alley. Ours was a small town, and I might have run into the invigilating aunt. Janet Leigh, after all, is spotted by her boss when she pauses at the traffic lights on her way out of Phoenix. To be 13 and at large so soon after lunch was itself an admission of guilt, like being an able-bodied civilian in wartime. Head down, I made it.

The cinema was called the Avalon; its name evoked chivalry and medieval enchantments, bravely defying the trams that clattered past and the odour of meat pies and pungent tomato sauce from the shop next door. A grim brick chapel stood opposite it, frowning. The lobby, to my surprise, was not barricaded against me. Shouldn't there have been barbed wire, or officials demanding the presentation of documents? In America, they had apparently hired guards to marshal the queues of ticket-holders, and played tapes of Hitchcock explaining why no one was allowed to enter the theatre after a screening of Psycho had begun. I almost expected an improvised infirmary for those who allegedly staggered out at the end, their nerves shredded. But, so far as I could see, no ambulance was standing by.

I cannot remember the rest of the experience without turning it into an anthology of Hitchcock clips, abbreviated excerpts from films I had not yet seen. The lobby elongated as I walked across it: an expressionistic camera trick, like the swooning zoom that opens a crevasse beneath James Stewart in Vertigo. Then there was the box office where a suspicious attendant behind the grille might call the police, which happens when Cary Grant - on the lam, like me - tries to buy a train ticket at Grand Central station in North by Northwest. Instead, a bored teenage girl glanced idly at me. Did I dry up, like Gregory Peck when he faces the ticket clerk at Pennsylvania station in Spellbound?

All he can blurt out is an absurd request for a ticket to Rome. What I said, I suppose, is: "One, please." Determined to cast off childhood, I did not ask for a child's discount. I got my ticket without trouble - but, as Joan Fontaine discovers in Rebecca when she bypasses the rusty, overgrown gate of Manderley, dreamers have an agility denied to those who remain awake, and can vault over obstacles. I was soon inside, in the darkness where the revelation, lit by a lunar beam from the projector, was due to occur.

Psycho did not disappoint me. I may not have understood all I saw, but I knew that taboos were being breached. What I didn't know was that Hitchcock omitted a few of the scabrous sights and thoughts with which Bloch's novel regales us. In the book, Norman tells himself not to make mental pictures of certain bodily parts, even though in erasing the images he admits the imagining he has already done. "Mother's thighs were dirty. Mustn't look," he says. Likewise he pointedly "never thought about Mother's breasts". When he transports his querulous parent to the fruit cellar, he reminds her that there's a pot for her use. "Norman," she croaks, "must you talk that way?" Despite these repressions, the film gave me plenty to think about.

After that first glimpse of avid tussling in a cheap hotel came the examination of a bathroom. For the first time in a film, someone flushed a toilet (though an incriminating scrap of paper, stained with a sum, remained behind in the bowl). There were confrontations, when I managed to unclench my eyes and look, with what ought to have remained invisible. Here was the featureless mask of an avenging deity: the traffic cop, inscrutable behind his dark glasses, or the shadowed figure with the slicing knife. At last I saw the face of death, leathery-skinned and laughing, with cavities where the eyes once were. I had been handed a psychological agenda for maturity, supplied with a lifetime's worth of bad dreams. I was definitely no longer innocent.

I retrieved my disguise as a schoolboy from the library cloakroom and went home by bus. I looked out of the back window in case a visored cop on a motorcycle should happen to be closing in, ready to arrest me for truancy or for knowing too much. Guilt, I discovered, is like a back-projection in a film: a nocturne in broad, indifferent daylight, cast on a blank screen. You can see it, because you are inside the trauma. Who else can? The sun still blandly shone, and objects beside the road were healthily flushed with colour, despite Psycho's bleached ceramic tiles and its muddy, heaving swamp. At home, our bathroom had only ordinary tales to tell: a comb with snagged teeth, the razor I would one day (as the maturing proceeded) have to scrape across my face, a Plimsoll line of soap scum around the tub.

But when I used the shower next morning, I found that it too had lost its innocence. The plastic curtain squealed in alarm when tugged on its metal rod. Hot icicles of water felt like needles, or dental drills. And the plughole, although the water swirled in a different direction in our hemisphere, announced that your life was leaking away even as you got yourself ready for another day at school.

Hitchcock took particular pleasure, I later learned, in estranging people from their bathrooms, which before Psycho were resorts of impregnable privacy, closets or cloisters where puritans purged themselves. He once claimed to have received a letter from a mother and father who blamed him for their daughter's insanitary state. Ever since seeing Henri-Georges Clouzot's Les Diaboliques, where the murderers drown their victim in a tub, she had refused to take a bath. Now, having been to Psycho, she flinched from the shower too. Hitchcock suggested that they should send her out to be dry-cleaned. It was an old joke, freshly adapted to America, where your clothes at least could be cleansed without immersion in water.

In Blackmail, the first of Hitchcock's British talking pictures, a London gossip - a woman whose stale face powder and flustered perspiration you can almost smell - prattles on in a shop about a local stabbing, unaware that the heroine has committed the crime. The case reminds her, she says, of a recent murder where the man was drowned in his tub. For a month, she was too frightened to have a bath; then for weeks after that she wouldn't go beyond a rinse-down. Listening, you tighten your nostrils in sympathy with the other customers in the shop.

Psycho infected me - and how many others? - with a mistrust of motels, which institutionalise our transitoriness. Even in hotels, I tread carefully in case I step on the nail-clippings of former occupants, embedded in the carpet piles, and try not to notice stray hairs in the bathtub. Surely the maids protest too much when they place those paper seals on the toilet seat, pretending that you have had no predecessors. The terrors are not confined to the bathroom. In Hitchcock's films, the most innocuous object can rear up threateningly. What could possibly be sinister about the record of Beethoven's Eroica, which Vera Miles finds on a gramophone turntable during her investigation of the Bates house? At the age of 13, I had no idea - though I felt an unmistakable chill when the camera peered into the gaping box to read the label of the silent disc. Now I think I know the answer.

The symphony summarises one abiding undercurrent of Hitchcock's work. It is about Napoleon, a man who - like many of Hitchcock's psychopaths - set himself up as a god, and it includes a funeral march for the toppled idol. It first rejoices in the hero's freedom from moral inhibitions, then recoils in dismay. Truffaut, detecting unease beneath the joviality of The Trouble with Harry, suggested that Hitchcock's films were afflicted by the mood Blaise Pascal analysed - "the sadness of a world deprived of God".

Gradually I came to understand Hitchcock's surreal genius: he knew how to rescind reality, and to make you afraid. "I brought you nightmares," whispers Joseph Cotten as the wicked uncle in Shadow of a Doubt, pleased to have upset a soporific town not unlike the one I lived in. Other founding fathers had higher-minded hopes for the new art of film. DW Griffith set out to make heaven visible from the lowly earth, and Chaplin's tramp mutely appealed to the brotherhood of man. Hitchcock, however, was no evangelist. He wanted to frighten us. Those who consider themselves invulnerable call this trivial or childish; to me, fear is the most rational response to existence, and the most reverent tribute to its irrationality.

I caught sight of Hitchcock once, while he was filming Frenzy in London's Covent Garden market during the summer of 1970. A crowd of technicians and anachronistic cockney porters surged around the buttoned-up blob in the sagging canvas chair. This unmoved mover hardly seemed to be directing; he just lumpily sat there and watched other people do things - mostly carting bags of vegetables, one of which might have contained a dead body. By then he did not need to bestir himself. He had succeeded in deliciously terrorising the world; and all of us, whether within the camera's range or not, were acting in the nightmare he had devised.

Having once been let out to play, the demons refuse to retire indoors. They prefer to take part in murderous charades, quoting Psycho with triumphant bravado. In 1998, the BBC paid OJ Simpson for a television interview. He indignantly insisted that he had not slaughtered his wife and her friend, then addressed a sideways smirk to the camera. Parting from the interviewer, Ruby Wax, he said he had a surprise for her, and promised to deliver it later. When the bell rang, she opened the door of her hotel room. There loomed OJ, his arm raised, emitting a series of staccato shrieks: he was tunelessly winging Bernard Herrmann's score for the shower scene in Psycho, with its fraught strings, while he lowered his arm to stab her. His weapon? Not Mrs Bates's knife, but a banana purloined from one of the hotel's hospitality baskets.

I had already performed my own version of this scene on a return visit to my parents in Australia. The episode did not quite follow Hitchcock's storyboard. I was in the shower one morning when I heard a fumbling at the bathroom door. Surely, I thought, the sound of running water safeguarded my privacy; but the door opened, and a shape positioned itself on the other side of the translucent curtain. A hand reached up, the curtain squeaked, and so (I am ashamed to say) did I. It was my father who stood there, neatly reversing roles for both of us. He held not a knife but a pair of over-sized carrots that he had dug up in his vegetable garden. Their tips were jagged, and he kept a strangling grip on their green top knots. They might have been a brace of downed game birds.

He blinked, even more startled than I was. "I thought it was your mother," he said; it seems he wanted to show her his carrots. At the time I remember wondering why that couldn't wait. The disinterred vegetables hadn't even shaken off their shroud of dirt. Now the incident seems touchingly matrimonial, proof of the intimacy my parents enjoyed with one another but not with me. I tugged the curtain back into place, and I suppose he took his carrots to the bedroom.

No blood was spilled, but I'm not sure that there was a happy ending. My father, who never saw Psycho, died soon afterwards. Those few seconds in the shower were as frank a conversation as we ever had. I still shudder when I think of it, and the chill is supernatural, like the fear that Hitchcock induces. For the ancient Greeks, the symptoms - prickling skin, an involuntary shock - warned that you were in the vicinity of a god. My parents explained such sensations according to their own more or less pagan theology. Someone, they used to say, is walking over your grave. And where, I always asked myself, might that resting place be? Psycho offered a choice: the white tub, so easy to scrub clean, or the black, gluttonous bog that gobbled cars and the bodies buried in them. Or, if you preferred, the cellar in which the fruit matured.

At the Universal studios theme parks in Los Angeles and Orlando, a facsimile of the Psycho set is a place of pilgrimage. The queues for admission to the traumatic bathroom are always long. Visitors line up to borrow Mrs Bates's smock and her hairnet, which come in all sizes. Suitably attired, you are then issued with a rubber knife and directed to slash a Universal studios intern, who modestly showers in a body stocking.

The duplication on opposite coasts recognises a ravenous public demand. Everyone, it seems, has spent some time at the Bates motel - or would like to do so. On arrival, a film we know by heart assigns us our moves. After depositing our worldly goods in a cabin, we go for a stroll. There is only one route to take, since the set ends just out of the viewfinder's range. Inevitably, we climb the path towards the family home on the hill. Of course it has a different use nowadays. That ghoulish house, with the silhouetted body in the window like a figure at a magic-lantern show, is a cinema. Inside it, we are licensed to dream.

 Taken from The Hitchcock Murders by Peter Conrad, published by Faber & Faber Ltd on 20 November at £16.99. © Peter Conrad 2000
