webTitle: Comment: In defence of the Christian religion

fields.headline: In defence of the Christian religion
fields.standfirst:
The liberal left's patronising jibes about Christianity are misguided

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The liberal left's patronising jibes about Christianity are misguided.
fields.body:
When it comes to Christianity the English liberal left get cross and sound crass. Typical of its intolerance and ignorance was a recent column here by the crime writer Joan Smith. Christianity, she informed us, was "infantile" and clerics tell "fairy stories". When it comes to "explaining" Christianity, Smith, like others of her tribe, produces Janet and Joan history - patronising and simplistic.

Christianity may be true. It may be false. But it is always serious. And its opponent needs a sense of why it has been so successful. Otherwise, the past looks completely baffling - a territory inhabited by only two kinds of people: the dupes who were credulous and the scoundrels who manipulated the con trick.

Cheap jibes at fairy stories miss the point that Christianity scandalised by subverting consoling myths. The Christians demythologised Jupiter and his gang. That is why many decent pagans blamed them for the fall of Rome - an empire and a city deprived of the gods' protection. But it is the Christian view of power that the English liberal left parodies most insistently.

Christian politics invented the idea of human rights and rubbished the classical belief that slavery was "natural". It inherited from Aristotle the idea of a natural law common to all humanity. Aquinas developed the vocabulary. The natural law was not just something which protected the church's self-interest. It was a corrective, a higher principle, which could measure the imperfect, variable laws of particular states.

Modern international law incorporating human rights is a Christian gift. The Spanish priest-theologians who accompanied the expeditions to 16th century Latin America are its founding fathers. They told the conquerors that the natives, being God's children, had natural rights and should not be enslaved. Having lost that battle on the ground, their heirs won the polemical war of books and pamphlets.

Early Christianity was ambiguous about slavery. It always forbad Christians from being the slaves of non-Christians but it took time - and reaction to Viking practice - for this to be seen as a universal goal. Still, the record is better than Islam's. And the comparable example of Hinduism with its sacralisation of caste has been an Indian disaster.

By establishing Christianity as a state religion, Emperor Constantine started a long and murky story of church collusion with state power. But polemical self-righteousness about the craven and the equivocal miss the plot. Prophecy has a habit of breaking out. For every cardboard cut-out Borgia cardinal there is an army of Bonhoeffers to tell truth to power.

Catholic Christianity has been particularly powerful as a critic of capitalism. Pope John Paul is both leftwing economist and social conservative. This is disturbing for English liberals who want all arguments to cohere. But the Catholic trade union has been the making of the European social policy whose language of corporate rights has recast English politics.

Christianity was a terrible event for the classical world, with its cosy view of the state. The city was the focus of loyalties - a home for the gods and the family alike. But the new faith said that loyalty to the earthly city was purely provisional. This was unnerving - hence the persecutions. Our "right of conscience" descends from the Christian refusal to worship emperors.

The very idea of progress is a Christian invention. Fortune's wheel ever-revolving in set combinations is a classical idea. But if God has come into the world once - and may do so again - then the present and future begin to be open to possibility. Compared to Islam (after the Crusades) Christianity was the more intellectually adventurous religion. Islam conflated the secular order with the religious one - and so was stultified. Hence "the rise of the west" and the long Ottoman decline.

" Leiden, Leiden; Kreuz, Kreuz," thundered Luther to some simpleton who informed him that life was about happiness. This is a deep divide. For Christians the world is that tragic story of suffering and the Cross. You ought to try to improve it - but don't get cocky and assume you'll get it right. Pessimists fearing the worst can still have fun. Optimists assuming the best can end up as disillusioned cynics. Christians fall into the first category - duly sceptical of all political utopias whether new right (now buried) or New Labour (now faded).

Christian apologetics has its shallow felicities: today's bread and suffering explained smoothly away so jam may arrive on the providential morrow. But even at this complacent worst Christians do not resemble the disfiguring fiction of English liberal fantasy - a substitute for knowledge and an opportunity for vulgar abuse.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: It was perhaps unfair to describe the Chinook shown on page 10 yesterday, as an "army helicopter". The army do not fly Chinooks but the RAF do.
fields.body:
It was perhaps unfair to describe the Chinook shown on page 10 yesterday, as an "army helicopter". The army do not fly Chinooks but the RAF do.

In an article headed "Matt, you are the weakest link. Goodbye", page 16, G2, November 8, we rather embarrassingly referred to CP Scott as the "founder" of the Guardian. The Manchester Guardian first appeared on Saturday, May 5, 1821. CP Scott did not become editor until New Year's Day, 1872. He carried on until 1929.

On page 4, Online, yesterday, Jane Austen, became Jane Austin.

The picture accompanying the obituary of Dick Morrissey, page 28, yesterday, was wrongly credited. It was taken by David Sinclair. Apologies.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: More Brown than green
fields.trailText: Congratulations to the Guardian for being the only broadsheet that recognises the tax reductions for low sulphur fuel are "completely justified on environmental grounds"
fields.body:
Congratulations to the Guardian for being the only broadsheet that recognises the tax reductions for low sulphur fuel are "completely justified on environmental grounds" (Leader, November 9). In contrast, the claim by Greenpeace that low sulphur fuels are not green fuels is hypocritical nonsense.

The fuel will be mandatory across the European Union in 2005 as a result of a 1998 directive that environmental groups campaigned for. Indeed the author of the legislation in the European parliament was Heidi Hautala who is the leader of the green MEPs.

Ultra-low sulphur petrol can deliver an immediate reduction in toxic emissions by as much as 17% and is essential for the introduction of new engine technologies, such as direct injection engines that will increase fuel economy by 25%.

In the 1990s, tax reductions encouraged the use of unleaded petrol and the same will be true for ultra-low sulphur. Until yesterday, hardly anyone knew about low sul phur fuel. As a result of the government's action they will now start to demand a fuel that will improve air quality and encourage the car industry's development of more fuel efficient engines. It beggars belief that Greenpeace can oppose it.
David Ward
Federation Internationale De L'Automobile
 OK, low sulphur petrol will improve air quality, tax relief spur brownfield use and Gordon Brown did say the word "environment" a record 13 times. But there was nothing in his budget to cut climate pollution, curb car travel, boost renewable energies, or help farmers go organic. Why no windfall tax on big oil's obscene profits? Even the last Tory government introduced one at this stage of the electoral cycle. Shell, Exxon et al are making billions from making climate change worse.

These polluter-pays revenues should fund Britain's fledgeling off-shore wind and solar industries and create green manufacturing jobs. Why no tax breaks to encourage motorists to buy low- carbon fuels, or genuinely fuel-efficient vehicles? That helps rural drivers the most. Calor Gas is converting one petrol station a day to stock liquified gas. The case of lead-free petrol shows alternative fuels must be much cheaper for drivers to switch. Why no pesticide tax, which the Treasury has privately approved? If rated against use and toxicity, it would hit large-scale farmers - who get the bulk of production-based subsidies - hardest.

Recycling this money to help impoverished farmers meet the soaring demand for organic produce would improve their finances much more than cutting vehicle excise duty on tractors. Two weeks ago, the prime minister warned about the global environmental crisis and promised to push environmental issues high up his political agenda.

Next week, the crucial climate change summit opens in the Hague.

The chancellor had a fantastic opportunity to support the economy and the environment, and back Labour's fine words with action. He blew it.
Charles Secrett
Director, Friends of the Earth

I rely on my 1600cc car to get to work, am in a works pension scheme and don't have enough spare to indulge in share buying. As a result, the chancellor's statement offers me nothing from the surplus he has built up on my taxes.

Will the government please offer some return to the wage-earning backbone of the country. Or are we the cash cow to feed Gordon's friend Prudence?
Bob Floyd
Glasgow

fields.bodyText: Congratulations to the Guardian for being the only broadsheet that recognises the tax reductions for low sulphur fuel are "completely justified on environmental grounds" (Leader, November 9). In contrast, the claim by Greenpeace that low sulphur fuels are not green fuels is hypocritical nonsense. The fuel will be mandatory across the European Union in 2005 as a result of a 1998 directive that environmental groups campaigned for. Indeed the author of the legislation in the European parliament was Heidi Hautala who is the leader of the green MEPs. Ultra-low sulphur petrol can deliver an immediate reduction in toxic emissions by as much as 17% and is essential for the introduction of new engine technologies, such as direct injection engines that will increase fuel economy by 25%. In the 1990s, tax reductions encouraged the use of unleaded petrol and the same will be true for ultra-low sulphur. Until yesterday, hardly anyone knew about low sul phur fuel. As a result of the government's action they will now start to demand a fuel that will improve air quality and encourage the car industry's development of more fuel efficient engines. It beggars belief that Greenpeace can oppose it. David Ward Federation Internationale De L'Automobile  OK, low sulphur petrol will improve air quality, tax relief spur brownfield use and Gordon Brown did say the word "environment" a record 13 times. But there was nothing in his budget to cut climate pollution, curb car travel, boost renewable energies, or help farmers go organic. Why no windfall tax on big oil's obscene profits? Even the last Tory government introduced one at this stage of the electoral cycle. Shell, Exxon et al are making billions from making climate change worse. These polluter-pays revenues should fund Britain's fledgeling off-shore wind and solar industries and create green manufacturing jobs. Why no tax breaks to encourage motorists to buy low- carbon fuels, or genuinely fuel-efficient vehicles? That helps rural drivers the most. Calor Gas is converting one petrol station a day to stock liquified gas. The case of lead-free petrol shows alternative fuels must be much cheaper for drivers to switch. Why no pesticide tax, which the Treasury has privately approved? If rated against use and toxicity, it would hit large-scale farmers - who get the bulk of production-based subsidies - hardest. Recycling this money to help impoverished farmers meet the soaring demand for organic produce would improve their finances much more than cutting vehicle excise duty on tractors. Two weeks ago, the prime minister warned about the global environmental crisis and promised to push environmental issues high up his political agenda. Next week, the crucial climate change summit opens in the Hague. The chancellor had a fantastic opportunity to support the economy and the environment, and back Labour's fine words with action. He blew it. Charles Secrett Director, Friends of the Earth I rely on my 1600cc car to get to work, am in a works pension scheme and don't have enough spare to indulge in share buying. As a result, the chancellor's statement offers me nothing from the surplus he has built up on my taxes. Will the government please offer some return to the wage-earning backbone of the country. Or are we the cash cow to feed Gordon's friend Prudence? Bob Floyd Glasgow floyds@ntlworld.com

fields.headline: Booker delicacy
fields.trailText: The Loafer made a kind offer (Review, November 4) to eat John McCririck's hat if Margaret Atwood were to win the Booker prize.
fields.body:
The Loafer made a kind offer (Review, November 4) to eat John McCririck's hat if Margaret Atwood were to win the Booker prize. May we know the venue for this forthcoming attraction and which particular hat of Mr McCririck will be consumed (Atwood takes Booker prize, November 8)?
David Rennie
Cardiff  I have spotted another alarming imbalance on your letters page. Can it be that Mike Rennie of Dundee who wrote to complain about the preponderance of letters from professors (November 8) is the same as Michael Rennie of Dundee (Letters, October 30) or indeed Professor Michael Rennie of Dundee University, a regular contributor to the page?

fields.headline: Torn in the USA
fields.trailText: Misleading ballots, late-arriving or missing ballot boxes, a recount in the hands of the brother of one of the challengers and the popular winner denied the prize (Is this the president? November 9)
fields.body:
Misleading ballots, late-arriving or missing ballot boxes, a recount in the hands of the brother of one of the challengers and the popular winner denied the prize (Is this the president? November 9). Why does it all sound so strangely familiar? Perhaps because these are exactly the kind of electoral practices encouraged in central America during the 80s by Reagan and Bush the elder.
Mark Lunt
Bristol, Connecticut fnords@earthlink.net

 Isn't it a bit worrying that a man who wishes to hold the most powerful office in the world is prepared to make a critical decision without first establishing the facts?
Tim Todd
Abingdon, Oxon

 With its declamatory last line, "Meet the new boss, same as the old boss", The Who's Won't Get Fooled Again is a curiously inappropriate choice of song for the Republican party. I'd go with Fast Cars by The Buzzcocks: "Sooner or later, you're gonna listen to Ralph Nader."
Jeremy Wallis
Ashwell, Herts

 Perhaps Jonathan Freedland (Missing you already Bill, G2, November 7) and the rest of your chorus of Clinton praise-singers will now explain to us why so great and progressive a president has proved to have such short coat-tails. How come the political legacy of this "president with towering political skills and a serious intellect" will be the Republicans still in control of Congress and probably a rich-boy dimwit in the White House?
Prof Alex Callinicos
University of York

fields.headline: Knives out over bent spoons
fields.trailText: I read your Pass Notes (November 6) and chuckled. It is difficult to think of a more useless ability than spoon bending.
fields.body:
I read your Pass Notes (November 6) and chuckled. It is difficult to think of a more useless ability than spoon bending. Mr Geller (Letters, November 8) states that his spoon bending has been verified by eminent scientists including Nobel prize winner Professor Brian Josephson.

There was one peer-reviewed journal article concerning spoon bending, in Nature in 1974, which could not report any psychic metal bending. Spoon bending is a simple party trick that anybody can learn. Details of this and other paranormal effects can be found in my recent book, The Psychology of the Psychic.

As your Pass Notes stated, Mr Geller is highly litigious. His only answer to my open letter in 1999 was a threat of legal action.
Prof David Marks
City University, London
 My late uncle (who was a magician) could reproduce Uri Geller's metal-bending demonstrations. Unlike Geller, he did not claim psychic powers, but freely admitted that he was performing a magic trick. Being a member of the Magic Circle, he would not let me into the secret of how it was done, but he did say he knew more than one way of doing it.
Jason Hill
Stoke-on-Trent
Jason@burslen.demon.co.uk

 Before your arrogant and sceptical journalists refute my claim, I should point out that this phenomenon has been observed under laboratory conditions (the Queen's Head, Ealing) by eminent scientists (my mates, Phil and Clive). See you in court!
Paul Bzowski
Harrow, Middx

fields.headline: What counts
fields.trailText:
This week, hundreds of organisations from around the world have gathered in New York for the UN conference, Financing for Development. The debate will focus on the crucial issue of how the international community will find the money to finance economic, social and human development in the south. The UN, World Bank, IMF, and world leaders will meet next year to discuss the same issues. The conference provides a real opportunity to discuss the reform of international economic decision-making. Given your coverage of the US election, which involves only 5% of the world's population (Letters, November 8), will you now start a debate on what global institutions are needed for the 21st century, to ensure we live in a truly transparent and democratically accountable world, as advocated by Charter 99?
Glenys Kinnock MEP
gkinnock@europarl.eu.int

fields.headline: Lessons for Britain's voting system
fields.trailText: The US elections have demonstrated the rising importance of electronic campaigning.
fields.body:
The US elections have demonstrated the rising importance of electronic campaigning. On this side of the pond the prospect of e-voting raises many questions for UK businesses, unions and the government. At Electoral Reform Ballot Services we have just completed the first major ballot in the UK with an e-voting option for the 400,000 members of MSF. We were keen to see if a large proportion of voters would use it.

Unfortunately the take up was disappointingly low, as it has been for the many ballots and surveys we have carried out using other technological innovations such as telephone voting. Current evidence clearly indicates that the overwhelming majority of people still prefer to use the post and the use of postal voting in recent local govern ment pilot schemes had a significant impact on turnout. Of course it is to be hoped that this may change and all institutions must ensure that participation is as easy and widely available as possible.

While internet voting is another tool that can help improve access to democracy, it is not, in itself, the answer to low turnouts. E-voting is now rightly on the agenda, but if our political masters want to avoid costly errors they need to ensure that decisions over its future use are based on hard facts and not hype from the dot.com industry.
Owen Thomas
Chief executive, Electoral Reform Ballot Services PBates@marketforce-communications.co.uk

 It is commonly said that the great virtues of first-past-the- post are the ability to deliver a clear result and to give power to the party winning the largest number of votes. In the American presidential election, it has conspicuously failed to deliver either of these things. Moreover, it is its second failure in 43 attempts. The system is much less reliable than it is made out to be.
Conrad Russell
Electoral Reform Society

 We are sure that there are many countries around the world (Cuba, Sudan or Nicaragua, perhaps?) who would be more than willing to send a team of impartial observers to help ensure that future American elections are free and fair.
David Grandy, Duncan Price & Steve Warrington
Loughborough University
D.B.Grandy@lboro.ac.uk

fields.headline: Our island
fields.trailText: As a result of the fairness and justice of the British legal system, I am very much looking forward to leading my people back to the Chagos Islands
fields.body:
As a result of the fairness and justice of the British legal system, I am very much looking forward to leading my people back to the Chagos Islands (Scandal of Diego Garcia, November 4). We believe that if the British public had known of these unlawful deportations at the time, we would probably still be living on the islands now.

There is a lesson for our community, that we must learn to stand on our own feet and insist that we are consulted during the process leading to our return. We must never again rely upon governments to tell us what we should have or not have. Because our community is shattered by our experiences, we need to organise ourselves with an administration and the ability to stand up and be heard. For this purpose, our solicitors, Sheridans, have set up the Ilois Support Trust.
Oliver Bancoult
Chairman, Chagos Refugees Group MGifford@sheridans.co.uk

webTitle: Comment: Europe must have its own constitution

fields.headline: A European Magna Carta
fields.standfirst:
Daniel Cohn-Bendit has a dream: that the president of the European commission should be elected by us

Special report: the European commission
Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: Daniel Cohn-Bendit has a dream: that the president of the European commission should be elected by us.
fields.body:
If Europe is to achieve a position in keeping with its role in history it cannot just remain a trading community for states, with glaring social differences. If Europe wants to go on keeping the peace, upholding social justice, freedom, citizen's rights, while maintaining a balanced environment and overall stability, it is not enough just to accept new countries. It must work to achieve even greater integration of its members.

To achieve this, Europe must have its own constitution. I am quite convinced that a constitution will not contribute in any way to making "Eurocrats" stronger. On the contrary it is necessary, indeed essential, for Europe to serve its peoples and cultures.

There should be two sides to a European constitution. First, Europeans must agree on the direction that they want their life in the community to take. They must decide which values are fundamental, the linchpins of everything that characterise a common European identity - from the promises of peace and economic unity expressed by the fathers and mothers of Europe, to the guarantee of a welfare state. This agreement would be a sort of Magna Carta, a European statement of fundamental values and rights. This charter should be more daring and inventive than the one we are offered at present.

Second, Europe needs a plan explaining how the project is to work. If we do nothing to change the current situation the principle of unanimous agreement, the role of the council of the European Union, or council of ministers, the rule determining the number of commissioners (which cannot exceed a certain limit without paralysing the work of the commission), the role of the European parliament and the court of justice - we will run straight into a dead end.

A draft constitution could be produced between now and 2005, just before we welcome new member states. Indeed it is absolutely essential, for without structural changes, the European Union, which is already in trouble, would be quite unable to cope with the arrival of new countries.

But how can Europe move forward? How can it avoid paralysis? Does it really stand a chance of carrying off this project successfully? I would suggest the following approach: legislative power in Europe could be invested in two chambers - the first would be the European parliament, elected directly by the people of Europe. The legislative authority of this body would be such that it could debate and decide all the issues affecting European interests -but no more than that. In other words, the principle of subsidiarity would be upheld and anything that did not fall within the scope of its authority would be the responsibility of national or regional assemblies. There can be no exceptions to this rule.

We know from experience that politicians have an unfortunate tendency to overstep their prerogatives. There must therefore be some way of holding them in check. A second chamber should, I believe, be able to provide this control. The members of the second chamber would not be elected by direct suffrage, but selected from representatives of national and regional assemblies. Like the US Senate, this chamber should be based on a system of equal rather than proportional representation, not directly related to the size of the population of each country. Its main job would be to represent the interests of the various member states.

The two assemblies are not designed to represent national governments. On the contrary they would comprise members of national or regional assemblies elected directly by the people. Not only would this situation enhance their democratic legitimacy, but also it would encourage electors to identify with their representatives. In its capacity as the repository of judicial power and the guardian of the European constitution, the European court of justice must affirm its position as the guardian of EU construction. In particular it should ensure that both assemblies comply with their constitutional prerogatives and it should protect citizens' rights.

In this way European government could play a prominent role. It could concentrate on truly European issues, rather than being hemmed in by national interests. This would be the real difference between the Europe of tomorrow and what we see today. At present the council of ministers is the de facto government of the EU. But the council is just a body representing national interests! This is made possible by a fable, according to which ministers defend national interests against an invisible intruder called "Europe". In fact they are the only actors in this farce. For example, complex, potentially problematic decisions - such as agricultural policy - are taken by the council. Ministers return home after summit meetings and explain that "Brussels" has once again taken some unreasonable decision.

A commission, with more extensive powers, should take over from the council. But it will need to think along truly European lines. It will have to break out of a system under which policy is decided to suit individual states andstart to serve Europe as a whole. This change will require radical reforms, to ensure that commissioners are no longer the delegates of national governments. In terms of legitimacy it is not enough just to be appointed. Commissioners must also have genuine democratic authority. The government of Europe must also stop concentrating on exclusively administrative issues and fulfil a political function. A powerful, active government of this kind, acting in the name of common European interests and with the same standing as national governments, or perhaps even greater importance, needs to be approved by the citizens of Europe. This could be achieved in two ways.

The president of the commission could be elected by universal suffrage. This system could involve the election of an electoral college representing the various member states on a proportional basis. The US example is worth considering in this context. The authority of the president has a democratic basis. He or she has no say in the affairs of individual states, but is empowered to take decisions on foreign policy, security, the environment and social policy.

Alternatively, a proportional vote could be organised using transnational, European electoral registers. At the European elections, people would have two votes, one for the members of the European parliament, the other for the president of the commission.

In this way the leader of the party polling the largest number of votes would become the EU president. After consulting the council of ministers, the president could form a government, the seat of executive power, and ask the European parliament for its approval.

For me, Europe is a vision, a dream, perhaps even one of the few remaining forms of Utopia for which it is still worth fighting. I am convinced that the notion of "constitutional patriotism" - to borrow an expression used by Jürgen Habermas about Germany - has considerable significance in the case of Europe. Deliberate, shared support for the principles and rules laid down in the constitution could unite Europeans and forge a sense of identity.

I am consequently convinced that the debate on the constitution, and the voting it would involve, are essential steps in the process of building a new Europe. The discussions, in which I hope everyone will take part, can only contribute to promoting greater awareness and political identification. In this respect I am a European, indeed a constitutional "patriot".

Daniel Cohn-Bendit is a Green member of the European parliament. This is extracted from an article in Le Monde. Translation by Harry Forster.

For me, Europe is a vision, a dream, perhaps even one of the few remaining forms of Utopia for which it is still worth fighting. I am convinced that the notion of "constitutional patriotism" - to borrow an expression used by Jürgen Habermas about Germany - has considerable significance in the case of Europe. Deliberate, shared support for the principles and rules laid down in the constitution could unite Europeans and forge a sense of identity. I am consequently convinced that the debate on the constitution, and the voting it would involve, are essential steps in the process of building a new Europe. The discussions, in which I hope everyone will take part, can only contribute to promoting greater awareness and political identification. In this respect I am a European, indeed a constitutional "patriot". Daniel Cohn-Bendit is a Green member of the European parliament. This is extracted from an article in Le Monde. fields.headline: Duller dome
fields.trailText: Well done to our boys in blue for foiling the evil machinations of those daylight robbers at the Millennium Dome
fields.body:
Well done to our boys in blue for foiling the evil machinations of those daylight robbers at the Millennium Dome (The great dome robbery, November 8). We can all sleep a little easier knowing that the heinous architect of this desperate plot and his bumbling lieutenant are safely locked away. Still, I can't help thinking that life will be a little duller without "Mad" Mandy Mandelson and Lord "Fingers" Falconer roaming our streets.
Damon Pattison
Kimpton, Herts

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 As if dealing with the peace process wasn't enough, O'Mandy Mandelson faces trouble in his capacity as president of Hartlepool FC. The club is in turmoil over an incident involving 7ft-tall mascot H'Angus the Monkey. The cuddly ape is loved in the Third Division for antics such as rugby tackling photographers. However, when during the half-time lottery draw at Scunthorpe recently, he started simulating sex with a 35-year-old female employee, it was felt he had taken the cause of amusing the crowd too far. H'Angus (we are asked not to mention real names, lest young fans who think the monkey is real become upset) was frog-marched from the ground while much of the 3,400 crowd cheered. "It was beyond a joke," says a spokesman. "He was gyrating behind her in front of a section of the crowd full of lads. The mascot offered to apologise but she just wanted rid of him." Although police have not been involved, H'Angus is banned from returning to Scunthorpe on November 18 when the teams meet again in the FA Cup.

 There is no room for more news of Michael Henderson's letter writing, People editor Neil Wallis's renewed marriage vows, or Carry On Up the Cabinet. All will appear next week.

 Publishers may wish to bid for my new thriller. It opens in early 2010 when the hero, a limey hack holidaying in Florida, pulls over by an alligator- infested swamp and finds, lapping up against the edge, a rectangular metallic box, heavily-rusted and containing enough pieces of paper to have changed the course of history. A day later, President Jeb Bush takes a call in the Oval Office. "Mr President," drawls the director of the FBI, "we have a situation down in Florida ..." Offers to the Diary, please, but don't waste my time with anything in five figures.

 It was a relief to hear BBC political editor Andy Marr explaining why, far from being a fiasco, this election was a triumph for US democracy. Until then, I'd been baffled into seeing something anti-democratic about the man with the fewer votes winning; or, indeed, the presidency being decided by 3,000 elderly Jewish voters who were bamboozled by a Florida ballot paper into voting for a far-rightist. Thank God Andy sorted it all out.

 The Telegraph did its share of sneering at media companies which prematurely rushed the result into print. Meanwhile, the Spectator cover reveals that "Mark Steyn sees Bush win by a whisker". Taki-George is on form too. "My fearless predictions are as follows," writes the Cypriot. "Gore wins the electoral college by a mile, and is congratulated by George W Bush, who just might have a chance to win the popular vote." You can't buy expertise like that.

 Finally on this for now, hats off to two House of Representatives candidates. Tennessee's third district went to the best-named man in US politics: Zach Wamp, a Republican with 139,661 votes (64%). Slightly less successful in Texas's seventh district was independent John R Skone-Palmer. He scored 0% of the vote, and 0 votes. Why he didn't bother to vote for himself is one of several things we hope to discuss with him soon.

 Independent on Sunday editor Janet Street-Porter suffers a mini-mutiny over a Salman Rushdie column lashing the previous week's news report about calls for him to lose police protection. Staff queenily threatened to injunct, but claim (with gratuitous sexism, we suspect) that they couldn't discuss it with Janet on Saturday morning because she was at the hairdresser's. The piece appeared, home editor Barry Hugill has departed, and legal threats fill the air. High drama indeed.

 Sub-editing at the Catholic Herald continues to impress. "Two New Religious Bishops" runs a headline on page three.

webTitle: 21 dead as Jakarta cracks down on separatists

fields.headline: 21 dead as Jakarta cracks down on separatists
fields.standfirst:
Police open fire on independence supporters trying to get through roadblocks to attend a rally in the Indonesian province of Aceh

Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Police open fire on independence supporters trying to get through roadblocks to attend a rally in the Indonesian province of Aceh.
fields.body:
Indonesian security forces have killed at least 21 people across the restive province of Aceh in the last two days in a bid to prevent tens of thousands of people descending on the provincial capital, Banda Aceh, for a massive pro-independence rally tomorrow.

Faisal Hadi, a coordinator of human rights groups in Aceh, said that in addition to the deaths 101 people had been injured in incidents in the province, on the northern tip of Sumatra. "It is clear the police and army were prepared to do anything to stop people reaching Banda Aceh for the rally," he said.

He said some fatalities were caused when convoys of trucks and cars refused to turn round at police roadblocks. Others were shot when they tried to reach the city by boat. "Police opened fire into the crowds while they were at sea and also trying to dock. There was no way they could miss."

The police admit to shooting 13 people dead, "in self- defence", but reputable human rights organisations monitoring events say the final death toll could be more than 40 once their staff have checked reports from remote areas.

Activists organising the rally put the death toll at over 100 but their figures have always been inflated in the past.

Local television showed graphic footage of people fleeing several different incidents and badly injured men, women and children being carried away for treatment.

Agus Suwandi, the local leader of Indonesia's Commission for Victims of Violence, said the true death toll would be "way higher" than what could be confirmed. "Based on what we're hearing I reckon many more than 40 people have been killed in the last two days."

News of the killings came as the Indonesian government announced that it would meet representatives of the Free Aceh Movement (Gam) guerrillas in Switzerland next week to discuss a possible solution to the separatist crisis that has been rumbling in the province for several decades and has left thousands of people dead.

The security forces began their operation to seal off Banda Aceh on Monday. Thousands of troops and police officers were deployed to block roads and rivers and check identity cards. Two road bridges were blown up, buses were banned from travelling and there were many reports of police and soldiers sweeping through villages destroying vehicles or shooting out the tyres.

A police spokesman, Senior Superintendent Kusbini Imbar, denied that his forces had over-reacted. "We only opened fire in self defence after we had been attacked by Gam in several locations," he said. "We know Gam was involved because we recovered grenades and other evidence from the scenes after they fled."

The rally, marking the first anniversary of a huge gathering in Banda Aceh which called for a referendum on ties with Jakarta, was expected to draw several hundred thousand people.

The rally's organiser, Muhammad Nazar, said he was now asking villages to hold their own meetings to reduce the risk of further casualties. "We are not violent people," he said. "We are not calling for a war or an armed struggle. All we want is for the Acehnese to be able to decide their own future."

Hundreds of Acehnese demonstrated in Jakarta on Wednesday, including outside the British embassy, to demand international intervention.

Indonesia's senior security minister, Susilo Bambang Yudohoyono, said that next week's talks in Geneva "will discuss two alternatives [for Aceh] - wider and special autonomy or accelerated development."

He said Jakarta would never grant independence to the oil- and gas-rich province.

webTitle: Philippine leader claims he rejected £2.8m bribe

fields.headline: Philippine leader claims he rejected £2.8m bribe
fields.standfirst: Estrada tries to enlist support of working class as impeachment motion draws closer
fields.trailText: Estrada tries to enlist support of working class as impeachment motion draws closer.
fields.body:
The beleaguered president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, fought back yesterday against corruption allegations, saying that he had rejected a huge bribe from illegal gambling syndicates.

He said in radio interviews that the 200m pesos (£2.8m) offered to him by his chief accuser was placed into a "Muslim youth scholarship fund" where it remains untouched.

But it was unclear why the money had not been returned. Critics of the president say that he has used the fund as a front to launder payoffs.

The allegations have led to widespread calls for Mr Estrada's resignation or impeachment. Next week the house of representatives is expected to prepare articles of impeachment, which are expected to be sent swiftly to the senate for a trial.

Mr Estrada has been stepping up efforts to rally the urban working class on his side against an opposition which he claims is "anti-poor". His followers hope to mobilise support at a mass prayer meeting in Manila tomorrow.

The rally has been organised by Mr Estrada's chief spiritual adviser, Mike Velarde, a multi-millionaire who leads a charismatic sect, El Shaddai, which claims to have 5m supporters.

"I would not touch it [payoffs from gambling syndicates]," Mr Estrada said yesterday, responding for the first time yesterday to the claims by a former crony, Luis Singson, which triggered the crisis.

"Since I was mayor I would not touch [illegal] money - and even more so since I was president."

He said that Mr Singson, a provincial governor, had offered him the 200m peso bribe from syndicates running a popular numbers game. Mr Singson said a month ago that Mr Estrada had accepted bribes totalling twice that sum.

Struggling to win back his populist image, Mr Estrada yesterday approved a long-delayed trust fund to help coconut farmers with shares that had previously been claimed by two of his close political allies. Mr Estrada's camp argue that this shows that he will give no favours to his former cronies.

After the crisis broke last month, the president took part in presentations of land deeds to Manila's urban poor, using the occasion to enlist their support.

"You are the ones who put me in power," he said. "Not those elitists in Makati [Manila's business centre]."

Observers say Mr Estrada is trying desperately to regain the credentials as "friend of the poor" which secured his landslide victory in 1998.

"It's clear that poor people whether urban or rural haven't yet taken a distinct anti-Estrada position," says Joel Rocamora, director of the Institute for Popular Democracy. "His administration understands that and is doing what it can to keep the support of the lower strata."

Mr Rocamora says the president is "playing Santa Claus rather early" and expects some gesture to be made soon to the rural poor.

"It is not so much that the poor still believe in Erap [Mr Estrada's nickname] but they are sceptical of the opposition. At the moment the anti-Estrada movement is dominated by the middle class and upper class."

The peso again breached the psychologically critical level of 50 to the US dollar yesterday as business hopes faded that Mr Estrada would step down soon.

In the manoeuvring around the president, the colourful figure of Mr Velarde looms large. Last week the vice-president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who has defected from Mr Estrada's camp, sought to woo Mr Velarde to her side, but he rejected her overtures.

Instead, he told thousands of supporters that the impeachment of Mr Estrada would turn the Philippines into "a banana republic", and urged them to pray for a solution.

Mr Velarde is a failed real estate developer who has built up political power and wealth with the mass following of his movement. He defied the Roman Catholic church in 1998 to support Mr Estrada's presidential bid.

Tomorrow's "national day of prayer and fasting" is ostensibly ecumenical but is dominated by El Shaddai. Mr Estrada spoke at last year's prayer day, making a ritual apology for failure to give enough help to the poor.

The pro-Estrada People's Movement against Poverty has issued a statement warning of a "rebellion of the poor", and yesterday a new"people's organisation", the Movement for Responsible Enterprise, emerged in Manila.

"We are not concerned whether [the charges against Mr Estrada] are true or not," said the chairman, Lito Descallar. "The problem is economic and some business groups are in cahoots with the opposition."

Mr Estrada said yesterday that he had refused an offer from Ms Arroyo to resign in return for immunity from prosecution. "They're offering a graceful exit [but] my graceful exit will be in 2004," he said, referring to the end of his term of office.

fields.headline: Radical accuses Iran of abuse
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: One of Iran's most prominent radicals, who is on trial accused of acting against the national interest, told a revolutionary court yesterday that he had been beaten and forced to wear the prison uniform of a common criminal.
fields.body:
One of Iran's most prominent radicals, who is on trial accused of acting against the national interest, told a revolutionary court yesterday that he had been beaten and forced to wear the prison uniform of a common criminal.

Akbar Ganji, once an out-spoken journalist and now a political prisoner, removed his prison jacket and vowed to go on a hunger strike in protest at his alleged mistreatment.

"I was beaten by four people today in the room of the prison director and they forced these clothes on me," he said.

Mr Ganji and 18 other reformers are also accused of spreading propaganda against the Islamic system and insulting religious sanctities.

The crimes are alleged to have been committed during a seminar in Berlin in April hosted by the Heinrich Böll Foundation. The participants at the conference held a discussion about Iran's reform movement, with some questioning whether Iran should have a religious government and whether women should be forced to wear veils.

The conservative establishment reacted angrily to their comments, and many of the participants were arrested on their return to Iran.

Adding fuel to the flames, Iranian opposition groups in Germany disrupted the meeting to embarrass the reformers. A scantily clad woman began dancing at the conference, and her activities were taped and played later on Iranian television.

The conference provided the evidence necessary for the powerful conservatives to bring many radical reformers to trial, legal experts say.

A prominent progressive cleric, Hassan Yousefi-Eshkevari, was convicted in a separate trial before a clerical court, and could face the death penalty. The verdict has been kept secret, pending appeal.

A defendant in the current trial, Jamileh Kadivar, is Iran's most powerful female politician and the wife of the minister of culture and Islamic guidance, whom the conservatives consider their great foe. She is also the sister of Mohsen Kadivar, a theologian who argues that religion should be separated from politics.

Mr Kadivar was recently released after serving 18 months for his writings, which were deemed "un-Islamic".

Many of the defendants represent the most radical faction within President Mohammad Khatami's reform movement, which is now greatly divided. While the president has tried to maintain political and social development at a moderate and gradual pace, others such as Mr Ganji have argued that the changes are too slow.

Last year, in order to expedite reform, Mr Ganji began writing articles in reformist newspapers which many considered went too far. He accused the former president, Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a leading figure among conservatives, of being behind the murders of dissident intellectuals in the 1990s.

The essays became best-selling books, making Mr Ganji a major target of the conservative establishment.

Mr Rafsanjani was badly damaged by the campaign and he surrendered his seat in parliament amid allegations that his supporters on the Guardian Council, which supervised elections in February, had rigged the results to give him a seat in the first round.

"The right in this country knows the reformers will completely fall apart because of their vast differences," said Saeed Leylaz, an astute political commentator.

"By pushing Rafsanjani out of the election, the leftists should have known they would suffer a blow in return. Now the reformers are severely split between those who want change from below and those who want change to come from the power structure."

webTitle: Art record  Picasso painting goes for £39m at auction

fields.headline: Art record  Picasso painting goes for £39m at auction
fields.trailText: A new record was set for a work by Pablo Picasso when his  Femme aux bras croisés ( Woman with Crossed Arms) sold for $55.6m (£39.2m) at Christie's in New York.
fields.body:
A new record was set for a work by Pablo Picasso when his Femme aux bras croisés ( Woman with Crossed Arms) sold for $55.6m (£39.2m) at Christie's in New York.

The figure was more than twice its pre-sale estimate of $25m and the fifth-highest sum ever paid for any work of art at auction.

The portrait of a seated woman, painted between 1901 and 1902 during the artist's blue period, was the star lot in Christie's autumn sale of impressionist and modern art. The buyer was not identified.

fields.headline: De Gaulle honoured at last
fields.trailText: General Charles de Gaulle returned to the Champs-Elysées yesterday - 30 years to the day after his death - as President Jacques Chirac inaugurated a 24ft bronze statue of France's wartime leader striding down the avenue during the 1944 liberation of Paris.
fields.body:
General Charles de Gaulle returned to the Champs-Elysées yesterday - 30 years to the day after his death - as President Jacques Chirac inaugurated a 24ft bronze statue of France's wartime leader striding down the avenue during the 1944 liberation of Paris.

"De Gaulle was France incarnate," said Mr Chirac in a speech praising his predecessor's achievements, including universal suffrage in 1945 and the founding of the Fifth Republic in 1958. He described the heritage of Gaullism as "a certain idea of democracy that underpins all our institutions".

The statue is the first in Paris to de Gaulle, who rejected the honour during his life. Parisians had also long opposed the idea, resenting his claim to have liberated them when he merely led American troops into town.

However, the unveiling in Paris two years ago of a typically pugnacious statue of Winston Churchill changed things. The city could no longer refuse the offer of a private association, the Free France Federation, to raise the £450,000 needed for a suitable monument to the wartime hero.

De Gaulle might not have approved of the spot chosen - the corner of the Avenue Winston Churchill, a stone's throw from the monument to the Briton who once referred to de Gaulle as "a vain and even a malignant man ... a mischief-maker with fascist tendencies".

webTitle: London, the Biography by Peter Ackroyd

fields.headline: London, the Biography by Peter Ackroyd
fields.standfirst:
Chatto & Windus, £25
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The master of parenthesis rummages through all his previous literary research and comes up with a history of London
fields.body:
Picture, if you will, London as a living body. Imagine the City as its pulsing heart, the parks its lungs and the tentacular sprawl of streets its veins. Yet pause not to imagine wherein might lie its arsehole.

Now picture this mighty organism on a journey through time, though not necessarily a linear chronological projection. We will be taking labyrinthine twists and turns, back and forth through history. It may, at times, be a contradictory peregrination, but one never other than revealing. So pay attention and don't get lost. Or you may end up in Surbiton.

The sea has always been part of this great city. For millions of years the land on which London was built was submerged beneath the oceans. Look carefully at parts of London stone and you might find flecks of sea urchin fossils. As the seas subsided, herds of mastodons and hippopotami roamed wild and their remains are still to be found deep beneath the earth of Trafalgar Square.

Red is the colour of London. It is the colour of fire and blood, the recurring punctuation marks of the capital, and is commemorated even today on buses and telephone boxes. Virginia Woolf describes the city as 'eternally burnt' and, ever since Boudicca laid waste to Londinium, it has been periodically engulfed in flames.

But out of the embers comes renewal; the Great Fire brought the Plague, carried from overseas by rattus rattus and whose pestilential story is told so well in an anecdotal, yet not unconsidered, fashion by Defoe, to its finality.

Londoners themselves have an almost pantomimic theatricality; the city slicker and the Cockney wideboy are just two stock characters. But what else might one expect from a city that is a stage unto itself? And what greater spectacles did London have to offer than its punishments?

As Samuel Johnson wrote to Boswell, 'Sir, executions are intended to draw spectators.' Not all were happy when executions were moved from the central arena of Tyburn to behind closed doors in Newgate.

If opera, or indeed soap opera, have often been the public image of London, it is commerce that has provided its raison détre. The city is the hub of the nation's trade and, of all the enterprises undertaken, none, I'm sure you may concur, has ever been so fine as this.

And if you really are busy - the digested read, digested:

fields.headline: the best parole officer scene
fields.standfirst: The yards
fields.trailText: The yards
fields.body:
Having returned home from prison, Leo Handler (Mark Wahlberg) notices his parole officer (Joseph Ragno) sitting in the corner of the party thrown for his release.

"We need to go over a few things," he mutters. "Where can we talk?"

"Uh, in the bedroom I guess."

In Leo's bedroom, the parole officer pulls out a file.

"Our records show that you were released at 4 o'clock this afternoon."

"That's right."

"You're supposed to make an arrival report."

"Nobody told me that. I thought I had 24 hours."

The parole officer looks up from his papers.

"OK, well, in future you should know that you're required to report with due diligence. Now, it says here that you've had some problems. I see that you served 16 months for auto theft. Your parole terms have you on attentive supervision."

Leo nods.

"I'll have access to your bank records, your W2s and your pay slips. That's to keep track of your cash flow. What about employment? You know what you're gonna do?"

"Yeah, I think I got something."

"What's that?"

"Well, my aunt's new husband has his own business. It's actually very, very important. I'm supposed to go and interview with him tomorrow. A couple of my friends are out there - they're working for him too."

Leo catches the parole officer's eye.

"I don't wanna cause no problems. I just want to become a productive person again, you know... in society."

See also: Shockproof, Straight Time, Made In Britain

Don't see also: Double Jeopardy

Pointless trivia: Prior to launching his acting career, Mark Wahlberg worked as a bricklayer.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Toy Story 2 | Man on the Moon | Kevin and Perry Go Large | Honest
fields.trailText: Toy Story 2 | Man on the Moon | Kevin and Perry Go Large | Honest
fields.body:
Toy Story 2
Rental and DVD (£22.99)
Buena Vista Cert U
****

Hollywood gets accused of dumbing down most weeks, but in Toonland, they've brained up exponentially in the last post-Simpsons decade. Like its predecessor and Disney-Pixar stablemate A Bug's Life, Toy Story 2 treats kids' intelligence with respect with an involving plot, stunning visuals, and a constant stream of gags, most of them pretty good.

There's top acting talent too, of course: Tom Hanks and Tim Allen return as Woody and Buzz and are joined by sitcom stars Kelsey Grammer as Stinky Pete, and the ever-odious Wayne Knight as the collector who kidnaps Hanks's cowboy character to make up a set of vintage toys to sell to Japan. It has fun, too, with massed ranks of Barbies and an aisle full of Buzz toys: "In 1995, short-sighted retailers understocked." (In other words, they're going to sell you lots more toys but they can get a joke out of that, too).

John Lasseter, who takes sole directing credit this time as well as co-writing, is a wiz at making this work on a number of levels: the vintage toys remind oldies of their own childhood and the toys' obsolescence is mined for pathos rather than sentiment. There's even a moral: toys are for children, not for museums. But it does all this lightly and, courtesy of Stinky Pete, it has fart jokes, too. The DVD includes lots of the traditional outtakes and interviews with most of its vocal stars.

Man on the Moon
Rental
Universal Cert 15
***

"You're insane, but you might also be brilliant." This is agent Danny DeVito's view of Andy Kaufman, as played by Jim Carrey. "You're unusual but you're also pointless," might have been more accurate as Carrey works his way through a range of Kaufman's elaborate practical jokes. These include reading the whole of The Great Gatsby onstage, wrestling women and getting an OAP to fake death at his Carnegie Hall show. The common aim seems to be to treat an audience with contempt. Apart from his role in Taxi, recreated here with the rest of the cast, minus DeVito, who is otherwise engaged, it's hard to see how Kaufman ever earned a living.

But presumably Carrey and director Milos Forman feel his refusal to be funny in any normal way makes him a rebel in the tradition of Forman's last oddball anti-hero, Larry Flynt. Like Flynt, Forman gives him Courtney Love for a partner. She lights up the screen briefly - it's hard to think of the last rock star who looked this natural acting (maybe Cher). She looks all ready for a lead role herself but sadly, this part is soon reduced to ghastly "adoring wife" cliches. Carrey loses himself in the role impressively, but this is just funny peculiar.

Kevin and Perry Go Large
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Warner Cert 15
**

It was a great Kevin and Perry TV moment when the lads, confronted by a suddenly sexualised childhood friend, produced small synchronised erections. Its symptomatic of Go Large's idea of how to transfer to the big screen that here, there are five erection jokes, they're enormous and sadly, not funny.

The basic set-up - the teens get to go to Ibiza, but Kevin's parents come too - doesn't provide many gag ideas for Enfield and co-writer Dave Cummings. Still, if you want vomit, wanking, spot-squeezing, and the horror of parents shagging, then purchase confidently.

Honest
Rental
Pathé Cert 18
**

Virtually condemned at birth (or at least on arrival at the local), the weirdest thing about Honest is that 18 certificate. It certainly deserves it, thanks to director Dave Stewart's nude tripping scene and occasional bits of gratuitous sex from an Appleton or two, but what were they thinking? The average All Saints fan is probably 15 or 16 so those empty cinema seats could hardly have come as a surprise.

The film itself is a largely inoffensive caper movie that could almost have been made in the year it's set, 1968. It's full of the sort of half-stoned naivety you expect in, say, Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush. So you have a double-barrelled toff running an underground paper, a bland American lead who intones: "Only a two bob cab ride from Carnaby Street to Bethnal Green but it's a different world," and three east end sister thieves - the curiously interchangeable All Saints who are not Shaznay - who dress as men, are good to their east end dad and hide nicked jewellery in a lava lamp.

With old writing pros Clement and La Frenais helping out its three novice actresses and novice director, you suspect this was all meant as a spoof, but the film doesn't seem to think so. Stewart's main aim seems to be to relive some old tripping experiences on film and get his mate Bob Dylan on the soundtrack.

fields.headline: Chuck & Buck
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw  hails an intriguing and original take on childhood friendships intruding into adult lives
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: [it] sprays satirical acid at the whole idea of the "inner child" and the psychobabble piety that the inner child is any more innocent than the raddled outer adult
fields.body:
It is a strange coincidence that a number of movies out this week treat of the adult's inner child, and the strange forgotten intensity of the friendships and experiences of your school days. But no film serves up this idea with more black comic shock and sheer exuberant lack of taste than Chuck & Buck.

It's a pornographic comedy of dysfunction which aspires to debunk the adult world of success, but in so doing sprays satirical acid at the whole idea of the "inner child" and the psychobabble piety that the inner child is any more innocent than the raddled outer adult. On the contrary: the inner child is kept inner for a good reason. Because it's a creepy little perv that you need to lock up - and throw away the key.

Miguel Arteta directs - and manages to do so with much more restraint and clarity than Harmony Korine might have done with similar material, perhaps because so many of Arteta's colleagues on this film have a more unassuming background in comedy. Chris Weitz (the co-director of American Pie) plays Charlie, a good-looking and way-cool twentysomething record producer in LA. Out of the blue, he receives a letter from Buck, an old school buddy that he hardly remembers, inviting him to his mother's funeral.

Charlie and his stylish fiancée, Carlyn (Beth Colt), dutifully turn up, only to find to their horror that Buck, played by Mike White, has simply stayed 10 years old in his mind, a grotesque, giggling, child-man - and obsessed with Charlie all these years, hoarding dozens of photos of him as a child.

Now Buck, with his T-shirt, shorts, lollipops and weird kiddie songs, wants to resume the friendship he had with Charlie when they were 10 in the Arcadian world of childhood. The nightmare begins as he stalks Charlie and his wife, turning up at their Hollywood house and parties, and at Charlie's office, insisting on his name for him then: Chuck. They will, once again, be Chuck and Buck.

Not revealing the ending is an over-rated virtue for the critic, but suffice it to say that this "Chuck and Buck" formulation is important because of the rhyming slang it contains about the precise nature of their childhood relationship. Maybe the best point of comparison is with the Stephen Wright joke about the 50-year-old man who runs up to a five-year-old shouting: "Hey, howya doin' Billy? I haven't seen you for 45 years! Oh... I guess you can't be... because he would have grown up..."

Trying to make conversation with someone you last met in infant school is a bizarre experience because the shared culture of childhood and its enthusiasms are mentionable only in the most detached way. When Buck comes to Charlie's office, he blurts out: "Remember how we bought all those office supplies when we were 10? Is it real now or is it still like a game?" Charlie flinches at the weirdness of the question and its tactless truth.

What is clear is that he does remember, that we all remember, and that our adult poise is fragile, requiring an elaborate complicity of all the other adults to forget about the ever-present vulnerability of our childhood selves.

A movie such as Big starring Tom Hanks tries to suggest that being a big kid is charming and picturesque and innocent, Chuck & Buck suggests that without the retrospective benediction of adulthood, a state with all the careful accretions of self-respect and social prestige, childhood was a monstrous, deracinated state.

Arteta and Mike White have taken the starting point of their film as Buck's mother's death, and it is the death of a parent which can give, or will give everyone their final, definitive glimpse into their own "childhood" not as something remembered, as a state which no longer applies, but as something alive and real and just below the surface.

One of the darkest aspects of this sort of bereavement is supposed to be the sense of suddenly being plunged back into childhood fears, childhood terrors, and dark, unacknowledged childhood fantasies about getting rid of parent-authority. Chuck & Buck dramatises and elaborates these fears in a knockabout, comic-book style with slightly implausible plot complications.

The movie is pretty rough and ready and has no ready-made audience to play to: it does not fall easily into any obvious comic category, but it is also - perhaps mercifully - refreshingly without any lofty Dogme-style seriousness, despite being filmed on DV. This is a very distinctive and often very funny picture, disquieting and diverting all at once.

fields.headline: Introducing the young guns
fields.trailText: We take a closer look at Seth Johnson, Michael Ball, Nicky Butt, Frank Lampard and Paul Robinson.
fields.body:
Seth Johnson (Derby County)
Age: 21
Left wing-back
One of a clutch of players promoted from the under-21s, Johnson is called up despite a chequered disciplinary record that includes 18 yellow cards in 18 months and an FA-imposed three-month suspension from international football that has only just expired, after breaking a curfew to go drinking during last summer's European under-21 championship. Brought up in Devon, his talent was unearthed as a 14-year-old by Crewe manager Dario Gradi. Tracked by Derby County throughout the 1998-99 season, he eventually chose Derby ahead of Liverpool, feeling the Midlands club would help him develop quicker. A tigerish player at home in left midfield or left wing-back, if selected he would become the fourth Gradi pupil to graduate to the senior England side following Rob Jones, David Platt and Geoff Thomas.

Michael Ball (Everton)
Age: 21
Left-back

webTitle: These kids are alright - but where are Lee and Ashley?

fields.headline: These kids are alright - but where are Lee and Ashley?
fields.trailText: You can't argue too much with Peter Taylor's selection, bar a couple of omissions. You don't know until you try and in any case, what have we got to lose?
fields.body:
England can only benefit from Peter Taylor's decision to give youth its head in Italy. It's not as if he has left out eight world-class players and thrown away the chance of a good result. Quite frankly it could be a big improvement on what we have seen recently.

The youngsters will realise they have a chance to impose themselves for an England place by shining against one of the best teams in the world, and somebody might just emerge as a player with genuine international potential in the way Michael Owen did in 1998.

Sometimes you come away from games like this thinking "he's better than I thought" and with the new coach waiting in the wings this is a first-class opportunity to see who is up to the job.

Sven-Goran Eriksson will have an open mind on lots of issues. I know his Lazio team are very experienced but he reportedly tried to buy Michael Owen and I don't think age will matter. He'll want the best players, plain and simple.

In that respect I don't think you can argue too much with Peter Taylor's selection. I would like to see Lee Hendrie given another chance soon because I feel he could fill the left-hand role if England play a midfield four. Ashley Cole might also be disappointed because I think he's an excellent prospect at left-back, and Jon Harley is similar.

But Peter Taylor has kept faith with many of the lads he had in the under-21s. Michael Ball and Seth Johnson are good examples. I wouldn't have thought Johnson's form with Derby has been anywhere near good enough to merit an England place, but Peter has obviously seen things he likes and it looks to be a case of throwing those two in at the deep end and seeing if they can solve the left-hand position.

One player I'm particularly excited about is Paul Robinson and I would start with him in goal. I'm not convinced by Richard Wright and we could put Robinson on a fast track and find out we have a top-class keeper we didn't realise we had a couple of months back.

Normally I wouldn't be saying this about a young keeper because I generally think of them reaching their best in their mid-20s. But we've talked about a crisis in that position, with David Seaman aged 37 and Nigel Martyn also knocking on. It gives us a chance to look at one early. If he's not quite up to it then fine.

On the subject of keepers I'm reliably informed by people at Coventry that Chris Kirkland might even be a better prospect than Robinson. He's 19 and has played only five matches but that position might be healthier than we imagined.

I certainly think we have a top-class centre-back in Wes Brown. He's the nearest to Paul McGrath I've seen in a long time. He's quick and lively, he's got enough power and he's cool. Against Dynamo Kiev on Wednesday he even produced a little backheel, which was the McGrath trademark. I would like to see him given a crack.

Whether Rio Ferdinand is the man to play alongside him I'm not sure. I'm not convinced by his defensive qualities. I would have liked him to be a bit more commanding in the air and I think sometimes he loses concentration. He's a bit between a midfield player and a central defender.

In fact I tried to buy him for Coventry after I saw him play in midfield for West Ham in the Youth Cup. He was totally dominant and I went up to Harry Redknapp after the match and offered him about 200 grand.

He told me in his cockney vernacular to clear off, so I said: "Alright, if I can't have him how about Frank Lampard?" I was turned down on that one as well but I like Lampard.

He's got the knack of scoring goals and that's always invaluable from midfield. It came home to me watching Manchester United against Dynamo Kiev that when Paul Scholes isn't around they're well short on goalscoring midfield players. Sometimes you'd look for Lampard to be more involved but he's very skilful with that knack of finding the net.

I wouldn't start him in Turin, though. My team, playing 3-5-2, would be: Robinson; Brown, Southgate, Barry; G Neville, Dyer, Beckham, Scholes, Ball; Heskey, Owen.

There will be times England will be overrun but that would happen whatever side you picked. And I think Peter Taylor has enough in his locker to give Italy a run for their money and show we have some young talent that will not be overawed.

fields.headline: Laslandes slide sinks Celtic
fields.standfirst:
Moravcik 54 | Laslandes 78, 114
Aet; 1-1 after 90min; agg: 2-3
fields.trailText: Two strikes from Lilian Laslandes on a nerve-shredding evening in Glasgow dumped Celtic out of the competition last night.
fields.body:
Two strikes from Lilian Laslandes on a nerve-shredding night in Glasgow ejected Celtic from a place in today's Uefa Cup third-round draw. Martin O'Neill has quickly gleaned that things north of the border can curdle the blood, but he surely never expected this.

"We have had a great night but we have ended up being beaten, I have no idea how," said the Celtic manager.

"For long periods of the game we made Bordeaux look second-rate but we were not able to finish them off. When they got the equaliser it was virtually the first time they had been in our penalty box."

Bordeaux, save for the elegant Christophe Dugarry, had looked a dull and slightly lifeless bunch before the 78th minute, when Laslandes abruptly equalised Lubomir Moravcik's earlier strike on almost the first occasion Jonathan Gould had been troubled. That put the tie at 2-2 on aggregate and primed for penalty kicks, with Ulrich Ramé, Bordeaux's goalkeeper, looking worryingly competent.

Laslandes, though, after 114 minutes of open play, made sure of no such scenario with a gorgeous winning goal. Receiving the substitute Bruno Basto's sweeping cross in the right of Gould's box, the striker's shot left the goalkeeper powerless as it bulleted high into his net.

The match did not carry the anxieties of Ibrox two nights previously but the 51,000 inside Parkhead were still stricken with nerves. When, like Celtic, you have not been past a third round in Europe since Michael Foot was still a power in the land, then occasions like this seem fraught.

Matters were made worse for Celtic by the absence through injury and ineligibility of Paul Lambert and Alan Thompson and their best chance of the opening half came when Henrik Larsson found himself seven yards out from Ramé before the goalkeeper saved the Swede's shot with his legs.

Celtic finally forced a breakthrough in the 54th minute after Larsson's vicious free-kick had somehow at the last second been flapped away by Ramé.

Bobby Petta's low cross was cleared weakly by the French, leaving Moravcik to rifle home a beautiful right-footed shot from 18 yards. The little Slovakian, described as "ancient" by O'Neill though only, in fact, 34, is supposed to preserve his precious energy but his celebratory run might have taken him to Bratislava and back.

No sooner was Moravcik substituted, though, than Laurent Batlles screwed the ball back for Laslandes to stretch out a leg and beat Gould in the 78th minute to bring on extra-time.

Celtic (3-5-2): Gould; Mjallby, Boyd, Valgaeren; Agathe, Petrov, McNamara (Healy, 39min), Moravcik (Johnson, 77), Petta (Berkovic, 105); Sutton, Larsson.

Bordeaux (4-4-2): Ramé; Jemmali (Saveljic, 101), Roche, Sommeil, Bonnissel; Batlles (Basto, 80), Diabate (Afanou, 55), Legwinski, Dugarry; Laslandes, Pauleta.

Referee: S Schmolik (Belarus).

fields.headline: Liverpool drawn against Olympiakos
fields.trailText: Liverpool have been handed a tricky looking tie against Olympiakos in today's third round Uefa Cup draw in Geneva.
fields.body:
Liverpool have been handed a tricky looking tie against Olympiakos in today's third round Uefa Cup draw in Geneva.

The Greeks will be no pushovers - they narrowly missed out on a place in the second phase of the Champions League, having come third behind Valencia and Lyon. Liverpool will be at home for the first leg on Thursday November 23, with the away leg being played a fortnight later.

Meanwhile Rangers also have a difficult looking draw against German side Kaiserslautern. Rangers came out of the draw first and will play the first leg at Ibrox on Thursday November 23 and then travel to Germany a fortnight later.

Elsewhere, Internazionale have been drawn against Bundesliga leaders Hertha Berlin, while Barcelona face Belgian side Club Bruges.

fields.headline: Laslandes adds a bit extra
fields.trailText: Celtic1 Moravcik 54 Bordeaux 1 Laslandes 78 (2-2 on aggregate after 90 minutes)
fields.body:
Celtic1 Moravcik 54 Bordeaux 1 Laslandes 78 (2-2 on aggregate after 90 minutes)

Celtic and Bordeaux scrambled into extra-time of this jangling Uefa Cup second round match in Glasgow last night after Bordeaux's Lilian Laslandes levelled an earlier effort from Lubomir Moravcik to put the tie 1-1 on the night and 2-2 on aggregate. Celtic had rarely been troubled in the game before a worrying onslaught in the last 10 minutes by the French swung the fortunes of the affair and petrified onlooking Glaswegians.

The irony was that Bordeaux had looked a touch slovenly throughout, quietly classy when the mood took them, which appeared to be quite rare. Before Jonathan Gould conceded a late equaliser he had barely been troubled.

The game didn't have the anxieties of Ibrox two nights before but 51,000 inside Parkhead were still stricken with nerves. When, like Celtic, you haven't been past a third round in Europe since Michael Foot was still a power in the land, then occasions like these seem fraught.

Matters were made worse for Celtic by the absence through injury and ineligibility of Paul Lambert and Alan Thompson and the home side's nerves were worse still for the sight of Christophe Dugarry in the colours of Bordeaux. This arrogant showman caused alarm to sweep through Celtic whenever he burst forward. Bordeaux didn't look indulgently talented but their lucky charm in number 26 certainly did.

Dugarry's dips of a shoulder and riding of rough tackles ensured that much of the first 50 minutes of this match were filled with Celtic squealing for doubtful penalties instead of scything through the French defence. Celtic's best chance of the opening half came when Henrik Larsson found himself seven yards out from Ulrich Ramé before the goalkeeper saved the Swede's shot with his legs.

Celtic finally forced a breakthough in the 54th minute. In the moments leading to it, Larsson's vicious free-kick had somehow at the last second been flapped away by Ramé, though Bordeaux's respite was to last only for a few seconds.

Bobby Petta's low cross was cleared weakly by the French, leaving Moravcik to rifle home a beautiful right-foot shot from 18 yards. The little Slovakian, described as "ancient" by O'Neill though only, in fact, 34, is supposed to preserve his precious energy. The celebratory run he embarked on here might have taken him to Bratislava and back.

Yet no sooner was Moravcik substituted than Bordeaux equalised. Laurent Batlles screwed the ball back for Laslandes to stretch out a leg and beat Gould in the 78th minute.

Celtic (3-5-2): Gould; Mjallby, Boyd, Valgaeren; Agathe, Petrov, McNamara, Moravcik, Petta; Sutton, Larsson.

Bordeaux (4-4-2): Ramé; Jemmali, Roche, Sommeil, Bonnissel; Batlles, Diabate, Legwinski, Dugarry; Laslandes, Pauleta.

Referee: S Schmolik (Belarus).
