webTitle: Labour extends Tory private finance scheme

fields.headline: Labour extends Tory private finance scheme
fields.standfirst: The government is committed to private funding of school and hospital building despite widespread criticism
fields.trailText: The government is committed to private funding of school and hospital building despite widespread criticism
fields.body:
If critics of the private finance initiative (PFI) held any hope that the scheme would be abandoned by Labour when it came to power, they were soon dashed.

The initiative for investing in new hospitals, school buildings and equipment was set up by the Tories in 1992. It was seized upon by a government looking for to answer a conundrum that has dogged all Labour governments - how can it appease the City by keeping down public sector borrowing and appeal to its core constituency by investing in new hospitals and schools?

The PFI was introduced by Tory chancellor Norman Lamont in the 1992 Budget. After the UK was forced to pull out of the European exchange rate mechanism earlier that year, the Conservatives needed to stimulate the economy and hold down public spending - and the PFI offered a relatively inexpensive way of boosting a recession-hit construction industry.

The PFI is now the major source of capital funding for local authorities and NHS bodies because ministers will not countenance the borrowing or increased taxes that would be needed if PFI were to be abandoned. Contracts worth more than £17bn have been signed in all parts of the public sector.

Under PFI, the private sector provides the cash to build, say, a new hospital. This is repaid monthly with interest once the building opens. Bidding companies normally put together a consortium consisting of a construction firm, a bank or equity fund and a provider of support services such as catering and laundry. This provider will also receive a monthly payment.

Contracts are agreed for a set period of time - for large hospital schemes, normally 25-30 years. Deals include a number of penalty clauses, for example, if a classroom becomes unusable because of defective heating or if hygiene standards fall.

The current government often refers to public-private partnerships (PPPs). PFI is an example of a PPP, a term that can also be applied to joint ventures with the private sector where public and private money is invested in a building project.

PFI has been criticised on many levels. One is the slow pace of progress. Work did not begin on a major NHS deal until 1997 and the first PFI hospitals did not open until spring and summer 2000. The lack of progress in the early years was mainly due to the complexity of the deals, and the fact that financiers held out for strong government guarantees to protect their investments.

Labour reversed the Conservatives' "let a thousand flowers bloom" approach - where projects competed with each other to find private sector partners - by limiting the number of PFI applicants to a shortlist of centrally determined "priority" projects. The government has also attempted to streamline the PFI by developing model contracts that cut through bureaucracy and reduce the cost of external advisors.

Public sector unions have criticised PFI as "back-door privatisation" of the NHS. They are concerned that the wages and conditions of support workers who are transferred from the NHS to the private sector consortia will suffer as businesses seek to maximise profits.

Economists point out that the government can borrow money from the markets at cheaper rates than the private sector so the PFI saddles public services with higher interest repayments than if the cash had been borrowed by the Treasury.

The government accepts this but it believes that PFI encourages greater control of costs over the project's lifetime. For example, since the consortium will be penalised if part of the building becomes unusable, it is in its interest to use high quality construction materials, which in turn should keep maintenance costs low.

A seemingly obscure technical detail in the accounting treatment of PFI emerged to threaten its future in 1997. It boiled down to whether the public sector is buying an asset in instalments or paying for the provision of a service. In the former case, the deal or part of the deal would go onto the public sector balance sheet, increasing public sector borrowing and wiping out one of main reasons for introducing the initiative. However, the Treasury is relaxed about the accounting treatment of PFI deals - it believes that under the new rules PFI payments on, say, a hospital building are "off balance sheet" - in other words, treated as fees for providing a service.

After the UK was forced to pull out of the European exchange rate mechanism earlier that year, the Conservatives needed to stimulate the economy and hold down public spending - and the PFI offered a relatively inexpensive way of boosting a recession-hit construction industry. The PFI is now the major source of capital funding for local authorities and NHS bodies because ministers will not countenance the borrowing or increased taxes that would be needed if PFI were to be abandoned. Contracts worth more than £17bn have been signed in all parts of the public sector. Under PFI, the private sector provides the cash to build, say, a new hospital. This is repaid monthly with interest once the building opens. Bidding companies normally put together a consortium consisting of a construction firm, a bank or equity fund and a provider of support services such as catering and laundry. This provider will also receive a monthly payment. Contracts are agreed for a set period of time - for large hospital schemes, normally 25-30 years. Deals include a number of penalty clauses, for example, if a classroom becomes unusable because of defective heating or if hygiene standards fall. The current government often refers to public-private partnerships (PPPs). PFI is an example of a PPP, a term that can also be applied to joint ventures with the private sector where public and private money is invested in a building project. PFI has been criticised on many levels. One is the slow pace of progress. Work did not begin on a major NHS deal until 1997 and the first PFI hospitals did not open until spring and summer 2000. The lack of progress in the early years was mainly due to the complexity of the deals, and the fact that financiers held out for strong government guarantees to protect their investments. Labour reversed the Conservatives' "let a thousand flowers bloom" approach - where projects competed with each other to find private sector partners - by limiting the number of PFI applicants to a shortlist of centrally determined "priority" projects. The government has also attempted to streamline the PFI by developing model contracts that cut through bureaucracy and reduce the cost of external advisors. Public sector unions have criticised PFI as "back-door privatisation" of the NHS. They are concerned that the wages and conditions of support workers who are transferred from the NHS to the private sector consortia will suffer as businesses seek to maximise profits. Economists point out that the government can borrow money from the markets at cheaper rates than the private sector so the PFI saddles public services with higher interest repayments than if the cash had been borrowed by the Treasury. The government accepts this but it believes that PFI encourages greater control of costs over the project's lifetime. For example, since the consortium will be penalised if part of the building becomes unusable, it is in its interest to use high quality construction materials, which in turn should keep maintenance costs low. A seemingly obscure technical detail in the accounting treatment of PFI emerged to threaten its future in 1997. It boiled down to whether the public sector is buying an asset in instalments or paying for the provision of a service. In the former case, the deal or part of the deal would go onto the public sector balance sheet, increasing public sector borrowing and wiping out one of main reasons for introducing the initiative. However, the Treasury is relaxed about the accounting treatment of PFI deals - it believes that under the new rules PFI payments on, say, a hospital building are "off balance sheet" - in other words, treated as fees for providing a service.

fields.headline: Private finance and councils
fields.standfirst: Seamus Ward examines the workings of the private finance initiative in local government
fields.trailText: Seamus Ward examines the workings of the private finance initiative in local government
fields.body:
Councils have a large degree of autonomy and they need no approval from central government if they have a PFI scheme that they can pay for from existing revenues. In reality, most need some extra cash to make the regular payments to their private sector partners. This money is given to councils by the government as part of their annual revenue support grant or in the form of a specific grant. Schemes have to be given government approval as there is a limited amount of money - around £3bn between 1997 and 2000.

Which projects are being carried out using PFI?
The most obvious local government PFIs include schools such as the new £15m Colfox school in Dorset, as well as libraries and residential care homes. The range of PFI projects reflects the variety of services delivered by local authorities. As well as waste disposal and magistrate courts schemes, councils have also been involved in procuring new police stations such as the £2.7m Ilkeston station in Derbyshire. The largest local government project is the £8bn scheme that aims to modernise London's ailing underground network.

What is the value of local government PFI projects?
It is difficult to get an accurate picture of council PFI projects. It is complicated by the number of Whitehall departments and the devolved administrations involved. However, official figures show that to date, contracts with a value of £1.2bn have been signed.

What about housing?
A form of PFI has been operating in social housing since 1989. Since then, local authorities have been able to transfer council houses to housing associations and other registered social landlords, if the move has been approved by the affected tenants. The new landlord takes over the management of the homes and agrees not to raise rents by more than an amount that is linked to the retail price index. The association will also raise funds through the City to carry out repairs or refurbishment. In the last 10 years transfers have brought £15bn into housing - more private finance than any other sector. By getting the houses off their books, councils have significantly reduced their debts.

webTitle: Do I have rights without a contract?

fields.headline: Do I have rights without a contract?
fields.trailText: I am feeling really burned out as I haven't had a holiday break since June 1999. My boss has pretty much told me that he will not pay me holiday pay as I am self-employed - but he is the only client.
fields.body:
The problem

I am a self-employed accounts manager. I work for a guy who has three restaurants and I spread my time between the three in a week that consists of approximately 40 to 45 hours.

I am feeling really burned out as I haven't had a holiday break since June 1999. My boss has pretty much told me that he will not pay me holiday pay as I am self-employed. He is the only client that I have due to the work load that the three restaurants place upon me. My quality of life is shocking - I am too tired to do a thing after work as the travelling is a 60 mile round trip each day.

Whenever I need a day off work I am docked for that day. I have asked him to put me on the payroll but he insists that he will not due to extra employers N.I. and also the fact that he will then have to pay me holiday pay.

The solution

I bet your boss thinks he is being really clever by effectively keeping a full-time employee on a self-employed basis and thus avoiding providing you with your statutory employment rights (such as holiday pay, sick leave etc). However, your circumstances are such that the law may actually define you as an employee, even though your boss prefers to label you as freelance (of course he does!). Ultimately only the courts can decide the status of individuals and, according to ACAS, they may apply a number of tests including:

 The degree of control - the greater the level of operational control the employer has, the more likely the worker is to be classed as an employee.

 The extent to which the worker is integrated into the employer's organisation - has the worker become part and parcel of the organisation?

So, you see, your employer may think that by not putting you on the payroll he is able to avoid giving you your rights, but in actual fact, putting you on the payroll may be irrelevant. You need to seek legal advice so that you know where you stand in the eyes of the law and then make sure your boss knows.

Remember, you cannot be sacked for asserting your employee rights so if your boss tried to let you go once you start asking for holiday leave, you would probably have a strong case with an industrial tribunal. However, a gentle approach in which you simply point out your rights and your employer's obligations is likely to be more effective than an aggressive one threatening legal action.

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Theatre Review: The Force of Change

fields.headline: The Force of Change
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court, London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Court, London
***
fields.body:
In the interview room of a police station, DS Caroline Paterson is attempting to break a resolutely mute suspect whom she knows has been involved in racketeering, intimidation and probably worse. It is a tough case for her, made tougher by the fact that she is a fast-track career policewoman with a promotion coming up, and has an interview partner in old-timer Bill, who has been on the Force for 30 years, who is proving more of a hindrance than a help. Quite how much of a hindrance only becomes apparent just before the interval.

Gary Mitchell's play could merely be a gritty episode of Prime Suspect and there are times when his televisual thriller seems to be little more than a sparkily written slice from one of those police dramas where a female detective encounters the misogyny of canteen culture. But context is all in Mitchell's play. Paterson is not in any old police force but the RUC, and the suspect in the interview room is Stanley Brown, a member of the UDA.

Mitchell has become the great chronicler of the protestant experience in Northern Ireland, and here, using a taut thriller format, he shows how the RUC, a Protestant force for a Protestant community, finds itself in a world of change where its role and even its name is under threat. For many in this police station it used to be obvious who the enemy was - the IRA. But now the enemy is closer to home and officers such as Caroline Paterson are a symbol of the attempt to push the RUC into a world where peace stands a chance.

The play, though never less than gripping, is always drama rather than theatre. But the friction of the here and now is so palpable that Mitchell succeeds in making the play seem urgent, compulsive and even essential. It makes you realise the extent of David Trimble's difficulties and why in the face of such entrenched tribal loyalties the peace process is such a mirage.

You leave the theatre feeling profoundly depressed. The seams of the plot show too much for it to be credible and I'd defy any actress, even if she was Sarah Bernhardt and Juliet Stevenson rolled into one, to be able to pull off the role of Caroline Paterson (played by Laine Megaw), who is not above using her gender and her sex appeal for her own ends.

Robert Delamere's production cleverly contains the explosive nature of the revelations so their impact is all the more devastating. Simon Wolfe as Caroline's police partner, and Stuart Graham as the misogynist who knows that his day will come, are outstanding.

Until November 25. Box office: 020-7565 5000.

fields.headline: Taj Mahal
fields.standfirst:
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.trailText:
Shepherd's Bush Empire, London
***
fields.body:
Thirty-three years after his recording debut, the man born as Henry St Clair Fredericks is back in fashion, and he's not wasting a moment. Dressed, as always, in hat, dark glasses and wild shirt, he has scarcely finished one song before he segues rapidly into the next, almost falling over himself as he shifts from slow blues to rolling New Orleans styles, soul ballads or frantic 1960s R&B. Taj Mahal has gone back to his roots, once again, and his enthusiasm is infectious as ever.

He has had a long, colourful career, from university graduate (a degree in animal husbandry) to band member, playing alongside Ry Cooder in the Rising Sons, and then unlikely 1960s blues hero, standing out against the psychedelic blues bombardment with his acoustic guitar work.

He was mixing folk, gospel, cajun and Caribbean styles long before categories such as "roots" or "world music" had become part of the pop vocabulary, and after surviving the barren years of the 1980s, he returned with a vengeance. He has worked with artists from the West Indies, India, Hawaii (where he has been living) and of course Africa. Kulanjan, recorded with the kora virtuoso Toumani Diabate, was seen by many as world music album of last year.

His new album Shoutin' in Key marks his return to old-style R&B, and was recorded live with his Phantom Blues Band, who joined him in Shepherd's Bush. An ideal Taj Mahal show would be one in which he mixed his beloved blues with all his other global influences, but for this concert he stuck to the black styles of the US.

There were further limitations. He may be capable of playing over 20 instruments, but here he played guitar on just a few songs, and harmonica on a few others. For the most part he simply sang. He may not be quite up there in the Sam Cooke or Ray Charles league, but what he lacks in sensitivity he makes up for in variety and enthusiasm, and his vocals were best heard on old classicssuch as Paint My Mailbox Blue, or the early Stones favourite, Down Home Girl. Elsewhere, he slowed down to revive Percy Mayfield's Stranger in My Own Home Town, threw in some classic R&B with Mr Pitiful, and veered towards jazz for Senor Blues, with his seven-piece band providing strong backing with some good brass and Hammond organ solos.

Great solid stuff, even if he never brought out his National Steel or provided any reminder of his African adventures with Diabate or Ali Farka Toure. This was left to the remarkably fine opening band, an engaging trio known as Flanagan, who played excellent slide guitar on old Bukka White blues, then switched to their own African blues tribute, Ali From Mali. Look out for them.

fields.headline: Daniel Johnston
fields.body:
Teddy-bear endearing though he is, Daniel Johnston is deeply unsettling to watch. It's not because the manic depressive 38-year-old once dreamed that his audience wanted to decapitate him, nor because he is known for thinking that certain people (strangers, Metallica, most inhabitants of Texas, where he lives) are the devil. Both stories are inclined to make you fearful of meeting his eyes, in case he sees something in you he doesn't like, but he soothes the uneasy by spending most of the show squinting in concentration. No, it's not the stories, but the songs that disturb, the images of death, the confessions of sadness that haunt his lyrics and jolt you like tiny electric shocks.

"Laughter can be an awful sound", "All of her hopes had been shattered", "Death waits for you so patiently", "After my first 1,000 years in hell I was burning, couldn't stand the smell" - dark thoughts accumulate through the show, each making you flinch. Folly finds Johnston musing on the horrors of the world, everything from the horrible influence of Hollywood movies to the evils of fast food: "The cows stand in line waiting to be hamburger, oh how they suffer." It looks funny written down, but there is something appalling about the bleak clarity of Johnston's lyrics. This isn't naivety, the word most often used to describe him, it is a deliberate morbid honesty and not a little gallows humour. "I had a dream that a man was sentenced to death for attempting to commit suicide," Johnston tells us blankly. A few people laugh, but most just shiver.

And then he changes everything with a little smile, with his excitement at being in London - "home of the Beatles!" - and being able to play for fans who have waited years (six, in my case) to see him, even if only for a too-brief half hour. It is impossible not to be charmed by this strange man in his faded tracksuit bottoms and old T-shirt, balancing his blunt-toned guitar on his swollen belly, singing in a sometimes faltering, sometimes lilting melody that goes crooked every time an idea takes him gambolling beyond the rhythm. "I'm drinking my life away," he mourns, "even though it's only Kool-Aid." We giggle. "Everyone should be an artist, guitarist, express yourself," he advises on Frustrated Artist, and we cheer. And then the mood twists again: "Oh, the sadness of the world, because I love you." His voice quivers, just slightly, and the words are a blow to the heart.

fields.headline: RLPO/ Handley
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
****
fields.body:
Vernon Handley's old association with the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra has been one of the foundation stones of his championing of British music. His achievements received the warmest of celebrations in a 70th birthday tribute concert: an all-British programme of relatively little-known works from the 1930s. With not a whiff of the "cowpat school" about them, Handley's chosen works - Bliss's Music for Strings, Vaughan Williams's Five Tudor Portraits and Bax's Sixth Symphony - together provided compelling evidence of the breadth of talent and originality of composers who can be all too easily pigeonholed.

In fact, Bliss's homeland could scarcely be guessed at from his Music for Strings, which had perceptible Slavic leanings, most discernible in the intensity of his soloistic string textures. By contrast, Vaughan Williams' settings of John Skelton's poems evoked a English schoolboyish humour and boisterousness, as well as the familiar bittersweet lyricism prompted by Jane Scroop's lament over her dead pet sparrow. The irony of Skelton's poem is smoothed over by the tenderness of its musical setting, which seems to bear out the composer's avowed sympathy with Skelton's mournful heroine. Here, as elsewhere in the Portraits, the RLPO and chorus were on fine form; contralto Liane Keegan was particularly impressive as the passionate Jane, although Damian Thantrey's baritone was perhaps slightly constrained in a rather subdued rendition of Pretty Bess. The first and last songs romped along with a Dionysian energy, with a wonderfully tipsy bassoon solo in the first, The Tunning of Elinor Rumming.

Performances of Bax's symphonies are rare events; Handley's choice of the Sixth for his birthday concert testifies to his special affinity for this unfairly neglected work. Whether the RLPO were simply tired out by a demanding first half, or whether shortage of rehearsal time had been a problem, they were not able to deliver on this occasion.

This was a pity, since Bax's Sixth is not an easy piece to love on first hearing; many of its textures and cross-rhythms are unusual enough to be off-putting if not played with total conviction. In the context of such dedicated programming, full appreciation of this work was difficult; nevertheless, to hear it at all made this concert a special event.

webTitle: Bank ties down interest rates for ninth month

fields.headline: Bank ties down interest rates for ninth month
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee left interest rates on hold for the ninth month yesterday, fuelling increasing City expectations that the cost of borrowing has peaked.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's monetary policy committee left interest rates on hold for the ninth month yesterday, fuelling increasing City expectations that the cost of borrowing has peaked.

The decisions to peg rates at 6% was widely anticipated following a stream of data pointing to a slowdown in economic growth, and had no impact on the financial markets.

"We have long argued that rates would peak at 6%, but this does not mean that there is now a green light for rate reductions," said Roger Bootle, economic adviser to accountants Deloitte & Touche.

"The MPC will want to see what Mr Brown does in the Budget in March, and to assure itself that a plunge in the pound is not going to cause inflation to surge." webTitle: Flood bill likely to top forecast

fields.headline: Flood bill likely to top forecast
fields.standfirst:
Dwellers at risk face higher insurance costs
Special report: the weather
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The estimated bill for the floods that have ravaged Britain is beginning to exceed insurers' initial expectations after Royal & Sun Alliance said yesterday it expects the damage throughout Europe to cost it up to £110m.
fields.body:
The estimated bill for the floods that have ravaged Britain is beginning to exceed insurers' initial expectations after Royal & Sun Alliance said yesterday it expects the damage throughout Europe to cost it up to £110m.

The disclosure comes a day after CGNU, Britain's biggest insurer, said its exposure to claims for flood and storm damage could hit £200m.

That total of £300m for two companies contrasts with the Association of British Insurers' statement that the total cost of the flood damage was likely to be £200m-£500m.

Royal & Sun Alliance chief executive Bob Mendelsohn warned that insurance premiums for those living on flood plains might have to rise. He stressed that it was too soon to speculate and a "knee-jerk reaction" was unlikely.

He was speaking after the insurer announced third-quarter results slightly below market expectations. Britain's second-largest general insurer said group operating profits for the nine months to Sep tember 30 rose to £502m from £461m last time. Shares closed down 6p at 489p.

The floods and storms are expected to cost it £80m-£110m but Mr Mendelsohn said: "Estimates are very preliminary and may vary significantly, upward or downward, as events develop. Obviously the event is still going on."

The bill would almost certainly be well below that for the hurricane of 1987, which cost Royal & Sun Alliance £450m.

The company had already identified policyholders living on flood plains and was pricing this into their premium rates. It would look at overall weather patterns and, if it believed the incidence of flooding was going to increase, these people would face premium increases, Mr Mendelsohn said.

For the vast majority of customers, who do not live in such areas, the impact on premiums was likely to be modest.

Some experts, including Jeffrey Salmon at Salmon Assessors, have said the total bill for the floods and storms could exceed £1bn. He claimed premiums could rise by as much as 60% over the next six months.

R&SA said that over the year to date general insurance premiums rose by 19% to £6.33bn, primarily due to acquisitions in the US and Scandinavia. UK life, pensions and investments sales were up 24% in annual premium equivalent terms to £167m.

Mr Mendelsohn tried to quell speculation that the insurer would make an acquisition to expand its fund management arm, Royal & Sun Alliance Investments.

fields.headline: State and Main
fields.standfirst:
London film festival
***
fields.trailText:
London film festival
***
fields.body:
"Communism's over? Huh! That's what they said about Warner Brothers in 1985!" Just a taste of the zappiest, snappiest dialogue available in the London film festival, and there are plenty more gags where that came from in David Mamet's State and Main, a light Capra-esque comedy that riffs amusingly, if insubstantially, on the theme of Hollywood versus America.

William H Macy is a haggard film director strung out on his own nervous energy, who turns up in a picturesque little town with a caravan of faintly unwholesome movie folk, including Bob Barrenger (Alec Baldwin), a louche leading man with a taste for underage girls. It turns out that they have been virtually run out of the last town they were in by creditors, so now they have to make their movie with whatever buildings happen to be around them. Philip Seymour Hoffman is Joseph, a once promising dramatist, lured into writing the screenplay for this film and now driven to distraction by fanatical demands for rewrites from Macy and from Marty Rossen (David Paymer), the quicksilver- tempered producer.

Hoffman (who is everywhere at the LFF this year) gives a performance that establishes him credibly as a romantic funny-valentine-type leading man, as he spurns the sexual advances of leading lady Claire (Sarah Jessica Parker) in favour of the brainy bookstore owner Ann, nicely played by Rebecca Pidgeon, a performance of much more style and ease than the one she produced in The Winslow Boy, David Mamet's unhappy and baffling excursion into British drawing-room drama.

Hoffman's basso profundo voice is always at its most compelling when it slows right down to a 45rpm-single-played-at-33rpm drawl, indicating agonised indecision and introspection: the kind of semi-inchoate groan that he first treated us to in Todd Solondz's Happiness. We get some of this here, and some of his gamely perky persona, his attempt to get along and go along with whatever craziness the movie industry is going to dish out.

It wouldn't be a David Mamet film without some sort of deception and illusion, and this duly arrives when Hoffman is forced to choose between his principles and his need to clamber up the Hollywood ladder. As in his stage play Speed-the-Plow, Mamet uses the wicked world of showbiz and the movies as the showcase for some fairly undemanding ethical dilemmas, but there is a lot of fun to be had here, and some terrific performances.

 At the Odeon West End, London WC2, tomorrow, and the Empire, London WC2, on Sunday. Box office: 020-7928 3232.

fields.headline: BT break-up sheds 5,000
fields.standfirst: £30bn debt and falling profits prompt last-minute dash to save credit rating
fields.trailText: BT yesterday announced a partial break-up of the company and said 5,000 jobs would be shed in the current financial year as it wrestles with a crippling combination of huge debts and falling profits.
fields.body:
BT yesterday announced a partial break-up of the company and said 5,000 jobs would be shed in the current financial year as it wrestles with a crippling combination of huge debts and falling profits.

The group is also scaling back its global ambitions and selling off £5bn worth of assets in Asia.

The company said it aimed to raise £10bn next year to pay down its substantial debts to a more manageable level.

Another £5bn will be raised from the partial stock market flotation of its directories business Yell and the global mobile phone business, BT Wireless.

BT has debts of £30bn and is anxious to avoid losing its "A" credit rating.

BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield described the restructuring as "no less dramatic in its way than the original privatisation in 1984." BT's problems stem from a combination of increasing competition, the huge cost of acquiring next-generation mobile phone licences and the accusation that it has overstretched itself. BT reported a slump in pre-tax profits for the first half of the year from £1.7bn to £1bn.

Further down the line there are plans to seek separate listings for its broadband division, BT Ignite, and its network business - the physical wires and cables.

The company has made 3,000 people redundant since April and there will be another 2,000 in the second half of the fiscal year. Head count will be reduced by another 5,000 in 2001, which the company said was in line with long term aims to make the business more efficient.

Sir Peter said the flotations would allow the individual companies to develop distinctive cultures from the "monolithic" parent group and make them more nimble. They will operate under a new holding company, which will hold the majority stakes and run centralised functions.

"BT is a big arse company - so does it move at the speed of a company with 10 people? Clearly not. We want to free up more parts of the business to give them that kind of speed," he said.

The most radical decision was the split of the wholesale and retail businesses which will need approval from the department of trade and industry. The network business - dubbed Netco - will operate at arm's length from the rest of BT and will be encouraged to seek contracts outside of the parent company.

Sir Peter identified western Europe and Japan as the key regions in which it intends to invest. Its global venture with AT&T, Concert, will continue to serve multinationals.

Yell - expected to be worth £4bn - will float by the end of the financial year and BT Wireless, valued between £30bn and £50bn, by the second half of 2001. Timing on the other two is less certain.

Sir Peter said the strategy had been shaped by both himself and chairman Sir Iain Vallance, and scotched rumours that Sir Iain was on his way out. Sir Peter also dismissed any suggestion that there was any pressure on him to quit.

Analysts, however, were not swept off their feet by BT's plans. Many had argued for a full break-up of the company rather than the planned partial flotations.

"It's too little too late," said one. BT shares, worth £15.21 at the start of the year fell 38p further to 750p.

Mark Lambert at Merril Lynch said: "The strategic changes are moves in the right direction, but we do not see an overnight cure."

Big deals: Where money went
1984 British Telecom privatised

1985 Faces first serious competitor - Mercury

1991 Changes name to BT

1993 Pays $4.3bn to take a 20% stake in MCI ,hailed as "the deal of the century". Government sells the remainder of its shares in BT

1994 Creates Concert, a $1bn joint venture with MCI 1995 Appoints Peter Bonfield from ICL as chief executive. Sir Iain Vallance, chairman and chief executive since 1987, remains chairman

1996 Breaks off merger talks with Cable & Wireless. Says it will merge with MCI - creating the world's second largest telecoms group with revenues of £25bn

1997 Outbid by WorldCom for MCI - by $9bn

1998 Sir Iain to become part-time chairman.BT clinches deal with AT&T to form a $10bn global joint venture

April 2000 Pays £4bn for 3G mobile phone licence, unveils plans to demerge a new Yellow Pages and e-commerce division. August Completes £18bn corporate debt restructuring. October Misses out on Italian 3G licence

fields.headline: BSO/Litton
fields.standfirst:
Poole Arts Centre
***
fields.trailText:
Poole Arts Centre
***
fields.body:
Mahler's 10th Symphony is a problematic piece. The work was left unfinished at Mahler's death, with only the first movement in a definitive, orchestrated form.

However, the sketches for the remaining four movements are advanced enough to represent a continuous draft of the whole symphony. For those who see the elegiac final movement of his Ninth Symphony as a reconciliation with his fate (Mahler had been diagnosed with a fatal heart condition) the completed 10th Symphony is too bitter a vision to contemplate. Even as far as its opening adagio, the symphony plunges into a nightmarish, desperate world - suggesting that Mahler did not find spiritual peace in his final years after all.

Thanks to the passionate performances of conductors such as Simon Rattle and Riccardo Chailly, the completion of the 10th Symphony by Deryck Cooke, in collaboration with Berthold Goldschmidt and David and Colin Matthews, is now much more than a mere concert-hall curiosity. However, it is still unusual to hear an alternative version of the symphony. Around the same time that Cooke was working on his edition, the American Clinton Carpenter embarked upon his own attempt to bring Mahler's sketches to life. Rarely heard in this country, Carpenter's realisation was performed by Andrew Litton and the Bourne-mouth Symphony Orchestra.

The broad outlines of both versions are similar. It is in the details of the orchestrations that differences are most acute. The challenge for anyone daring to breathe life into Mahler's sketches is in matching the extraordinary range of Mahler's imagination. In Mahler's other symphonies, instrumental timbre is almost as crucial to the narrative of the music as the notes. And though Carpenter creates a definite contrast between the worlds of each movement - from the rustic energy of the second to the weird dervishes of the third - there are also places of un-Mahlerian muddiness.

But Litton and the BSO were committed advocates of Carpenter's Mahler, and made the symphony a terrifying revelation. Even the signs of strife in the enormously taxing string lines of the first and last movements only added to the sense of the human torment of this music, and the emotional abyss that Mahler creates. The 10th Symphony remains an enigma, in whichever version it is played: surely that would have been true even if Mahler himself had lived to complete the piece.
